vignette.presentation:
2. A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of gradually progressive weakness in the shoulder and hip muscles. She
has hypothyroidism treated with thyroxine but is otherwise healthy. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows moderate
bilateral weakness of the deltoid, biceps, triceps, psoas, glutei, and quadriceps muscles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
Her erythrocyte sedimentat ion rate is 85 mm/h, and serum creatine kinase activity is 2456 U/L. Complete blood count and urinalysis are within
normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Electromyograp hy and nerve conduction studies

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Electromyography and nerve conduction studies are used to support a diagnosis of inflammatory myopathy such as polymyositis, as in this case. Polymyositis is an autoimmune condition affecting the proximal muscles. It is closely related to dermatomyositis, however, unlike dermatomyositis, it does not present with cutaneous findings. The muscular inflammation is characterized by endomysial COB+ inflammatory infiltrate. This is in contrast to dermatomyositis which demonstrates a perimysial CD4+ inflammato ry infiltrate. An inflammatory infiltrate of the muscle occurs, causing damage to the myocytes, leading to release of creatine kinase, an intracellular molecule. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is also increased, indicating the presence of inflammation. This can be used to monitor disease progress in polymyositis. Both polymyositis and dermatomyositis are characterized by several autoantibodies: positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) and anti-Jo-1, anti-SRP, and anti-Mi-2. Treatment of polymyositis involves systemic steroids followed by long-term immunosuppressive therapy with medications such as methotrexate or azathioprine.

distractor_explanations.A: Quantitative sensory testing is used to evaluate damage to small and large nerve endings, not primary muscle inflammation. MRI of the spinal cord (Choice C) would be beneficial in evaluating muscle weakness because of a spinal epidural abscess or tumor. While these pathologies can cause proximal muscle weakness, other symptoms such as fever, back pain, and sensory deficits would also be seen. As polymyositis is an inflammatory myopathy with no spinal cord involvement, imaging of the spinal cord will not be helpful. Skin biopsy (Choice D) is indicated in evaluation of suspected dermatomyositis. However, this patient does not demonstrate any cutaneous findings, and thus, a skin biopsy is not warranted Clinical C) MRI of the spinal cord D) Skin biopsy E) Lumbar puncture Correct Answer: B. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies are used to support a diagnosis of inflammatory myopathy such as polymyositis, as in this case. Polymyositis is an autoimmune condition affecting the proximal muscles. It is closely related to dermatomyositis, however, unlike dermatomyositis, it does not present with cutaneous findings. The muscular inflammation is characterized by endomysial CD8+ inflammatory infiltrate. This is in contrast to dermatomyositis which demonstrates a perimysial CD4+ inflammatory infiltrate. An inflammatory infiltrate of the muscle occurs, causing damage to the myocytes, leading to release of creatine kinase, an intracellular molecule. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is also increased, indicating the presence of inflammation. This can be used to monitor disease progress in polymyositis. Both polymyositis and dermatomyositis are characterized by several autoantibodies: positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) and anti-Jo-1, anti-SRP, and anti-Mi-2. Treatment of polymyositis involves systemic steroids followed by long-term immunosuppressive therapy with medications such as methotrexate or azathioprine. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, and E. Quantitative sensory testing (Choice A) is used to evaluate damage to small and large nerve endings, not primary muscle inflammation. MRI of the spinal cord (Choice C) would be beneficial in evaluating muscle weakness because of a spinal epidural abscess or tumor. While these pathologies can cause proximal muscle weakness, other symptoms such as fever, back pain, and sensory deficits would also be seen. As polymyositis is an inflammatory myopathy with no spinal cord involvement, imaging of the spinal cord will not be helpful. Skin biopsy (Choice D) is indicated in evaluation of suspected dermatomyositis. However, this patient does not demonstrate any cutaneous findings, and thus, a skin biopsy is not warranted. Lumbar puncture (Choice E) may be used to diagnose Guillain-Barre syndrome, a demyelinating polyneuropathy that starts with the distal extremities and progresses proximally. It may affect the lungs through diaphragmatic paralysis, which is the most serious complication of the disease. While proximal muscle weakness can ensue, this would only occur after involvement of the distal extremities.

explanation.educational_objective: Polymyositis and dermatomyositis are autoimmune inflammatory myopathies. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies are part of the initial evaluation of these diseases. ., Clinical

vignette.presentation:
4. One day after undergo ing an elective cholecystectomy, a 67-year-o ld woman becomes confused and belligerent. She has a 2-year history of mild
dementia, Alzheimer type. She takes no medications. Intramuscular haloperidol is administered, and 1 hour later, she begins to repetitively
hyperextend her neck. She also has repetitive conjugate upward movements of the eyes that she says she cannot control. Examination shows no
other abnorma lities. Administration of a medication with which of the following properties is the most appropriate treatment?

question_stem: the most appropriate treatment?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Acute dystonias can occur in response to antipsychotics, such as haloperidol, antiepileptic drugs, or antiemetics. Common presentations include torticollis (head tilted to the side and down), retrocollis (head tilted back), opisthotonos (arching of the back), and oculogyric crisis (upward deviation of the eyes). It rarely presents with laryngospasm and strider. These movements are involuntary and cannot be controlled by the patient. The pathophysiology is an imbalance in the dopaminergic-cholinergic pathways of the basal ganglia. Risk factors for development include male sex, young age, recent cocaine use, and a history of previous acute dystonic reaction. Acute dystonias are treated with diphenhydramine or benztropine, both of which are anticholinergic medications that work to restore the proper balance in the dopaminergic and cholinergic pathways.

distractor_explanations.B: Antidopaminergic agents are used primarily in the treatment of schizophrenia and include agents such as haloperidol. Antidopaminergic agents can also be used to treat nausea. As acute dystonias are caused by an imbalance in the dopaminergic and cholinergic pathways, further antagonism of dopamine would likely worsen symptoms.
distractor_explanations.C: Antiserotonergic medications are used to treat nausea, especially chemotherapy-induced nausea and emesis. Some antidepressants and antipsychotics also have antiserotonergic activity. However, serotonin is not involved in the pathophysiology of acute dystonia.
distractor_explanations.D: Cholinergic agents increase the amount of acetylcholine present in the neuromuscular junction, which leads to increased muscular contraction. They can be used to treat myasthenia gravis, to reverse neuromuscular blockade, and to improve symptoms associated with Alzheimer disease. Cholinergic agents would worsen this patient's acute dystonia.
distractor_explanations.E: Dopaminergic drugs are used to treat Parkinson disease by increasing the amount of dopamine available in the nigrostriatal pathway. This leads to increased movement and improvements in bradykinesia. Dopaminergic agents would not improve acute dystonia.
distractor_explanations.F: Serotonergic medications primarily include antidepressant medications. Serotonin is not involved in the pathophysiology of acute dystonia.

explanation.educational_objective: Acute dystonia most commonly occurs in response to typical antipsychotics and presents with torticollis, retrocollis, opisthotonos, and oculogyric crisis. Treatment involves anticholinergic medications, such as diphenhydramine or benztropine. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Acute dystonia most commonly occurs in response to typical antipsychotics and presents with torticollis, retrocollis, opisthotonos, and oculogyric crisis. Treatment involves anticholinergic medication

vignette.presentation:
5. A previously healthy 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of progressive sensory loss. Initially, only her feet felt
numb, but the loss of sensation has slowly ascended symmetrically to the umbilicus. She also has had urinary urgency and frequency, nocturia, and
the perception of a tight band-like sensation around her midabdominal region. Examination shows slowing of left eye adduction during saccadic
movement of the eyes to the right. There is diffuse hyperreflexia. Sensation to pinprick is decreased to the level of the umbilicus. Which of the
following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Multiple sclerosis, the most prevalent immune-mediated demyelinating disease, may present initially with transverse myelitis though can also demonstrate neurologic symptoms from lesions in other central nervous system (CNS) locations. Transverse myelitis refers to inflammation that extends transversely across the spinal cord, leading to bilateral sensory, motor, or autonomic dysfunction. When sensory tracts are involved, sensory deficits are evident at a clear dermatomal level (also known as a sensory level, likely T10 in this patient) and may present as a band-like sensation at that level. Autonomic symptoms may present as urinary urgency or incontinence, bowel incontinence, or sexual dysfunction. According to the McDonald criteria for multiple sclerosis diagnosis, patients must have evidence of demyelinating lesions that are separated in time and location. This evidence can be based on subjective symptoms or imaging evidence. This patient presents with evidence of lesions separated in space (a T10 spinal cord lesion, a lesion potentially affecting the medial longitudinal fasciculus, several corticospinal tract lesions as evidenced by diffuse hyperreflexia). Though the patient did not experience discrete symptomatic episodes separated by time, the presence of multiple lesions in discrete locations makes multiple sclerosis the most likely diagnosis (as the other deficits likely arose at different times). MRI of the brain typically shows white matter hyperintensities in the periventricular region, cortex, subcortical region, cerebellum, or spine. Oligoclonal bands of immunoglobu lins, indicating immune overactivation, can be found in the cerebrospinal fluid but are not necessary for diagnosis. Treatment includes corticosteroids for symptomatic management of acute flares and long-term disease-modifying treatments such as interferon or monoclonal antibodies.

distractor_explanations.A: Adrenal leukodystrophy is a rare X-linked peroxisomal disorder that results from the accumulation of very long fatty acid chains in various tissues. As a result of peripheral neuropathy and myelopathy, female carriers of the disorder may present with bilateral spastic paraparesis, sphincter dysfunction, neurogenic bladder, and sexual dysfunction. However, multiple sclerosis is more common, r ~ - - - , r, Clinical E) Multiple sclerosis Correct Answer: E. As a result of peripheral neuropathy and myelopathy, female carriers of the disorder may present with bilateral spastic paraparesis, sphincter dysfunction, neurogenic bladder, and sexual dysfunction. However, multiple sclerosis is more common, and transverse myelitis is more typical of multiple sclerosis than adrenal leukodystrophy. Patients with multiple sclerosis may present initially with transverse myelitis, which may demonstrate a sensory level and a band-like sensation, along with possible autonomic and motor symptoms Clinical

vignette.presentation:
6. A 67-year-old woman is brought to the physician 3 hours after a 5-minute episode of visual loss in her left eye. She has not had any other
symptoms. She has hypertension and stable angina pectoris. Medications include lisinopril and metoprolol. Her pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure
is 150/92 mm Hg. Funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. A grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best at the apex. Neurologic
examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Amaurosis fugax describes brief episodes of transient, unilateral vision loss and is indicative of retinal ischemia caused by either microembolization or inflammation of the ophthalmic artery. It often precedes the onset of central retinal artery occlusion , which is considered an ophthalmic stroke. In the absence of signs and symptoms of giant cell arteritis, such as fever, chills, weight loss, temporal headache and tenderness, or jaw claudication, amaurosis fugax is most suggestive of embolic retinal ischemia and should prompt an emergent evaluation for sources of emboli. The majority of emboli to the ophthalmic vasculature originate from the carotid arteries and cardiac valves. Evaluation should include prompt carotid duplex ultrasonography, as well as echocardiography. Treatment of carotid vascular or cardiac valvular disease can prevent central retinal arterial occlusion, which may cause irreversible blindness.

distractor_explanations.A: Complete blood count and measurement of erythrocyte sedimentation rate (Choice B) are useful for the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis, which often presents with amaurosis fugax, thrombocytosis, and an increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate. However, this patient's lack of other symptoms renders carotid arterial disease, rather than giant cell arteritis, as the more likely cause of her amaurosis fugax. Visual field testing (Choice C) may be useful for the diagnosis of glaucoma or cortical vision loss. Delaying the search for embolic sources while pursuing other diagnostic tests puts the patient at risk for ischemic stroke and blindness. MRI of the brain (Choice D) may be useful for the diagnosis of optic neuritis. It is not useful for identifying the source of emboli that are causing this patient's amaurosis fugax. Vision loss secondary to optic neuritis typically lasts for several days or weeks, rather than minutes Clinical F) Ocular tonometry Correct Answer: E. Amaurosis fugax describes brief episodes of transient, unilateral vision loss and is indicative of retinal ischemia caused by either microembolization or inflammation of the ophthalmic artery. It often precedes the onset of central retinal artery occlusion, which is considered an ophthalmic stroke. In the absence of signs and symptoms of giant cell arteritis, such as fever, chills, weight loss, temporal headache and tenderness, or jaw claudication, amaurosis fugax is most suggestive of embolic retinal ischemia and should prompt an emergent evaluation for sources of emboli. The majority of emboli to the ophthalmic vasculature originate from the carotid arteries and cardiac valves. Evaluation should include prompt carotid duplex ultrasonography, as well as echocardiography. Treatment of carotid vascular or cardiac valvular disease can prevent central retinal arterial occlusion, which may cause irreversible blindness. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, and F. Complete blood count (Choice A) and measurement of erythrocyte sedimentation rate (Choice B) are useful for the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis, which often presents with amaurosis fugax, thrombocytosis, and an increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate. However, this patient's lack of other symptoms renders carotid arterial disease, rather than giant cell arteritis, as the more likely cause of her amaurosis fugax. Visual field testing (Choice C) may be useful for the diagnosis of glaucoma or cortical vision loss. Delaying the search for embolic sources while pursuing other diagnostic tests puts the patient at risk for ischemic stroke and blindness. MRI of the brain (Choice D) may be useful for the diagnosis of optic neuritis. It is not useful for identifying the source of emboli that are causing this patient's amaurosis fugax. Vision loss secondary to optic neuritis typically lasts for several days or weeks, rather than minutes. Ocular tonometry (Choice F) allows for the measurement of intraocular pressure and is useful for the diagnosis of glaucoma, which is characterized by slowly progressive optic nerve damage in the setting of increased intraocular pressure. The vision loss caused by glaucoma is insidious and characterized by initial peripheral vision loss with slow encroachment upon central vision. Glaucoma does not present with amaurosis fugax.

explanation.educational_objective: Amaurosis fugax describes brief episodes of transient, unilateral vision loss and is indicative of retinal ischemia as a result of emboli. It often precedes the onset of central retinal artery occlusion, which is an ophthalmic stroke. Patients who present with amaurosis fugax should undergo an emergent evaluation with carotid duplex ultrasonography and echocardiography to prevent an ischemic stroke of the eye or of the brain. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Amaurosis fugax describes brief episodes of transient, unilateral vision loss and is indicative of retinal ischemia as a result of emboli. It often precedes the onset of central retinal artery occlusi

vignette.presentation:
7. A previously healthy 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive weakness, numbness, and tingling of
both arms. Her pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the upper extremities and
4/5 in the lower extremities. There is muscle wasting and atrophy of the forearms and hands bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the
upper extremities and 4+ in the lower extremities. Babinski sign is present bilaterally. There is decreased sensation to pinprick and light touch in
the upper extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient presenting with an upper motor neuron pattern of dysfunction in the lower extremities and a lower motor neuron-pattern of dysfunction in the upper extremities likely has syringomyelia. Syringomyelia features a progressively expanding cystic lesion involving midline spinal cord structures. Syringomyelia may be associated with congenital malformations such as Chiari type I malformation, spinal cord infections, autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, neoplasms, or spinal cord trauma. Syringomyelia typically damages spinothalamic fibers decussating in the anterior white commissure. Consequent ly, patients present with deficits in pain and temperature sensation in the bilateral upper extremities (since the ascending spinothalamic tracts in the lateral spinal cord are unaffected, sensation in the lower body is intact). The spinothalamic tract also carries sensory fibers that mediate poorly localized light touch (versus localized light touch fibers of the posterior columns). The cystic lesion can expand to the bilateral anterior horns (the location of the cell bodies of lower motor neurons). Therefore, patients may also present with a lower motor neuron pattern of dysfunction in the bilateral upper extremities (eg, decreased muscle tone, hyporeflexia, early muscle atrophy). The cyst may also progressive ly expand to the lateral corticospinal tract in severe cases, leading to an upper motor neuron pattern of dysfunction (eg, spastic weakness, hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign) in the lower body.

distractor_explanations.A: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that affects the anterior horns along with the lateral corticospinal tract as it descends in the brain and spinal cord. Subsequently, patients demonstrate a combination of upper and lower motor neuron findings in an asymmetric distribution that may include the bulbar muscles. Sensory impairment would be atypical, and a pattern of dysfunction that can be localized to a single lesion within the cervical spine is more consistent with syringomyelia. Guillain-Barre syndrome (Choice B) is an inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy that presents with acute-onset, ascending, j • Exam Section : Item 47 of 50 Clinical Correct Answer: D. Syringomyelia typically damages spinothalamic fibers decussating in the anterior white commissure. Consequent ly, patients present with deficits in pain and temperature sensation in the bilateral upper extremities (since the ascending spinothalamic tracts in the lateral spinal cord are unaffected, sensation in the lower body is intact). The spinothalamic tract also carries sensory fibers that mediate poorly localized light touch (versus localized light touch fibers of the posterior columns). The cystic lesion can expand to the bilateral anterior horns (the location of the cell bodies of lower motor neurons). Therefore, patients may also present with a lower motor neuron pattern of dysfunction in the bilateral upper extremities (eg, decreased muscle tone, hyporeflexia, early muscle atrophy). The cyst may also progressive ly expand to the lateral corticospinal tract in severe cases, leading to an upper motor neuron pattern of dysfunction (eg, spastic weakness, hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign) in the lower body. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and E. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Choice A) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that affects the anterior horns along with the lateral corticospinal tract as it descends in the brain and spinal cord. Subsequently, patients demonstrate a combination of upper and lower motor neuron findings in an asymmetric distribution that may include the bulbar muscles. Sensory impairment would be atypical, and a pattern of dysfunction that can be localized to a single lesion within the cervical spine is more consistent with syringomyelia. Guillain-Barre syndrome (Choice B) is an inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy that presents with acute-onset, ascending, bilateral muscle weakness with hyporeflexia. Many patients also demonstrate autonomic dysfunction and/or sensory symptoms. A chronic time course and an upper motor neuron pattern of dysfunction are inconsistent with Guillain-Barre syndrome. Postherpetic neuralgia (Choice C) refers to prolonged burning pain after the resolution of shingles. Motor dysfunction is inconsistent with postherpetic neuralgia. Tabes dorsalis (Choice E) refers to neurosyphilis of the posterior columns and dorsal roots of the spinal cord. Patients typically present with impaired sensation of light touch, vibration, and proprioception along with ataxia. Motor dysfunction would be atypical.

explanation.educational_objective: Syringomyelia features a cystic cavity in the central cervical or thoracic spinal cord, which affects midline structures such as the anterior white commissure (decussation of the spinothalamic tracts) and the anterior horns (cell bodies of lower motor neurons). Patients with syringomyelia may present with deficits in pain and temperature sensation and a lower motor neuron pattern of dysfunction in the bilateral upper extremities. The syrinx may progressively expand to affect the lateral corticospinal tract, leading to an upper motor neuron pattern of dysfunction in the lower body Clinical
explanation.concept: Syringomyelia features a cystic cavity in the central cervical or thoracic spinal cord, which affects midline structures such as the anterior white commissure (decussation of the spinothalamic tracts)

vignette.presentation:
8. A 42-year-old woman with alcoholism has severe burning paresthesias of both feet and decreased vibratory sensation in both ankles 2 months after
beginning treatment for active, cavitary pulmonary tuberculosis. At the time of diagnosis she was malnourished, and isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol,
vitamin B and folic acid were prescribed. The most likely cause of paresthesias of her feet and decreased sensation in her ankles is failure to take
6
which of the following prescribed medications?

question_stem:
The most likely cause of paresthesias of her feet and decreased sensation in her ankles is failure to take
6
which of the following prescribed medications?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Primary tuberculosis results from an initial exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis, leading to the development of hilar lymphadenopathy and a Ghon focus (Ghon complex), as in this case. In the primary infection, patients present with subacute fevers, weight loss, night sweats, cough, and malaise. Active tuberculosis is treated primarily with a combination of rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. lsoniazid binds vitamin B (pyridoxine) which may result in early excretion and inactivation of pyridoxine, 6 and also inhibits pyridoxine phosphokinase, which is necessary to activate it. Pyridoxine deficiency then results, of which the primary symptoms are peripheral neuropathy or paresthesia. Therefore, all patients taking isoniazid concurrently take pyridoxine supplementation. Pyridoxine deficiency limits synthesis of histamine, hemoglobin, and neurotransmitters including epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine, serotonin, and y-aminobutyric acid (GABA). In addition to peripheral neuropathy, deficiency commonly presents with dermatitis, sideroblastic anemia, glossitis, and seizures.

distractor_explanations.A: Ethambutol is used to treat mycobacterial infection. It neither contributes to nor prevents vitamin B deficiency. Its primary 6 side effects include optic neuropathy, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. Folic acid (Choice B) is converted to tetrahydrofolic acid and is used as a coenzyme in the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleosides. Folate is contained in leafy vegetables and absorbed in the jejunum. Folate deficiency is often seen in patients with malnutrition, alcohol use disorder, and patients taking anti-folate medications (eg, phenytoin, methotrexate). It is not caused by any of the medications used to treat tuberculosis. lsoniazid (Choice C) binds vitamin B and leads to deficiency if not adequately supplemented. Deficiency of vitamin B causes 6 6 peripheral neuropathy, as in this case. If the patient failed to take isoniazid, she would not experience this side effect, though her tuberculosis infection would be suboptimally treated.
distractor_explanations.D: Rifampin is an anti-tuberculosis drug that increases the activity of the CYP450 enzymes in the liver. It also causes bodily fluids to exhibit an orange tinge. It does not affect concentrations of vitamin B5-

explanation.educational_objective: lsoniazid therapy for latent tuberculosis without sufficient pyridoxine supplementation can lead to pyridoxine deficiency. This is characterized by peripheral neuropathy, dermatitis, sideroblastic anemia, glossitis, and seizures. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: lsoniazid therapy for latent tuberculosis without sufficient pyridoxine supplementation can lead to pyridoxine deficiency. This is characterized by peripheral neuropathy, dermatitis, sideroblastic ane

vignette.presentation:
9. A 20-year-old college student comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 2 days after sustaining a head injury when he ran into another
player while playing flag football. He did not lose consciousness but does not remember anything from the rest of the game. He was evaluated in
the emergency department 1 hour after the injury; a CT scan of the head showed no abnormalities and he was discharged. Today, he reports a mild,
persistent headache that improves with acetaminophen. He has not had nausea, vomiting, or memory problems and was able to return to school
today. Examination shows no abnormalities. He asks about playing i11 a flag football playoff game tomorrow. Which of the following is the most
appropriate recommendation?

choices.text: No contact sports pending evaluation in 1 wee!<
No contact sports pending an MRI of the brain
No contact sports pending a lumbar puncture
No contact sports for 1 year; schedule regular follow-up examinations
Return to sports; no further management is indicated at this time
No contact sports pending a lumbar puncture
No contact sports for 1 year; schedule regular follow-up examinations
Return to sports; no further management is indicated at this time

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Mild traumatic brain injury, also known as a concussion, commonly results in loss of consciousness, confusion, amnesia, headache, dizziness, nausea, or vomiting minutes after the injury. Symptoms that commonly develop within the following days include mood disturbances, photophonophobia, trouble concentrating, or insomnia. Focal neurologic symptoms, such as limb weakness or vision changes, indicate traumatic vascular injury. As such, all patients with suspected concussion should undergo a thorough neurologic examination, and a subset of at-risk patients should receive neuroimaging. All patients should be monitored closely for 24 hours for neurologic deterioration, which may indicate a developing intracranial hematoma. To prevent cumulative brain injury (eg, from a second concussion), patients with concussion should return to their usual activities in a graded fashion, beginning with the return to school or work. Each day, a more intense activity can be introduced (eg, first light aerobic exercise), culminating with contact sports after a week in uncomplicated and improving cases.

distractor_explanations.B: An MRI of the brain may assist in detecting occult blood products in the subacute and chronic phases in patients with persistent symptoms. Repeat imaging is not necessary for patients with improving symptoms or patients in the acute phase with stable, expected symptoms such as mild headache. A lumbar puncture (Choice C) is not typically necessary for ruling out an intracranial hematoma in the setting of suspected concussion. Neuroimaging is sufficient. Prohibiting contact sports for a year (Choice D) would be unnecessary if a patient experiences improving symptoms after the acute r ~ - - - - , r - - - - , Clinical C) No contact sports pending a lumbar puncture D) No contact sports for 1 year; schedule regular follow-up examinations E) Return to sports; no further management is indicated at this time Correct Answer: A. Mild traumatic brain injury, also known as a concussion, commonly results in loss of consciousness, confusion, amnesia, headache, dizziness, nausea, or vomiting minutes after the injury. Symptoms that commonly develop within the following days include mood disturbances, photophonophobia, trouble concentrating, or insomnia. Focal neurologic symptoms, such as limb weakness or vision changes, indicate traumatic vascular injury. As such, all patients with suspected concussion should undergo a thorough neurologic examination, and a subset of at-risk patients should receive neuroimaging. All patients should be monitored closely for 24 hours for neurologic deterioration, which may indicate a developing intracranial hematoma. To prevent cumulative brain injury (eg, from a second concussion), patients with concussion should return to their usual activities in a graded fashion, beginning with the return to school or work. Each day, a more intense activity can be introduced (eg, first light aerobic exercise), culminating with contact sports after a week in uncomplicated and improving cases. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E. An MRI of the brain (Choice B) may assist in detecting occult blood products in the subacute and chronic phases in patients with persistent symptoms. Repeat imaging is not necessary for patients with improving symptoms or patients in the acute phase with stable, expected symptoms such as mild headache. A lumbar puncture (Choice C) is not typically necessary for ruling out an intracranial hematoma in the setting of suspected concussion. Neuroimaging is sufficient. Prohibiting contact sports for a year (Choice D) would be unnecessary if a patient experiences improving symptoms after the acute concussion phase. However, returning to sports immediately (Choice E) would put this patient at risk for serious progression of brain injury if another concussion were to occur.

explanation.educational_objective: Common early concussion symptoms include loss of consciousness, confusion, amnesia, headache, dizziness, nausea, or vomiting. To prevent cumulative brain injury, patients with a concussion should return to their usual activities in a graded fashion; contact sports are allowable after a week in uncomplicated and improving cases. ., Exam Section : Item 10 of 50 Clinical
explanation.concept: Common early concussion symptoms include loss of consciousness, confusion, amnesia, headache, dizziness, nausea, or vomiting. To prevent cumulative brain injury, patients with a concussion should retu

vignette.presentation:
10. A 19-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by paramedics after having a seizure at a dormitory party on campus. According to
her boyfriend, who accompanied her, she had been drinking more water than usual and then became silent and began staring. He then witnessed
her collapse to the floor and begin shaking for approximate ly 1 minute. On arrival, she is mute and unresponsive to questions. She appears
restless and periodically grinds her teeth. Her temperature is 39.6°C (103.3°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is
150/95 mm Hg. Physical examination shows profuse diaphoresis and piloerection. Pupils are 5 mm bilaterally. The remainder of the examination
shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Prothrombin time 16 sec
Serum
Na+ 114mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 40 mg/dL
Creatinine 2 mg/dL
ALT 90 U/L
Creatine kinase 1200 U/L
The most likely diagnosis is intoxication with which of the following substances?

question_stem: The most likely diagnosis is intoxication with which of the following substances?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MOMA), called ecstasy or "Molly," is a psychotherapeutic agent and drug of abuse. It is a stimulant and causes feelings of increased energy, euphoria, and disinhibition. Minor characteristic side effects include agitation, bruxism (grinding teeth), diaphoresis, and blurry vision. However, serious side effects also accompany ecstasy use. Autonomic instability (hypertension, tachycardia, and hyperthermia) can lead to life-threatening cardiovascular toxicity. This patient demonstrates another serious complication: hyponatremia secondary to increased water intake and secretion of anti-diuretic hormone. Severe hyponatremia may be accompanied by seizures, as seen in this case, as well as confusion, coma, or death. This is a particular risk in young women. Treatment includes rapid administration of hypertonic saline if recurrent seizure activity occurs, followed by gradual correction of sodium and management of autonomic instability.
explanation.educational_objective: 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MOMA), called ecstasy or "Molly," can potentially cause both minor and serious side effects, including autonomic instability, cardiovascu lar toxicity, and severe hyponatremia. ., Exam Section : Item 11 of 50 Clinical
explanation.concept: 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MOMA), called ecstasy or "Molly," can potentially cause both minor and serious side effects, including autonomic instability, cardiovascu lar toxicity, and severe hy

vignette.presentation:
11. A 47-year-o ld man with a history of alcoholism is brought to the emergency department by his family because of confusion. He lives alone, and
they found him disoriented 4 hours ago. An empty plastic container with a sweet odor was found in his apartment. He is oriented only to place.
Cranial nerves, motor strength, and sensation are normal. Serum studies show a creatinine concentrat ion of 1.5 mg/dl, bicarbonate concentrat ion
of 8 mEq/L, and an increased anion gap. Serum ketones test is negative. Urinalysis shows crystals. Exposure to which of the following is the most
likely cause of these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Patients with ingestion of ethylene glycol may present similarly to patients with alcohol intoxication, with central nervous system effects such as disorientation and altered mental status. Ethylene glycol is metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase to toxic metabolites including glycolate, glyoxylate, and oxalate. These metabolites are directly toxic to the kidneys through tubular damage as well as oxalate crystal precipitation causing tubule obstruction, resulting in acute kidney injury. Oxalate crystals are seen on urine microscopy. These metabolites also contribute to an anion-gap metabolic acidosis. Management of ethylene glycol poisoning involves fomepizo le, an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor that prevents metabolization of ethylene glycol to its toxic metabo lites. For severe ingestions, hemodial ysis to remove ethylene glycol and its metabolites may be necessary.

distractor_explanations.A: Acetaminophen toxicity is characterized by acute liver failure. At high doses, saturation of phase II metabolic pathways leads to excess acetaminophen being metabolized by cytochrome P450-mediated reactions to N-acetyl-p-benzoquinoneimine (NAPQI), which has strong oxidizing properties and is directly hepatotoxic .
distractor_explanations.B: Arsenic poisoning is uncommon and can cause dermatitis, skin cancer, neuropathy, hepatotoxicity, and in severe cases, systemic toxicity and death. Acute large exposure to arsenic can cause gastrointestina l distress, QT prolongation which may progress to Torsades de pointes, cardiac arrhythmias, shock, and acute respiratory distress syndrome. Carbon monoxide (CO) (Choice C) is a byproduct of combustion and poisoning occurs as a consequence of inhaling the gas. CO has an affinity for hemoglobin that is hundreds of times greater than that of oxygen, readily displacing oxygen from heme. Symptoms of CO poisoning include headache, loss of consciousness, dizziness, vomiting, and fatigue.
distractor_explanations.D: Cyanide inhibits the electron transport chain, leading to lactic acidosis, compensatory respiratory alkalosis, hypotension, lethargy, and bradycardia. It would not present with acute kidney injury and crystals on urinalysis.
distractor_explanations.E: Ethanol ingestion can present with altered mental status, but metabolic acidosis, crystals on urinalysis, and acute kidney injury are more likely because of ethylene glycol ingestion.
distractor_explanations.G: Methanol can be metabolized to formic acid, a toxic metabolite that can cause visual disturbances, retinal edema, optic disc hyperemia, gastrointestinal distress, putaminal hemorrhage, and neurologic depression.
distractor_explanations.H: Organophosphate poisoning is caused by increased concentrations of acetylcholine because of the inhibition of acetylcholinesterase. Symptoms of organophosphate poisoning include diarrhea, vomiting, urination, sweating, salivation, bronchospasm, lethargy, and possible coma.
distractor_explanations.I: Salicylate toxicity can present with hyperventi lation, gastrointestinal upset, hyperthermia, tinnitus, agitation, delirium, and hallucinations . Salicylates cause respiratory alkalosis and metabolic acidosis because of the decoupling of the electron transport chain.

explanation.educational_objective: Ethylene glycol is metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase to toxic metabolites including glycolate, glyoxylate, and oxalate. Patients present with an acute kidney injury, metabolic acidosis, and crystals on urinalysis Exam Section : Item 12 of 50 Clinical
explanation.concept: Ethylene glycol is metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase to toxic metabolites including glycolate, glyoxylate, and oxalate. Patients present with an acute kidney injury, metabolic acidosis, and crystal

vignette.presentation:
12. A 77-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician for a routine follow-up examination. He feels well. His only medication is a diuretic.
His blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. On neurologic examination, cranial nerves are intact. Muscle tone and strength are normal. Deep tendon
reflexes are absent in the ankles but otherwise normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Measureme nt of urine lead concentration

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: A thorough neurologic examination should include evaluation of the cranial nerves, gait, coordination, movement, muscle strength and tone, light touch, pain and temperature sensation, deep tendon reflexes, and the plantar response (Babinski sign). Deep tendon reflexes can be checked over the biceps, triceps, brachioradialis, knee, and Achilles tendons using a reflex hammer. They are graded on a scale of Oto 4 where 0 is absent, 2 is normal, and 4 is clonus (continual contraction). Reflex strength should be compared on either side and within the same patient. The Achilles reflex test is particularly useful for evaluating pathology of the S1 nerve root and differentiating upper from lower motor neuron dysfunction. However, bilaterally absent Achilles reflex is also a normal variation, the proportion of which increases with age. Thus, in this case, the absence of both Achilles reflexes does not require any additional management. Educational Objectives: A, B, C, and D. Measurement of urine lead concentration (Choice A) is appropriate when lead poisoning is suspected. Symptoms of lead poisoning occur within days or weeks of exposure and include distal motor neuropathy. While this does cause hyporeflexia, it would affect all the reflexes in the body, not just the Achilles. It would also cause other lower motor neuron symptoms such as muscle weakness, atrophy, and fasciculations, which this patient lacks. MRI of the lumbar spine (Choice B) would be beneficial in evaluating hyporeflexia because of a spinal nerve or spinal cord lesion. Neither of these pathologies would present with bilaterally absent Achilles reflexes alone without other symptoms like back pain or muscle weakness. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies (Choice C) are used to support a diagnosis of inflammatory myopathy such as polymyositis or dermatomyositis. This condition is associated with muscle weakness, not peripheral neuropathy. These studies are not necessary in this asymptomatic individual Exam Section : Item 12 of 50 Clinical E) No additional management is indicated Correct Answer: E. A thorough neurologic examination should include evaluation of the cranial nerves, gait, coordination, movement, muscle strength and tone, light touch, pain and temperature sensation, deep tendon reflexes, and the plantar response (Babinski sign). Deep tendon reflexes can be checked over the biceps, triceps, brachioradialis, knee, and Achilles tendons using a reflex hammer. They are graded on a scale of Oto 4 where 0 is absent, 2 is normal, and 4 is clonus (continual contraction). Reflex strength should be compared on either side and within the same patient. The Achilles reflex test is particularly useful for evaluating pathology of the S1 nerve root and differentiating upper from lower motor neuron dysfunction. However, bilaterally absent Achilles reflex is also a normal variation, the proportion of which increases with age. Thus, in this case, the absence of both Achilles reflexes does not require any additional management. Educational Objectives: A, B, C, and D. Measurement of urine lead concentration (Choice A) is appropriate when lead poisoning is suspected. Symptoms of lead poisoning occur within days or weeks of exposure and include distal motor neuropathy. While this does cause hyporeflexia, it would affect all the reflexes in the body, not just the Achilles. It would also cause other lower motor neuron symptoms such as muscle weakness, atrophy, and fasciculations, which this patient lacks. MRI of the lumbar spine (Choice B) would be beneficial in evaluating hyporeflexia because of a spinal nerve or spinal cord lesion. Neither of these pathologies would present with bilaterally absent Achilles reflexes alone without other symptoms like back pain or muscle weakness. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies (Choice C) are used to support a diagnosis of inflammatory myopathy such as polymyositis or dermatomyositis. This condition is associated with muscle weakness, not peripheral neuropathy. These studies are not necessary in this asymptomatic individual. Lumbar puncture (Choice D) may be used to diagnose Guillain-Barre syndrome, a self-limited demyelinating polyneuropathy that starts with the distal extremities and progresses proximally. While the Achilles reflexes would be absent, symptoms would also include lower extremity muscle weakness which is lacking in this patient. Educational Objective: The proportion of individuals who have bilaterally absent Achilles reflexes increases with age. Without other symptoms such as back pain or weakness, an older patient with bilaterally absent Achilles reflexes may be reassured that it is a normal finding. ., Clinical

vignette.presentation:
13. An otherwise healthy 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of decreased libido and delayed ejaculation. He says
that his symptoms are having a detrimental effect on his relationship. He has not had similar problems in the past. Four months ago, he was
evaluated for low mood and loss of interest and productivity; his symptoms have been well controlled with sertraline since that time. He takes no
other medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following neurotransmitters is most likely responsible for this
patient's current symptoms?

question_stem:
most likely responsible for this
patient's current symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Increased serotonin likely explains this patient's sexual dysfunction. Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that increases synaptic serotonin activity and improves mood in patients with major depressive disorder. SSRls commonly cause sexual dysfunction within all three phases of sexual response (libido, sexual arousal, and orgasm). If the sexual dysfunction is persistent and distressing, management commonly involves lowering the SSRI dose, switching to an antidepressant with a lower risk for sexual dysfunction (eg, bupropion, mirtazapine), or adding bupropion or a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor such as sildenafil. Libido is typically enhanced by dopamine and gonadal hormones and may be inhibited by medications such as antipsychotics and SSRls. Arousal is promoted by acetylcholine, which leads to vasodilation of the helicine/vaginal arteries and consequent penile/clitora l tumescence. Medications with anticholinergic activity and SSRls inhibit arousal. Norepinephrine enhances orgasm (and ejaculation), and beta blockers and SSRls inhibit orgasm.

distractor_explanations.A: Acetylcholine mediates arousal via the vasodilation of the helicine or vaginal arteries. Medications with anticholinergic activity, which include paroxetine but not sertraline within the SSRI class, may inhibit arousal but would not likely affect libido or ejaculation. y-Aminobutyric acid (Choice B), or GABA, is the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter. GABA is not known to be involved in sexual response.
distractor_explanations.D: Norepinephrine enhances orgasm and ejaculation. SSRls do not affect norepinephrine, and medications acting on norepinephrine would less likely affect libido.

explanation.educational_objective: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRls) commonly cause dysfunction in libido, sexual arousal, and orgasm/ejaculation. Lowering the SSRI dose, switching antidepressant medication, or adding phosphodiesterase inhibitors or bupropion may improve sexual dysfunction. ., Exam Section : Item 14 of 50 Clinical
explanation.concept: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRls) commonly cause dysfunction in libido, sexual arousal, and orgasm/ejaculation. Lowering the SSRI dose, switching antidepressant medication, or adding pho

vignette.presentation:
14. A previously healthy 27-year-o ld man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of pain in his neck and left shoulder radiating through
the lateral surface of his left arm to his thumb and index finger. Examination shows a decreased biceps reflex on the left. Muscle strength is 4/5 on
extension of the left wrist. Sensation to light touch is decreased over the left thumb and index finger. The remainder of the examination, including
neurologic examination, shows no abnormal ities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: C6 radiculopathy is the most likely diagnosis. The C6 dermatome is located on the lateral aspect of the forearm and extends to the lateral two digits of the hand. Injury to the C6 nerve roots will cause decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in these distributions along with motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension. The C6 nerve root carries efferent information for the biceps reflex. Dermatomes and myotomes are components of the embryonic somite, a paired segment of paraxial mesoderm. When fully developed, the dermatome is an area of skin whose afferent fibers travel within a single spinal nerve, and myotome is a group of muscles innervated by efferent fibers from a single spinal nerve. Radiculopathy refers to pathology of a spinal nerve root and may be caused by spondylosis (degenerative changes of the spine), disc herniation, infection, tumor, demyelination, or infarction. Disc herniation and spondylosis are the most common causes and lead to compression of the nerve root as it exits the spinal cord. Sensory deficits, motor dysfunction, and pain typically occur in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected nerve root.

distractor_explanations.A: radiculopathy would lead to sensory and motor dysfunction in the neck and shoulders around the acromioclavicu lar joint. Sensory and motor dysfunction in the distal upper extremity and an absent biceps reflex are more consistent with C6 radiculopathy. C5 radiculopathy (Choice B) would lead to sensory and motor dysfunction in the lateral aspect of the shoulder and upper arm. C5 radiculopathy typically results in an absent biceps reflex, as the C5 nerve root carries afferent information for this reflex. However, C5 radiculopathy would not cause decreased sensation in the digits Exam Section : Item 14 of 50 Clinical C6 radiculopathy is the most likely diagnosis. The C6 dermatome is located on the lateral aspect of the forearm and extends to the lateral two digits of the hand. Injury to the C6 nerve roots will cause decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in these distributions along with motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension. The C6 nerve root carries efferent information for the biceps reflex. Dermatomes and myotomes are components of the embryonic somite, a paired segment of paraxial mesoderm. When fully developed, the dermatome is an area of skin whose afferent fibers travel within a single spinal nerve, and myotome is a group of muscles innervated by efferent fibers from a single spinal nerve. Radiculopathy refers to pathology of a spinal nerve root and may be caused by spondylosis (degenerative changes of the spine), disc herniation, infection, tumor, demyelination, or infarction. Disc herniation and spondylosis are the most common causes and lead to compression of the nerve root as it exits the spinal cord. Sensory deficits, motor dysfunction, and pain typically occur in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected nerve root. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, E, F, and G. C4 radiculopathy (Choice A) would lead to sensory and motor dysfunction in the neck and shoulders around the acromioclavicular joint. Sensory and motor dysfunction in the distal upper extremity and an absent biceps reflex are more consistent with C6 radiculopathy. C5 radiculopathy (Choice B) would lead to sensory and motor dysfunction in the lateral aspect of the shoulder and upper arm. C5 radiculopathy typically results in an absent biceps reflex, as the C5 nerve root carries afferent information for this reflex. However, C5 radiculopathy would not cause decreased sensation in the digits. C7 radiculopathy (Choice D) would lead to sensory and motor dysfunction of the posterior arm and forearm along with the medial three fingers. The biceps reflex would not be affected. C8 radiculopathy (Choice E) would lead to sensory and motor dysfunction of the medial third of the hand, including the medial aspect of the fifth digit. The biceps reflex would not be affected. Carpal tunnel syndrome (Choice F), resulting from compression of the median nerve, would initially lead to pain and paresthesia in the first three digits and may progress to hand weakness. The biceps reflex would be unaffected, and sensory and motor symptoms of the forearm and arm would be atypical. Cubital tunnel syndrome (Choice G), resulting from compression of the ulnar nerve as it crosses the elbow, features sensory deficits, motor dysfunction, and pain of the medial two digits along with dysfunction of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. The biceps reflex would be unaffected, and sensory and motor symptoms of the forearm and arm would be atypical.

explanation.educational_objective: Radiculopathy refers to nerve root pathology that leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesia, and pain in a dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected root. C6 radiculopathy will cause decreased sensation, pain, or paresthesia in the lateral forearm and lateral two digits. Additionally, C6 radiculopathy causes motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension, with an absent biceps reflex Clinical

vignette.presentation:
15. A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of a ?-day history of increasingly severe pain around the waist. He says that it feels like a
burning belt from the left midback to the umbilicus. He has a history of chronic low back pain. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with
glyburide and asthma treated with beclomethasone and albuterol inhalers. He completed a 10-day course of corticosteroids for asthma 3 weeks
ago. Examination shows numbness in the left T12 distribution. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is
the most likely explanation for these findings?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's history of diabetes and presenting signs and symptoms of burning pain in a dermatomal distribution are, in the absence of other findings, consistent with a diagnosis of diabetic radiculopathy. Formation of advanced glycation end products in chronic diabetics leads to microvascular ischemic damage to various tissues, including to the vasa nervorum. This mechanism underlies the pathogenesis of both diabetic polyneuropathy, as well as diabetic radiculopathy. Diabetic thoracic radiculopathy presents with unilatera l burning and electric-like pain extending from the back to the anterior abdomina l midline in a dermatomal distribution that may involve one or several spinal levels. Patients often experience numbness and muscular weakness of the affected nerve distribution. Most patients experience improvement in their symptoms over several months with conservative treatment.

distractor_explanations.A: Ankylosing spondylitis is an autoimmune disorder affecting the axial joints, especially the intervertebral and sacroiliac joints. Patients present with slowly progressive, dull, lower back pain and stiffness that characteristically improves with activity. Patients usually present in the third decade of life and rarely experience burning pain. Atherosclerotic vascular disease (Choice B) may cause claudication, which presents with pain of the lower extremity that occurs in the setting of exercise and resolves with rest. Patients may experience coolness, pallor, hair loss, and poor wound healing of the affected limb Clinical This patient's history of diabetes and presenting signs and symptoms of burning pain in a dermatomal distribution are, in the absence of other findings, consistent with a diagnosis of diabetic radiculopathy. Formation of advanced glycation end products in chronic diabetics leads to microvascular ischemic damage to various tissues, including to the vasa nervorum. This mechanism underlies the pathogenesis of both diabetic polyneuropathy, as well as diabetic radiculopathy. Diabetic thoracic radiculopathy presents with unilateral burning and electric-like pain extending from the back to the anterior abdominal midline in a dermatomal distribution that may involve one or several spinal levels. Patients often experience numbness and muscular weakness of the affected nerve distribution. Most patients experience improvement in their symptoms over several months with conservative treatment. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, E, F, and G. Ankylosing spondylitis (Choice A) is an autoimmune disorder affecting the axial joints, especially the intervertebral and sacroiliac joints. Patients present with slowly progressive, dull, lower back pain and stiffness that characteristically improves with activity. Patients usually present in the third decade of life and rarely experience burning pain. Atherosclerotic vascular disease (Choice B) may cause claudication, which presents with pain of the lower extremity that occurs in the setting of exercise and resolves with rest. Patients may experience coolness, pallor, hair loss, and poor wound healing of the affected limb. Epidural abscess (Choice D) is a localized collection of pus in the epidural space, typically occurring in the setting of hematogenous bacterial or fungal infection and immunocompromise. Patients may present with fever, back pain, altered mental status, meningismus, and focal neurologic deficits. Low back strain (Choice E) may result from heavy lifting and presents with dull, aching, bilateral lower back pain and with shooting pain toward a lower extremity. It does not typically present with radicular, belt-like pain. Lumbar radiculopathy (Choice F), also known as sciatica, results from compression of a lumbar radicular nerve and commonly results from degenerative spondyloarthropathies and arthritis. Patients typically present with burning or shooting pain that radiates down the back of the leg as well as numbness, weakness, and paresthesia of the foot. This patient's complaint of burning belt-like pain is more consistent with thoracic radiculopathy secondary to diabetes. Lumbar stenosis (Choice G) causes compression of the spinal cord and presents with pain and weakness of the back and lower extremities that is characteristically aggravated by extension of the hip and spine and alleviated by flexion of the hip and spine. Patients may experience radiculopathy, impotence, and incontinence.

explanation.educational_objective: Diabetic microvascular damage to nerves may result in polyneuropathy or radiculopathy. Diabetic thoracic radiculopathy presents with unilateral burning and electric-like pain extending from the back to the anterior abdominal midline in a dermatomal distribution involving one or several spinal levels Exam Section : Item 16 of 50 Clinical

vignette.presentation:
16. A 12-year-old girl with systemic lupus erythematosus is brought to the emergency department by her parents after they had difficulty awakening
her this morning. She has needed constant stimulation to stay awake. Over the past 2 days, she has had a flu-like illness and vomiting. She has
been unable to take her corticosteroid and antihypertensive medications. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are
40/min, and blood pressure is 180/130 mm Hg. She is obtunded but moves all extremities to painful stimuli. Funduscopic examination shows
bilateral papilledema with flame hemorrhages. Deep tendon reflexes are brisk and symmetric. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 12 mm/h.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Hypertensive encephalopathy is a known complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and results from acute and severe increases in blood pressure. It may manifest with headache, vomiting, agitation, altered mental status, and seizure, and can progress to obtundation and coma. Visual symptoms may result from cortical hypertension or from hypertensive retinopathy, manifesting as papilledema and flame hemorrhages on fundoscopic examination. Treatment includes carefully lowering the blood pressure while avoiding excessively rapid drops, which can cause cerebral or cardiac ischemia. In general, a decrease in the mean arterial pressure of 25% within the first hour is appropriate, with gradual correction over the next day or more. Sodium nitroprusside is a potent vasodilator and is a preferred agent because of its short half-life, allowing it to be titrated via intravenous infusion.

distractor_explanations.A: Brain neoplasm can cause altered mental status in a subacute or chronic time course. It would be less likely in this patient who is presenting with acute hypertensive encephalopathy. Cerebral vasculitis (Choice B) as a manifestation of SLE is rare. Cerebral vasculitis can present with neurologic deficits, headache, seizures, or coma. Hypertensive encephalopathy is more likely in this patient. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (Choice D) presents commonly in younger, overweight females taking vitamin A, oral contraceptives, or danazol. It is usually associated with a holocephalic headache and blurry vision Exam Section : Item 16 of 50 Clinical Please Walt F) Reye syndrome Correct Answer: C. Hypertensive encephalopathy is a known complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and results from acute and severe increases in blood pressure. It may manifest with headache, vomiting, agitation, altered mental status, and seizure, and can progress to obtundation and coma. Visual symptoms may result from cortical hypertension or from hypertensive retinopathy, manifesting as papilledema and flame hemorrhages on fundoscopic examination. Treatment includes carefully lowering the blood pressure while avoiding excessively rapid drops, which can cause cerebral or cardiac ischemia. In general, a decrease in the mean arterial pressure of 25% within the first hour is appropriate, with gradual correction over the next day or more. Sodium nitroprusside is a potent vasodilator and is a preferred agent because of its short half-life, allowing it to be titrated via intravenous infusion. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, E, and F. Brain neoplasm (Choice A) can cause altered mental status in a subacute or chronic time course. It would be less likely in this patient who is presenting with acute hypertensive encephalopathy. Cerebral vasculitis (Choice B) as a manifestation of SLE is rare. Cerebral vasculitis can present with neurologic deficits, headache, seizures, or coma. Hypertensive encephalopathy is more likely in this patient. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (Choice D) presents commonly in younger, overweight females taking vitamin A, oral contraceptives, or danazol. It is usually associated with a holocephalic headache and blurry vision. lntracerebral hematoma (Choice E) can be idiopathic or secondary to trauma, aneurysms, arteriovenous malformations, tumors, or hypertension. In a young patient with SLE who has missed doses of corticosteroids and antihypertensive medications, hypertensive encephalopathy is more likely. Reye syndrome (Choice F) classically presents in children and is rare in adults; it may be idiopathic but is associated with salicylate use during a preceding viral infection. Reye syndrome presents in stages one through five with early stages demonstrating nonspecific rash, lethargy, confusion, nausea and vomiting, eventually leading to stupor. In later stages, coma, cerebral edema, seizures, organ failure, hyperammonemia, and death can result. Physical examination typically shows depressed mental status or loss of consciousness depending on the stage, as well as hepatomega ly in later stages.

vignette.presentation:
17. A previously healthy 4-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of a 3-day history of increased drowsiness.
During this period, she also has been feeding poorly and "spitting up" after each feeding. She has not had fever. She was born at term following an
uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. On arrival, she is responsive to tactile stimuli. She is at the 25th percentile for length and weight and
90th percentile for head circumference. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 100/70
mm Hg. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanel. There is a hyperpigmented macule with hair growth on the upper lumbar spine; her
parents report that this finding was noted at birth. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Chiari malformations are rare congenital malformations that typically present in infancy with feeding and breathing problems, spina bifida (classically manifesting as myelomeningocele), and obstructive hydrocephalus (presenting as large head circumference and bulging anterior fontanel in this patient) as a result of the downward displacement of the cerebellar vermis and tonsils. This patient's hyperpigmented macule with hair growth on the upper lumbar spine likely represents spina bifida occulta (a small defect in the vertebrae). Some patients also demonstrate eye movement abnormalities. Some Chiari malformations present in adolescence with bilateral cranial nerve palsies, weakness, and cerebellar dysfunction as a result of the downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils and consequent brainstem compression. Imaging typically demonstrates downward displacement of the cerebellar vermis and tonsils, along with ventriculomegaly from hydrocephalus. Treatment involves surgical intervention for neural tube defects, shunting for hydrocephalus, and medical management of feeding and respiratory difficulties.

distractor_explanations.A: Bacterial meningitis typically presents with fever and signs of meningeal irritation (nausea, irritability, confusion, anorexia, headache, and nuchal rigidity). Spina bifida occulta is not associated with acute bacterial meningitis. Hydrocephalus may result from bacterial meningitis. Idiopathic increased intracranial pressure (Choice C) would present with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (nausea, vomiting, positional headache) without hydrocephalus or other central nervous system pathology. Spina bifida occulta would be atypical. r ~- - - , r - - - - , Exam Section : Item 17 of 50 Clinical Please Walt Correct Answer: B. Chiari malformations are rare congenital malformations that typically present in infancy with feeding and breathing problems, spina bifida (classically manifesting as myelomeningocele), and obstructive hydrocephalus (presenting as large head circumference and bulging anterior fontanel in this patient) as a result of the downward displacement of the cerebellar vermis and tonsils. This patient's hyperpigmented macule with hair growth on the upper lumbar spine likely represents spina bifida occulta (a small defect in the vertebrae). Some patients also demonstrate eye movement abnormalities. Some Chiari malformations present in adolescence with bilateral cranial nerve palsies, weakness, and cerebellar dysfunction as a result of the downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils and consequent brainstem compression. Imaging typically demonstrates downward displacement of the cerebellar vermis and tonsils, along with ventriculomegaly from hydrocephalus. Treatment involves surgical intervention for neural tube defects, shunting for hydrocephalus, and medical management of feeding and respiratory difficulties. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, and E. Bacterial meningitis (Choice A) typically presents with fever and signs of meningeal irritation (nausea, irritability, confusion, anorexia, headache, and nuchal rigidity). Spina bifida occulta is not associated with acute bacterial meningitis. Hydrocephalus may result from bacterial meningitis. Idiopathic increased intracranial pressure (Choice C) would present with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (nausea, vomiting, positional headache) without hydrocephalus or other central nervous system pathology. Spina bifida occulta would be atypical. lntracranial schwannoma (Choice D) would be rare in infants and may manifest as a cerebellopontine angle mass, presenting with cranial nerve dysfunction. Spina bifida occulta is not associated with intracranial schwannoma. Tuberous sclerosis (Choice E) is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder characterized by benign tumors in several organ systems. Hamartomas can form in the skin (leading to shagreen patches and hypomelanotic macules known as "ash-leaf spots") or brain (leading to epilepsy and intellectual disability), along with cardiac rhabdomyomas (leading to mitral regurgitation), and renal angiomyolipomas. This patient instead has a lumbar patch of hair that likely represents spina bifida occulta.

Spina bifida occulta may present as a hyperpigmented macule with hair growth in the lumbar region. Imaging demonstrates downward displacement of the cerebellar vermis and tonsils, along with ventriculomegaly from hydrocephalus. ., Exam Section : Item 18 of 50 Clinical

vignette.presentation:
18. A 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of headaches accompanied by nausea and vomiting over the past 2 weeks; they are located
behind the left eye and improve after sleep. The headaches started during final examinations, and she now is missing 2 to 3 days of school weekly
because of the pain. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Examination
shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Migraine is a common condition that presents with recurrent primary headaches. Migraine headaches are typically severe, unilateral, throbbing, and associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia. The pain is usually located behind or adjacent to the eye. Some patients additionally experience an aura before or during the headache, which may present with vision loss followed by the perception of scintillating shapes or lines or paresthesia. Migraine triggers include stress, menstruation, weather changes, fasting, and alcoholic beverages. Sleep may improve migraines. Migraines are postulated to arise from deficient serotonin inhibition of descending pain pathways. Acute migraine treatment includes triptans and/or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). For patients with disabling or frequent migraines, prophylactic treatment is also recommended and includes ~-adrenergic blockers, antidepressants such as tricyclic antidepressants and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, and anticonvulsants.

distractor_explanations.A: Brain tumor may cause generalized headaches associated with vomiting that typically occur while patients are lying supine as a result of increased intracranial pressure and may be accompanied by papilledema and blurred vision. This patient's headache improved in the supine position. Cluster headaches (Choice B) are primary headaches that typically present with short-lived, unilateral, severe pain in the orbital, supraorbital, or temporal region of the head and are accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (eg, miosis, ptosis, lacrimation, nasal congestion). This patient did not demonstrate autonomic symptoms.
distractor_explanations.D: Sinusitis may be associated with bilateral, pressure-like, periorbital headaches and nasal congestion. Headaches are not typically associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia. This patient's unilateral headaches that started during a stressful period are more consistent with migraine. Tension-type headaches (Choice E) typically manifest as mild- to moderate-intensity, bilateral, dull headaches without other symptoms, often arising from stress. This patient experienced severe, unilateral headaches with associated nausea and vomiting.

explanation.educational_objective: Migraines are typically unilateral, pulsating headaches that are associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia, and may also present with visual or sensory aura. Stress is a common migraine trigger, and sleep may improve headaches. ., Exam Section : Item 19 of 50 Clinical

vignette.presentation:
19. Over the past year, a 72-year-old man has had progressive aching in his lower extremities when he walks in the shopping mall. Initially, the pain
began after 15 minutes of walking and resolved after he stopped; now, it starts after 5 or 10 minutes of walking, and it occasionally occurs when he
stands up after sleeping all night. The pain radiates from his buttocks to his feet. He describes it as a "terrible" pain. He has mild chronic
obstructive pulmonary disease but continues to smoke one pack of cigarettes daily. He has cervical arthritis and often has neck and arm pain.
Examination shows decreased breath sounds bilaterally. Strength and sensation are normal in the extremities. Babinski's sign is absent bilaterally.
Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in both knees and ankles and 2+ in the upper extremities. Dorsalis pedis pulses are normal. Which of the following is
the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Alcoholic rhabdomyolysis J) Hypokalemic periodic paralysis
Amyotrophic lateral scleros is K) Hypothyroid myopathy
Becker muscular dystrophy L) Lumbar spinal stenosis
Epidural metastatic carcinoma P) Sensorimotor periphera l neuropathy
Epstein-Barr virus infection Q) Spinal cord compression

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Mucosa! neuromas, growths on the oral mucosa and lips, are a finding of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 2B. Other features of MEN2B include medullary thyroid carcinoma, and pheochromocytoma. MEN2B is also associated with neurofibromatosis type I, and these disorders can present simultaneous ly. Neurofibromatosis type I (von Recklinghausen disease) is a genetically inherited disorder caused by a defect in NF1, the gene which encodes neurofibromin on chromosome 17. It follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. It is characterized by a constellation of cutaneous manifestations (neurofibromas, plexiform neurofibromas, cafe au lait macules, and axillary freckling), a variety of central nervous system tumors including optic nerve glioma and iris hamartoma (Lisch nodule), and bony abnormalities such as long bone dysplasia and sphenoid wing dysplasia. Patients are also at higher risk for developing astrocytomas, brainstem gliomas, and soft tissue sarcomas. Neurofibromatosis type II has a different constellation of findings: bilateral acoustic schwannomas, cataracts, meningiomas, and ependymomas, and is not associated with MEN.

distractor_explanations.E: are among them. Ependymoma (
distractor_explanations.B: is a central nervous system neoplasm formed from ependymal cells which typically arises in the fourth ventricle. Ependymoma is a feature of neurofibromatosis type II. Lymphoma (
distractor_explanations.C: is a hematologic malignancy derived from lymphocytes which has many different subtypes and presentations. CNS lymphoma is a type of intracranial neoplasm, but it is not seen in neurofibromatosis type I or MEN2B.

vignette.presentation:
20. A 25-year-o ld man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of increasing low back pain that is most severe on awakening in the
morning. His pain is relieved by stretching. There is no history of trauma. He is otherwise healthy except for occasional dysuria. Examination
shows decreased forward flexion of the spine and tenderness over the lumbosac ral area and at the insertion site of the Achilles tendon. Which of
the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Abdomina l aortic aneurysm G) Metastatic cancer
Herniated disc at L4-L5 I) Pyelonephritis
lnterverteb ral discitis J) Rheumatoid arthritis
Lumbar spinal stenosis L) Systemic lupus erythematosus

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Ankylosing spondyl itis (AS) refers to an inflammatory arthritis of the spine and other joints (eg, the sacroiliac joints) along with extra-articu lar inflammation. Patients typically present at younger than age 40 years with insidious chronic low back pain that worsens at night and improves with activity (caused by the mobilization of inflammatory material from joints). This pattern of pain is known as inflammatory back pain. Sacroiliac arthritis and enthesitis (inflammation of the attachments of tendons and ligaments to bone) are other common joint manifestations. Extra-articular manifestations commonly include anterior uveitis, psoriasis, and inflammatory bowel disease. AS is associated with reactive arthritis, which classical ly presents with post-infectious conjunctivitis, arthritis, and urethritis. Over time, patients with AS can develop decreased spine mobility, hyperkyphosis, osteopenia, and an increased risk for vertebra l fragility fractures. Laboratory studies demonstrate increased acute phase reactant concentrations (eg, erythrocyte sedimentation rate) along with a positive HLA-B27 test in many patients. Plain x-rays may illustrate fused vertebrae and sacroiliac joints. Treatment typically begins with nonsteroida l anti-inf lammatory drugs and escalates to disease-modifying immunomodulating medication in refractory cases.
explanation.educational_objective: Ankylosing spondylitis is an inflammatory condition of the spine and sacroiliac joints, leading to insidious back pain in patients typically younger than age 40 years. The pain is worse at night and improves with activity. Extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis are common. Vertebral fusion and decreased spine mobility commonly result Exam Section : Item 21 of 50 Clinical
