vignette.presentation:
34. A 42-year-old woman with AIDS comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of progressive right-sided weakness, slurred speech, and
headache. She is right-handed. Funduscopic examination shows papilledema. Neurologic examination shows aphasia, right homonymous
hemianopia, and right-sided spastic weakness. A CT scan of the head with contrast shows multiple small ring-enhancing lesions with surrounding
edema and mass effect in the left frontal, right occipital, and left parietal lobes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Toxop/asma gondii is an intracellular protozoan parasite. Transmission can occur through the ingestion of oocysts from cat feces or infected meat, direct transmission between a mother and fetus, or from organ transplantation, which leads to invasion followed by dissemination of the parasite where it typically lies dormant. It is a ubiquitous organism and nearly 10% of individuals will be seropositive for T gondii, but the parasite does not usually cause severe disease in immunocompetent individuals. In patients with HIV infection and CD4+ T-lymphocyte counts less than 100 cells/mm 3, however, reactivation can occur with several distinct clinical syndromes of which cerebral toxoplasmosis results in the most morbidity. Cerebral toxoplasmosis typically presents with multiple ring enhancing lesions scattered throughout the brain. Seizures, focal neurologic deficits, and systemic symptoms are common, as are signs of increased intracranial pressure. Patients with HIV infection and positive Toxop/asma lgG antibodies are typically treated empirically with a sulfonamide and pyrimethamine if cerebral toxoplasmosis is suspected, but confirmatory diagnosis occurs through a brain biopsy, which will show a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells, along with the presence of the T gondii organism. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an AIDS-defining disease.

distractor_explanations.A: Cryptococcosis is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, an encapsulated fungus and opportunistic pathogen in immunocompromised patients. It can cause cryptococca l meningitis, encephalitis, and pulmonary cryptococcosis. Meningoencephalitis presents subacutely with fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity, often accompanied by cough and shortness of breath caused by concurrent pulmonary infection. Focal neurologic deficits and mass lesions on neuroimaging are rare.
distractor_explanations.B: Cysticercosis is caused by Taenia so/ium and presents with headache, seizures, and increased intracranial pressure. Neuroimaging will show cystic, ring-enhancing, calcified lesions in the brain parenchyma, meninges, ventricles, spinal cord, and/or orbit. It less commonly presents with focal neurologic deficits such as those seen in this patient. Primary central nervous system lymphoma (Choice C) is a rare form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs in immunocomp romised patients and presents with focal neurologic deficits, vision changes, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and increased intracranial pressure. It appears similar to toxoplasmosis on neuroimaging but is much less common than toxoplasmos is. If this patient failed to improve with pyrimethamine and sulfonamide therapy, central nervous system lymphoma would be the likely diagnosis. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (Choice D) is a demyelinating disease of the central nervous system caused by human polyomavirus 2 (formerly JC virus), most commonly in immunocompromised patients. It presents subacutely with altered mental status, ataxia, vision changes, and hemiparesis. Lesions occur primarily in the white matter and are not enhanced with contrast; rather, they appear as hypodense lesions.

explanation.educational_objective: Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxop/asma gondii, an intracellular protozoan parasite that is most commonly transmitted via the ingestion of cat feces or infected meat. In immunocompromised patients, particularly AIDS patients with CD4+ T lymphocyte counts less than 100 cells/mm 3, it can cause cerebral toxoplasmos is, which presents with seizures, focal neurologic deficits, systemic symptoms, and increased intracranial pressure. Neuroimaging will show multiple ring-enhancing lesions, and treatment is with pyrimethamine and sulfonamide therapy Clinical
explanation.concept: Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxop/asma gondii, an intracellular protozoan parasite that is most commonly transmitted via the ingestion of cat feces or infected meat. In immunocompromised patients, part

vignette.presentation:
35. A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of progressive numbness and weakness of his legs. Six
years ago, he had non-Hodgkin lymphoma treated successful ly with chemotherapy and radiation therapy. He is currently taking no medications.
Cranial nerve examination shows no abnormalities. Muscle strength is intact in the upper extremities but 3/5 in the proximal lower extremities and
4/5 in the distal lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ in the upper extremities and 3+ in the lower extremities. Babinski sign is present
bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick is decreased below the level of the nipples, and sensation to vibration is decreased over the feet and ankles.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Metastatic spinal cord compression occurs most commonly in prostate, lung, or breast cancer, although it can occur with any malignancy. It is generally caused by vertebral bony metastases that tend to occur in the vertebral body, particularly of the thoracic spine. Its presentation depends on the level of the lesion and the degree of spinal cord compression. Symptoms include back pain, which is often worse at night or with lying down, muscle weakness, sensory abnormalities, bladder or bowel dysfunction, and gait instability. It will generally present with an upper motoneuron pattern of injury in the lower extremities with hyperreflexia and positive Babinski signs, as in this patient, assuming the compression is in the thoracic or upper lumbar region. Ascending numbness or paresthesias are also common. Diagnosis is classically made utilizing MRI of the spine. Patients may be treated with glucocorticoids, radiation therapy, and/or surgical decompression and spine stabilization.

distractor_explanations.A: induced polyneuropathy classically presents with sensory loss and paresthesias in the distal extremities that ascend in a "stocking and glove" pattern. Most chemotherapy-induced polyneuropathy will improve over time after chemotherapy is stopped, making this a less likely explanation for this patient's acute onset of symptoms. Guillain-Barre syndrome (Choice B) is caused by autoimmune-mediated nerve destruction following a systemic infection, such as Campy/obacter jejuni. It classically presents with ascending paralysis with absent deep tendon reflexes that begins in the lower extremities. It can also ascend to involve the upper extremities, diaphragm, and cranial nerves in some patients.
distractor_explanations.D: Myopathy is caused by a disorder affecting the muscle itself, rather than the nerves that innervate it. Generally, it presents with symmetric proximal muscle weakness in response to genetic metabolic abnormalities, toxins (eg, alcohol or medications), endocrine dysfunction (eg, hypothyroidism), or inflammation. It does not present with sensory changes. Paraneoplastic neuropathy (Choice E) is an immune-mediated destruction of neuronal tissue in the presence of an underlying malignancy. It can present in a variety of ways, such as an acute sensorimotor radiculopathy, chronic sensorimotor neuropathy, or autonomic neuropathy. This patient's symptoms would be most similar to an acute sensorimotor radiculopathy, but this syndrome presents with a predominant ascending motor paralysis.

explanation.educational_objective: Metastatic spinal cord compression presents in malignancy with back pain worse at night, muscle weakness, sensory abnormalities, bladder or bowel dysfunction, and gait instability. Physical examination may disclose hyperreflexia, Babinski sign, and changes in perception of pinprick or vibratory sensation. Treatment includes glucocorticoids, radiation therapy, and/or surgical decompression and spine stabilization. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Metastatic spinal cord compression presents in malignancy with back pain worse at night, muscle weakness, sensory abnormalities, bladder or bowel dysfunction, and gait instability. Physical examinatio

vignette.presentation:
36. A previously healthy 62-year-o ld man has had progressive difficulty with speech and swallowing over the past year. Symptoms were subtle at first,
and only he and his family noticed a problem. Recently, two ham radio colleagues have commented that he sounds different on the air. He has
also noticed that he has difficulty manipulating objects in the left hand, walking smoothly, and going up and down stairs. He has not had any
difficulty with his thought processes. Examination shows slow deliberate speech with mild dysarthria. Cranial nerves are otherwise normal. There
is wasting of intrinsic hand muscles and distal weakness in the left hand. Gait is slightly broad-based, but Romberg sign is absent. Deep tendon
reflexes are 3+ in the left upper extremity, 2+ in the right upper extremity, and 3+ in the lower extremities. Jaw jerk is hyperactive . His serum
potassium concentrat ion is 3.2 mEq/L. An x-ray of the chest shows normal findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Alcoholic rhabdomyolysis J) Hypokalemic periodic paralysis
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis K) Hypothyroid myopathy
Becker muscular dystrophy L) Lumbar spinal stenos is
Epidural metastatic carcinoma P) Sensorimotor periphera l neuropathy
Epstein-Barr virus infection Q) Spinal cord compression

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is likely given insidious onset of upper and lower motoneuron deficits. ALS is caused by the progressive destruction of motoneurons. Patients may develop asymmetric weakness of the extremities. Unilateral hand weakness, foot drop, and bulbar symptoms (eg, dysphagia, voice changes) may occur simultaneous ly. On physical examination, the presence of both upper motoneuron signs such as hyperreflexia and spasticity, combined with lower motoneuron signs such as hyporeflexia suggests the diagnosis. Parkinsonian features such as masked facies, tremor, and shuffling gait may occur, as can autonomic dysfunction. Eventually, patients develop respiratory insufficiency. The clinical progression is relentless and results in death.
explanation.concept: TBD

vignette.presentation:
37. A 27-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 4-week history of difficulty with speech and weakness of his right leg. He has a 5-year
history of HIV infection treated with antiretroviral therapy. On admission, his temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). Examination shows thrush. There is mild
nonfluent aphasia. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the right lower extremity. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in the right lower extremity and 2+ elsewhere.
Babinski sign is present on the right. An MRI of the brain shows six ring-enhancing lesions in the cerebral hemispheres bilaterally; the largest
lesion is in the left frontal lobe. Some of the lesions have surrounding edema. Pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine therapy is started. Two weeks later,
there is no improvement in his symptoms. A second MRI of the brain shows no decrease in the size of the lesions, and some have increased in
size. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma is a rare variant of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs most commonly in immunocompromised patients. It can occur in the brain, spinal cord, leptomeninges, or eyes. Presenting symptoms include focal neurologic deficits, vision changes, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, headache, nausea, emesis). In immunocompetent patients, neuroimaging will most commonly show a solitary, hypodense periventricular mass with well defined borders and mild surrounding edema. In immunocompromised patients, however, the development of primary CNS lymphoma is strongly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, with additional risk factors in HIV including a decreased CD4+ T lymphocyte count, increased viral load, and chronic co-infection with hepatitis B or C virus. Imaging in immunocompromised patients more commonly shows multifocal disease, numerous, ring- or heterogeneously enhancing lesions throughout the corpus callosum, periventricular areas, and periependyma l regions. The diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow cytometry or cytology, with evidence of EBV DNA in the CSF supporting the diagnosis. Treatment typically consists of high-dose and generally intrathecal chemotherapeutics and antiretroviral therapy.

distractor_explanations.A: abscesses of the brain can occur in immunocompromised patients. These are typically microabscesses that can lead to the development of encephalopathy with altered mental status and are seen on MRI as small, ring-enhancing lesions often with a hemorrhagic component. However, these patients commonly present with fever, nuchal rigidity, and headache, which this patient does not demonstrate Exam Section : Item 37 of 50 Clinical Central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma is a rare variant of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs most commonly in immunocompromised patients. It can occur in the brain, spinal cord, leptomeninges, or eyes. Presenting symptoms include focal neurologic deficits, vision changes, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, headache, nausea, emesis). In immunocompetent patients, neuroimaging will most commonly show a solitary, hypodense periventricular mass with well defined borders and mild surrounding edema. In immunocompromised patients, however, the development of primary CNS lymphoma is strongly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, with additional risk factors in HIV including a decreased CD4+ T lymphocyte count, increased viral load, and chronic co-infection with hepatitis B or C virus. Imaging in immunocompromised patients more commonly shows multifocal disease, numerous, ring- or heterogeneously enhancing lesions throughout the corpus callosum, periventricular areas, and periependyma l regions. The diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow cytometry or cytology, with evidence of EBV DNA in the CSF supporting the diagnosis. Treatment typically consists of high-dose and generally intrathecal chemotherapeutics and antiretroviral therapy. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, E, and F. Candida! abscesses (Choice A) of the brain can occur in immunocompromised patients. These are typically microabscesses that can lead to the development of encephalopathy with altered mental status and are seen on MRI as small, ring-enhancing lesions often with a hemorrhagic component. However, these patients commonly present with fever, nuchal rigidity, and headache, which this patient does not demonstrate. Cryptococcal meningitis (Choice C) presents subacutely with fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, and photophobia, as well as encephalopathy in severe cases. It is most common in immunocompromised patients. Neuroimaging typically shows no abnormalities, and the diagnosis is made with serum cryptococcal antigen and CSF evaluation. Listeria! meningoencephalitis (Choice D) occurs in patients at the extremes of age (neonates, elderly) and in those that are immunocompromised. It classically presents with fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, altered mental status, cranial nerve palsies, and focal neurologic deficits. While Listeria monocytogenes can cause brain abscesses, this is exceedingly rare. Nocardial abscesses (Choice E) can occur in immunocompromised patients. They classically present with fever, headache, signs of meningeal irritation, and focal neurologic deficits. It more commonly occurs in a concurrent pulmonary infection, which is associated with fever, weight loss, cough, hemoptysis, shortness of breath, and chest pain. Toxoplasma encephalitis (Choice F) commonly presents with headache, fever, and neurologic deficits, as well as altered mental status. Toxoplasma lesions appear as ring-enhancing lesions on brain MRI, similar to CNS lymphoma. However, toxoplasma encephalitis would be expected to improve with sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine.

explanation.educational_objective: CNS lymphoma is a rare form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs in immunocompromised patients with focal neurologic deficits, vision changes, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and increased intracranial pressure. Neuroimaging will show ring enhancing lesions that do not improve with sulfadiazine or pyrimethamine therapy Clinical
explanation.concept: CNS lymphoma is a rare form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs in immunocompromised patients with focal neurologic deficits, vision changes, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and increased intracranial pres

vignette.presentation:
38. A 67-year-old woman comes for a routine health maintenance examination. She is concerned about developing dementia because she lives alone;
she does not want to be a burden to her children. Her father was just diagnosed with dementia, Alzheimer type. She takes no medications other
than hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. Her blood pressure is 124/84 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following
measures is most likely to decrease her risk for multi-infarct (vascular) dementia?

question_stem: most likely to decrease her risk for multi-infarct (vascular) dementia?

choices.text: Daily vitamin D and calcium supplementation
Daily vitamin D and calcium supplementatio n

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Vascular dementia is the second most common form of dementia after Alzheimer type, characterized by stepwise cognitive decline following recurrent cerebral infarctions (strokes). The rate of decline and specific symptoms depend on the regions of the brain affected, and patients typically develop cognitive impairment, motor dysfunction, and behavioral changes as the disease progresses. Risk factors include age, hypertension, obesity, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and prior cerebrovascular accidents. Diagnosis is made clinically with support of neuroimaging demonstrating cerebral ischemic changes. Risk factor reduction is the primary approach to prevention. Continued control of blood pressure is most likely to decrease the risk for this patient developing vascular dementia.

distractor_explanations.D: Daily fish oil supplementation and daily vitamin E supplementation (Choice F) have also been shown to have a mild protective effect. However, control of blood pressure has a stronger association with cardiovascular risk reduction. Daily aspirin prophylaxis (Choice C) is recommended for patients who have existing clinically significant cardiovascular disease (such as history of a myocardial infarction or cerebrovascular event). It is not likely to significantly lower the risk for vascular dementia in this patient. Daily vitamin D and calcium supplementation (Choice E) is recommended for women who are postmenopausal, patients taking chronic systemic corticosteroids, and patients with advanced renal disease to reduce the risk for osteoporosis and fragility fractures. Educational Ob'ective: The risk for develo in vascular dementia can be reduced b the mana ement of modifiable risk factors for Clinical measures is most likely to decrease her risk for multi-infarct (vascular) dementia? A) Continued control of blood pressure B) Regular aerobic exercise C) Daily aspirin prophylaxis D) Daily fish oil supplementation E) Daily vitamin D and calcium supplementatio n F) Daily vitamin E supplementatio n Correct Answer: A. Vascular dementia is the second most common form of dementia after Alzheimer type, characterized by stepwise cognitive decline following recurrent cerebral infarctions (strokes). The rate of decline and specific symptoms depend on the regions of the brain affected, and patients typically develop cognitive impairment, motor dysfunction, and behavioral changes as the disease progresses. Risk factors include age, hypertension, obesity, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and prior cerebrovascular accidents. Diagnosis is made clinically with support of neuroimaging demonstrating cerebral ischemic changes. Risk factor reduction is the primary approach to prevention. Continued control of blood pressure is most likely to decrease the risk for this patient developing vascular dementia. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, E, and F. Efforts to reduce overall cardiovascular risk factors should be encouraged, which includes regular aerobic exercise (Choice B). Daily fish oil supplementation (Choice D) and daily vitamin E supplementation (Choice F) have also been shown to have a mild protective effect. However, control of blood pressure has a stronger association with cardiovascular risk reduction. Daily aspirin prophylaxis (Choice C) is recommended for patients who have existing clinically significant cardiovascula r disease (such as history of a myocardial infarction or cerebrovascular event). It is not likely to significantly lower the risk for vascular dementia in this patient. Daily vitamin D and calcium supplementation (Choice E) is recommended for women who are postmenopausal, patients taking chronic systemic corticosteroids, and patients with advanced renal disease to reduce the risk for osteoporosis and fragility fractures.

explanation.educational_objective: The risk for developing vascular dementia can be reduced by the management of modifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease. vignette.presentation:
39. A previously healthy 45-year-o ld woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after she lost consciousness while shopping in a
department store; on regaining consciousness, she had a severe headache and photophobia. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min,
respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examinat ion shows slight neck stiffness with flexion. There is pain with lateral
deviation of the eyes. Neurologic examination shows no other abnormalities. A CT scan of the head shows no lesions or evidence of bleeding.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharging the patient with analgesic therapy

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) refers to bleeding into the subarachnoid space and can be caused by aneurysmal or non-aneurysma l rupture of an artery in the subarachnoid space. Patients typically present with an acute, severe headache (often described as the worst headache of their life), along with neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma in severe cases. Fever can be associated with SAH and is associated with worse outcomes. CT scan of the head typically shows hyperdense blood products in the cerebral sulci and basal cisterns. However, the sensitivity of CT scan for SAH is lower with small volume bleeding or a delayed presentation. If there is strong suspicion for SAH with a negative CT scan, a lumbar puncture can be performed, which may show red blood cells or xanthochromia, which represents hemoglobin degradation products. As the blood products circulate within the subarachnoid space, complications include the development of communicating and/or obstructive hydrocephalus in the acute stage, along with the potential for re-bleeding and vasospasm in the days following the initial bleed. It is a neurosurgical emergency that may be fatal if progressive or untreated.

Discharging the patient with analgesic therapy (Choice B) would be dangerous in the care of this patient, as further evaluation for subarachnoid hemorrhage is indicated. The patient is at risk for hydrocephalus, vasospasm, rebleeding, or severe hemorrhage after a sentinel bleed. r ~ - - , r - - - , Clinical ' E) Lumbar puncture Correct Answer: E. explanation.educational_objective: Patients with SAH typically present with an acute, severe headache (often described as the worst headache of their life), along with neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma in severe cases. A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 6 hours after the onset of double vision, loss of balance, and dizziness. She has no history of similar symptoms. She sustained a myocardial infarction 2 months ago. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and clonidine. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37.1 °C (98.8°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg in both arms. A left carotid bruit is heard. Pulses are decreased in the lower extremities. Atherosclerotic involvement of which of the following arteries is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? A) Brachiocephalic B) Common carotid C) External carotid D) Internal carotid E) Middle cerebral F) Subclavian G) Vertebral Correct Answer: G. This patient likely has an occlusion of the vertebral artery leading to vertebrobasilar insufficiency. Vertebrobasilar insufficiency can be caused by ischemia in patients with poor sympathetic regulation or thromboembolism commonly originating from an atherosclerotic plaque in or dissection of a vertebral artery (known as a posterior circulation stroke). Risk factors for posterior circulation strokes include smoking, hypertension, age, hyperlipidemia, coronary artery disease, and peripheral artery disease (as evidenced by this patient's diminished lower extremity pulses). The brain stem, cerebellum, and occipital lobes are commonly affected. Patients typically present with vestibulocerebel lar signs (eg, ataxia, dysmetria, dizziness, imbalance, vertigo, vomiting, nystagmus), ipsilateral cranial nerve dysfunction (eg, dysphagia, dysarthria, vertical or horizontal gaze palsies), contralatera l hemiparesis (caused by corticospinal tract damage), contralateral impairment in pain and temperature sensation (caused by spinothalamic tract damage), and/or contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (caused by posterior cerebral artery involvement). Unlike hemispheric strokes arising from the internal carotid arteries, cortical deficits such as cognitive and speech impairment are typically absent. A noncontrast CT scan of the head rules out hemorrhage, and the diagnosis may be confirmed with vessel imaging if the lesion is sufficiently large. If no hemorrhage is seen, acute management of posterior circulation strokes may involve tissue plasminogen activator therapy or thrombectomy. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, E, and F. The brachiocephalic artery (Choice A) supplies the arm, head, and neck. Atherosclerotic disease and consequent occlusion of the brachiocephalic artery may lead to neck and upper extremity pain in addition to signs of vertebrobasilar insufficiency that are exacerbated on exercise Clinical Correct Answer: G. The brachiocephalic artery (Choice A) supplies the arm, head, and neck. Atherosclerotic disease and consequent occlusion of the brachiocephalic artery may lead to neck and upper extremity pain in addition to signs of vertebrobasilar insufficiency that are exacerbated on exercise. Common carotid artery (Choice B) occlusion from atherosclerotic disease less frequently causes symptoms because of retrograde collateral flow through the external carotid artery. If a stroke were to occur, it would affect the ipsilateral anterior and middle cerebral arterial territory, which would not result in signs of vertebrobasilar insufficiency. External carotid artery (Choice C) occlusion from atherosclerotic disease typically does not produce symptoms but may lead to an ocular ischemic syndrome. The internal carotid artery (Choice D) supplies the middle cerebral artery (Choice E), which supplies the lateral frontal and anterolateral parietal lobes. During acute occlusion of the internal carotid artery (typically as a result of a thrombus induced by atherosclerotic disease) or middle cerebral artery (typically related to an embolus from the internal carotid artery), patients may present with hemiparesis and hemisensory deficit (predominantly of the contralateral face and upper body), along with speech impairment. The subclavian artery (Choice F) supplies the upper extremity and gives rise to the vertebral artery. Atherosclerotic disease and occlusion of the subclavian artery usually presents with upper extremity fatigability, claudication, and/or rest pain along with symptoms of vertebrobasilar insufficiency that are exacerbated by exercise. vignette.presentation:
41. A 37-year-old woman with alcoholism is hospitalized for detoxification. On the second day after admission, she has an impaired sensorium and a
decreased attention span during examination. She appears frightened and disoriented and shrieks, "Make the snakes go away." Her temperature
is 38.3°C (101 °F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 190/120 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in
management?

question_stem:
the most appropriate next step in
management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient has developed delirium tremens, a serious complication of alcohol withdrawal. Alcohol increases the central nervous system activity of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), the main inhibitory neurotransmitter. Abrupt discontinuation of alcohol results in imbalanced and unopposed sympathetic excess. Uncomplicated alcohol withdrawal typically presents with tremors, anxiety, restlessness, headache, nausea, and diaphoresis, which can begin within hours after the cessation of alcohol use. Delirium tremens, the most concerning and life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal, involves severe confusion and disorientation, fluctuations in consciousness, agitation, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instability (generally characterized by tachycardia, hypertension, and potentially hyperthermia). As in this patient, delirium tremens can begin 2 to 5 days after the patient's last alcoholic drink. Delirium tremens is managed supportively with benzodiazepines (GABAA receptor agonists) to address the psychomotor agitation associated with withdrawal and prevent the worsening of withdrawal manifestations. The specific benzodiazepines utilized include chlordiazepoxide, a long-acting benzodiazepine given on a scheduled basis in patients experiencing or at risk for complicated withdrawal (eg, delirium tremens), and/or lorazepam, a short-acting benzodiazepine given as-needed for withdrawal symptoms. Management also includes frequent assessments including vital sign checks, fluid resuscitation, and nutritional supplementation (especially with commonly deficient vitamins and minerals such as thiamine, potassium, and magnesium).

distractor_explanations.A: CT scan of the head and oral thioridazine (Choice C), a first-generation antipsychotic, would be unnecessary in this patient whose acute-onset disorientation and hallucinations are consistent with delirium tremens. Psychosis and agitation related to alcohol withdrawal should be treated with benzodiazepines rather than antipsychotics. Intravenous antibiotic therapy (Choice D) would be unnecessary in this patient whose hyperthermia and tachycardia are consistent with delirium tremens rather than infection Exam Section : Item . 4 1 of 50 Clinical .,. . . , E) Intravenous administration of vitamin B (thiamine) 1 Correct Answer: B. Psychosis and agitation related to alcohol withdrawal should be treated with benzodiazepines rather than antipsychotics. Intravenous antibiotic therapy (Choice D) would be unnecessary in this patient whose hyperthermia and tachycardia are consistent with delirium tremens rather than infection. Intravenous administration of vitamin B (thiamine) (Choice E) should be administered during this patient's hospitalization to prevent 1 Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. However, intravenous thiamine does not emergently address alcohol withdrawal symptoms such as this patient's autonomic dysfunction.

vignette.presentation:
42. An otherwise healthy 52-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after the sudden onset of severe low back pain and
severe shooting pain down her left buttock and leg. The pain began when she arose quickly from a seated position to open a sliding glass door.
Two analgesic tablets leftover from a dental procedure provided no relief. She is an avid cyclist. On arrival, intravenous administration of morphine
is begun and provides minimal relief. The patient notes numbness over the perineum when she attempts to void. She is reluctant to move from a
flexed, seated position to a stretcher because of the pain. Muscle strength is 3/5 on great toe extension, dorsiflexion, and plantar flexion of the left
foot. Knee jerk is present on the left. Achilles tendon reflex is absent on the left. An MRI of the lumbosacra l spine shows a large central herniation
at L4-5 that compresses the L5 and S1 nerves on the left. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cauda equina syndrome occurs as a result of compression of the spinal nerve roots comprising the cauda equina. Often, such compression occurs because of malignancy, trauma (eg, compression fractures with fragment retropulsion), disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spinal epidural abscess, or spinal epidural or subdural hematoma. Symptoms include lower extremity numbness, weakness, paralysis, hyporeflexia, perinea! anesthesia, fecal incontinence with poor rectal tone, and overflow incontinence marked by inability to void and urinary retention. Emergent MRI of the lumbosacral spine is indicated to investigate the cause of cauda equina syndrome, and to determine the necessity of surgical decompression. Initial treatment for patients with epidural spinal cord compression and neurologic deficits include symptomatic treatment, pain control, and glucocorticoid therapy prior to operative therapy. High-dose glucocorticoid therapy is helpful as a bridge to definitive therapy, can help control pain, and may transiently improve neurologic function secondary to decreasing edema at the site of cord compression. However, cauda equina syndrome is a surgical emergency and requires decompression with lumbar laminectomy as soon as possible.

distractor_explanations.A: A bone scan is used to examine and diagnose abnormalities in bones, such as bony metastases, fractures, or osteomyelitis. It is not used to evaluate neuromuscular weakness. Physical therapy (Choice B) can be used in the management of other types of back pain, such as lumbosacral strain. However, lumbosacra l strain will not cause perinea! anesthesia or neuromuscular weakness. Cauda equina is a surgical emergency, making physical therapy an incorrect initial next step Clinical • .J• el .t • e e I • •• · • E) Lumbar laminectomy Correct Answer: E. Cauda equina syndrome occurs as a result of compression of the spinal nerve roots comprising the cauda equina. Often, such compression occurs because of malignancy, trauma (eg, compression fractures with fragment retropulsion), disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spinal epidural abscess, or spinal epidural or subdural hematoma. Symptoms include lower extremity numbness, weakness, paralysis, hyporeflexia, perinea! anesthesia, fecal incontinence with poor rectal tone, and overflow incontinence marked by inability to void and urinary retention. Emergent MRI of the lumbosacral spine is indicated to investigate the cause of cauda equina syndrome, and to determine the necessity of surgical decompression. Initial treatment for patients with epidural spinal cord compression and neurologic deficits include symptomatic treatment, pain control, and glucocorticoid therapy prior to operative therapy. High-dose glucocorticoid therapy is helpful as a bridge to definitive therapy, can help control pain, and may transiently improve neurologic function secondary to decreasing edema at the site of cord compression. However, cauda equina syndrome is a surgical emergency and requires decompression with lumbar laminectomy as soon as possible. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D. A bone scan (Choice A) is used to examine and diagnose abnormalities in bones, such as bony metastases, fractures, or osteomyelitis. It is not used to evaluate neuromuscular weakness. Physical therapy (Choice B) can be used in the management of other types of back pain, such as lumbosacral strain. However, lumbosacra l strain will not cause perinea! anesthesia or neuromuscular weakness. Cauda equina is a surgical emergency, making physical therapy an incorrect initial next step. Bed rest and analgesic therapy (Choice C) is no longer recommended for back pain, as it can lead to prolonged pain, as well as worsened muscle and bone strength. It would certainly not be appropriate in cauda equina syndrome, as delayed surgical decompression can lead to permanent neurologic deficits. Intravenous administration of muscle relaxants (Choice D) may provide symptomatic relief in lumbosacral strain or other muscular disorders. Patients with cauda equina may similarly gain some symptomatic relief. However, the more pertinent next step in this patient is lumbar laminectomy to prevent permanent neurologic dysfunction.

Diagnosis is made with MRI and definitive treatment includes emergent surgical decompression with lumbar laminectomy. ., Clinical

ago and is still receiving monthly chiropractic man ipulations. His voice is hoarse . There is left ptosis and nystagmus . The left pupil is 2 mm smaller
than the right. There is decreased sensation to pain over the left side of the face and right extrem ities. He has ataxia on the left. Mental status
examination shows no abnorma lities. Which of the following arteries is most likely to be occluded?

question_stem: most likely to be occluded?

choices.text: Left anterior cerebral I) Right carotid
Left carotid J) Right middle cerebral
Left middle cerebral K) Right ophthalmic
Left ophthalmic L) Right posterior cerebral
Left posterior cerebral M) Right vertebra l

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient likely has an occlusion of the left vertebra l artery leading to vertebrobasilar insufficiency. Vertebrobasi lar insufficiency can be caused by ischemia in patients with poor sympathetic regulation or thromboembolism common ly originating from an atherosclerotic plaque in or dissection of the vertebra l artery (known as a posterior circulation stroke). A thrombus of the vertebral artery commonly forms from atherosclerotic disease but may also form as a result of an intimal defect from trauma or vertebra l artery dissection, a known complication of chiropractic manipu lation. The brain stem, cerebellum, and occipital lobes are common ly affected. Patients typically present with vestibu locerebe llar signs (eg, ataxia, dysmetria, dizziness, imbalance, vertigo, vomiting, nystagmus), ipsilateral cranial nerve dysfunction (eg, dysphagia, dysarthria, vertical or horizonta l gaze palsies), contralateral hemiparesis (caused by corticospinal tract damage), contralateral impairment in pain and temperature sensation (caused by spinothalamic tract damage), and/or contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (caused by posterior cerebral artery involvement). In posterior circulation strokes affecting the lateral pons, Horner syndrome may occur, which presents with unilateral ptosis and miosis (pupillary constriction) and ipsilateral facial anhidrosis. If no hemorrhage is shown on noncontrast CT scan of the head, acute management of posterior circulation strokes may involve tissue plasminogen activator therapy or thrombectomy. In dissection, antiplatelet and anticoagu lant administration is indicated to prevent conversion to a thromboembolic stroke if none has yet occurred.

She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and now weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally.
Visual field testing shows no abnorma lities. Funduscop ic examination shows blurred optic discs; there are no spontaneous venous pulsations. The
remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A CT scan of the head shows small lateral ventricles. On lumbar puncture, the opening
pressure is 290 mm H 0; cerebrospina l fluid (CSF) analysis shows no leukocytes or erythrocytes. Which of the following is the most likely
2

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Impaired resorption of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is the primary mechanism behind pseudotumor cerebri, or idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). IIH is characterized by signs of increased intracranial pressure including headache, papilledema, and increased opening pressure on lumbar puncture without any underlying pathology to cause such findings on neuroimaging. It is primarily seen in young women who are overweight. Although there is no malignant cause underlying the increased intracranial pressure, it may cause debilitating headaches and permanent vision loss. Headaches that are secondary to increased intracranial pressure often are worse when lying down and relieved by standing. The most common risk factors for the development of pseudotumor cerebri include female gender and obesity. However, hypervitaminosis A from increased dietary intake is another potential cause of IIH. This can be from excessive dietary intake or from the use of retinoid medications such as isotretinoin or all-trans retinoic acid. Other medications associated with IIH include tetracyclines, danazol, and growth hormone.

distractor_explanations.A: Aqueductal stenosis causes dilation of the lateral and third ventricles and is a cause of hydrocephalus in children. Idiopathic increased intracranial pressure presents with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (nausea, vomiting, positiona l headache) without hydrocepha lus. Cerebellar astrocytoma (Choice B) is a primary central nervous system tumor seen most often in children and a potential cause of secondary intracranial hypertension and hydrocepha lus if it obstructs the flow of CSF. IIH is characterized by increased intracranial pressure but not hydrocephalus Clinical D) Impaired resorption of CSF E) Lateral venous sinus thrombosis Correct Answer: D. Impaired resorption of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is the primary mechanism behind pseudotumor cerebri, or idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). IIH is characterized by signs of increased intracranial pressure including headache, papilledema, and increased opening pressure on lumbar puncture without any underlying pathology to cause such findings on neuroimaging. It is primarily seen in young women who are overweight. Although there is no malignant cause underlying the increased intracranial pressure, it may cause debilitating headaches and permanent vision loss. Headaches that are secondary to increased intracranial pressure often are worse when lying down and relieved by standing. The most common risk factors for the development of pseudotumor cerebri include female gender and obesity. However, hypervitaminosis A from increased dietary intake is another potential cause of IIH. This can be from excessive dietary intake or from the use of retinoid medications such as isotretinoin or all-trans retinoic acid. Other medications associated with IIH include tetracyclines, danazol, and growth hormone. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and E. Aqueductal stenosis (Choice A) causes dilation of the lateral and third ventricles and is a cause of hydrocephalus in children. Idiopathic increased intracranial pressure presents with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (nausea, vomiting, positional headache) without hydrocepha lus. Cerebellar astrocytoma (Choice B) is a primary central nervous system tumor seen most often in children and a potential cause of secondary intracranial hypertension and hydrocephalus if it obstructs the flow of CSF. IIH is characterized by increased intracranial pressure but not hydrocephalus. Choroid plexus papilloma (Choice C), a hamartoma of the choroid plexus and rare intracranial tumor, is a cause of communicating hydrocephalus by increasing the production of CSF. It most commonly presents in a young child with headache secondary to increased intracranial pressure. Lateral venous sinus thrombosis (Choice E) may be induced by an infection of facial skin, orbit, or nasal sinuses which causes a septic thrombus to form. The most common presenting symptom is acute onset of headache, though orbital pain, edema, visual disturbances, fever, and mental status changes are also seen. This young woman with obesity, chronic headache, and signs of increased intracranial pressure suggests IIH instead.

45. A 6-year-o ld boy is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after a motor vehicle collision in which he was the unrestrained front seat
passenger; he lost consciousness momentarily. Examination shows a 2 x 2-cm area of soft-tissue swelling over the forehead, a small abrasion on
the left cheek, and an abrasion on the right elbow. Neurologic findings are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Mild traumat ic brain injury, also known as a concussion, commonly results in the loss of consciousness, confusion, amnesia, headache, dizziness, nausea, and/or vomiting minutes after the injury. A concussion can be caused by direct or indirect blunt head trauma and typically causes self-limited brief neurologic impairment , such as the loss of consciousness, repetitive questioning, or confusion. Symptoms that commonly develop within the following days include mood disturbances, photophonophobia, trouble concentrating, and/or insomnia. Patients do not have focal neurologic symptoms such as limb weakness or vision changes that would indicate traumatic vascular injury or intracran ial hemorr hage. All patients with suspected concussion should undergo a thorough neurologic examination, and a subset of at-risk patients should receive neuroimaging. All patients should be monitored closely for neurologic deterioration, which may indicate a developing intracran ial hem1atoma. To prevent cumulative brain injury (eg, from a second concussion), patients with concussion should return to their usual activities in a graded fashion, beginning with the return to school and without return to sports until cleared by a physician.

distractor_explanations.B: A cervical spine fracture could present with neck pain, altered mental status, focal neurologic deficits, and decreased neck mobility. Closed head injury (Choice C) refers to blunt head trauma with no object penetrating the skull and dura mater, and encompasses a variety of injuries, such as hematomas, skull fractures, intracrania l hemorrhage, or traumatic brain injury. This patient lost consciousness momentarily and has no other apparent neurologic deficits, making concussion a more specific diagnosis. Epidural hematoma (Choice D) classically occurs after injury to the middle meningeal artery and can present with an initial lucid interval followed b deterioration of mental status as a result of arterial bleedin and hematoma ex ansion. E idural hematomas resent on CT Clinical Correct Answer: A. Mild traumatic brain injury, also known as a concussion, commonly results in the loss of consciousness, confusion, amnesia, headache, dizziness, nausea, and/or vomiting minutes after the injury. A concussion can be caused by direct or indirect blunt head trauma and typically causes self-limited brief neurologic impairment, such as the loss of consciousness, repetitive questioning, or confusion. Symptoms that commonly develop within the following days include mood disturbances, photophonophobia, trouble concentrating, and/or insomnia. Patients do not have focal neurologic symptoms such as limb weakness or vision changes that would indicate traumatic vascular injury or intracranial hemorrhage. All patients with suspected concussion should undergo a thorough neurologic examination, and a subset of at-risk patients should receive neuroimaging. All patients should be monitored closely for neurologic deterioration, which may indicate a developing intracranial hem1atoma. To prevent cumulative brain injury (eg, from a second concussion), patients with concussion should return to their usual activities in a graded fashion, beginning with the return to school and without return to sports until cleared by a physician. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, E, and F. A cervical spine fracture (Choice B) could present with neck pain, altered mental status, focal neurologic deficits, and decreased neck mobility. Closed head injury (Choice C) refers to blunt head trauma with no object penetrating the skull and dura mater, and encompasses a variety of injuries, such as hematomas, skull fractures, intracranial hemorrhage, or traumatic brain injury. This patient lost consciousness momentarily and has no other apparent neurologic deficits, making concussion a more specific diagnosis. Epidural hematoma (Choice D) classically occurs after injury to the middle meningeal artery and can present with an initial lucid interval followed by deterioration of mental status as a result of arterial bleeding and hematoma expansion. Epidural hematomas present on CT scan as lens-shaped, bi-convex hyperdense collections abutting the skull. Facial bone fracture (Choice E) can occur as a result of direct blunt trauma to the face and can be associated with pain and ecchymosis. Patients can present with a variety of signs or symptoms depending on which facial bone is fractured, including facial deformity, midface instability, malocclusion, nerve entrapment, or diplopia. A frontal skull fracture (Choice F) is uncommon as a result of the hardness of the bone, but can occur after severe, high-impact blunt head injury and can be associated with intracranial bleeding. It can present with swelling, tenderness, a palpable skull defect or crepitus, and can be associated with altered mental status.

pulse is 130/min, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 92/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanelle. There are bilateral

the most likely diagnosis?

Depressed skull fracture L) Shaken baby syndrome

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Chronic use of immunosuppressants including glucocorticoids increase the likelihood of tuberculosis reactivation. Tuberculous meningitis typically presents with nuchal rigidity, fever, and altered mental status, similar to the symptoms seen in bacterial meningitis. However, unlike bacterial meningitis which presents acutely, tuberculous meningitis typically shows a subacute presentation. Presence of cranial nerve palsies is also more likely in tuberculous meningitis than bacterial meningitis. Physical examination may show a positive Kernig or Brudzinski sign, indicative of meningeal irritation. Results of laboratory studies will show nonspecific changes including leukocytosis and mild anemia. A tuberculin skin test or interferon-gamma release assay are usually positive, but a negative result is also possible. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) evaluation is the initial diagnostic step and will reveal an increased opening pressure, increased white blood cell count with prominent lymphocytes, increased protein concentration, and decreased glucose concentration. Culture of the CSF for acid-fast bacilli may be positive, though the sensitivity of this test for tuberculous meningitis is less than 50%. Radiologic evaluation may show basilar exudates, as in this case, as well as periventricu lar infarcts and hydrocephalus.

posterior thigh, and calf pain that begins after standing or walking for 10 minutes. It is relieved in 2 minutes by bending forward at the waist or
sitting. She has coronary artery disease and underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 2 years ago. Neurologic examination shows no
abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Doppler flow studies of the lower extremities
Doppler flow studies of the lower extremities

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The patient is presenting with symptoms suggestive of spinal stenosis with neurogenic claudication. Spinal stenosis describes narrowing of the central canal, neural foramen, or lateral recesses of the spine with subsequent nerve compression and ischemia. Common causes include degenerative arthritis, spondyloarthropathies, degenerative disc disease, hypertrophy of the ligamentum flavum, and osteophyte formation in the facet joints. Neurogenic claudication describes low back pain with radiation to the buttocks and lower extremities that results from increased nerve compression, as may occur with extension of the spine during standing and walking downhill. Reducing narrowing within the spinal column with spinal flexion as during sitting or walking uphill tends to relieve the pain. Diagnostic evaluation involves x-ray imaging followed by MRI of the lumbar spine.

distractor_explanations.A: Carotid duplex ultrasonography is recommended to screen for atherosclerotic plaque in patients with a known cardiovascular disease history or significant risk factors. If a stroke or transient ischemic attack were suspected as the cause of the patient's neurologic symptoms, carotid duplex ultrasonography should be performed to evaluate for intervenable lesions. The exacerbating and alleviating factors in this case are more suggestive of spinal stenosis. Doppler flow studies of the lower extremities (Choice B) are useful in distinguishing neurogenic claudication from claudication caused by peripheral vascular disease. Vascular claudication is typically relieved by rest as opposed to postural changes. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies (Choice C) can be used to confirm the presence of radiculopathy caused by nerve root compression or evaluate for other myopathy or neuropathy as the cause of the patient's symptoms. These tests are reasonable if the diagnosis is still in doubt after the initial imaging studies. MRI is the most appropriate next step. r ~ -- , r - - - - , Exam Section : Item 47 of 50 Clinical B) Doppler flow studies of the lower extremities C) Electromyography and nerve conduction studies D) MRI of the lumbar spine E) Myelography Correct Answer: D. Reducing narrowing within the spinal column with spinal flexion as during sitting or walking uphill tends to relieve the pain. Diagnostic evaluation involves x-ray imaging followed by MRI of the lumbar spine. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and E. If a stroke or transient ischemic attack were suspected as the cause of the patient's neurologic symptoms, carotid duplex ultrasonography should be performed to evaluate for intervenable lesions. The exacerbating and alleviating factors in this case are more suggestive of spinal stenosis. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies (Choice C) can be used to confirm the presence of radiculopathy caused by nerve root compression or evaluate for other myopathy or neuropathy as the cause of the patient's symptoms. These tests are reasonable if the diagnosis is still in doubt after the initial imaging studies. MRI is the most appropriate next step. CT myelography (Choice E) is recommended for evaluating the bony structures of the spine in the setting of prior spine surgery, where hardware may cause significant artifact on MRI, or for patients who are unable to obtain an MRI for other reasons.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's examination findings of attention deficit (likely neglect) and left arm drift are suggestive of the presence of a contralateral upper motoneuron lesion, which, in conjunction with her symptoms of new chronic headache, is suggestive of a brain tumor. Hemispatia l neglect often occurs as a result of lesions of the parietal cortex and may also occur in stroke. Similarly, left arm drift may be suggestive of an upper motoneuron lesion in a variety of locations, such as the contralateral frontal cortex, cerebellum, or pyramida l tract. Collectively, this patient's findings localize her lesion to the right parietal cortex.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Radiation-induced brachia! plexopathy is a potential complication of radiation to the brachia! plexus, most commonly occurring after radiation therapy for breast or lung cancer. Radiation damages the brachia! plexus and presents with symptoms of brachia! neuritis, including pain, paresthesia, and weakness in the distribution of the affected nerves that may occur months or years after the initial insult. In this scenario, the radiation has likely affected the C5 and C6 nerve roots (called Erb Palsy), leading to dysfunction of the deltoid, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and biceps brachii muscles, resulting in impaired upper extremity abduction, lateral rotation, flexion, and supination. Consequent ly, the patient's upper extremity hangs near the body in a medially rotated, extended, and pronated position as shown in the photograph. Lymphedema of the upper extremity can also result from radiation-induced fibrosis of the lymph nodes and is often associated with radiation-induced brachia I plexopathy. Neoplastic brachia! plexopathy should be ruled out with MRI. Treatment is supportive and includes brachia! decompression surgery, pain management, and physical and occupationa l therapy Exam Section : Item 49 of 50 Clinical Radiation-induced brachia! plexopathy is a potential complication of radiation to the brachia! plexus, most commonly occurring after radiation therapy for breast or lung cancer. Consequently, the patient's upper extremity hangs near the body in a medially rotated, extended, and pronated position as shown in the photograph. Lymphedema of the upper extremity can also result from radiation-induced fibrosis of the lymph nodes and is often associated with radiation-induced brachia I plexopathy. Neoplastic brachia! plexopathy should be ruled out with MRI. Treatment is supportive and includes brachia! decompression surgery, pain management, and physical and occupationa l therapy.

distractor_explanations.E: Syringomyelia features a cystic cavity in the central cervical and/or thoracic spinal cord, which affects midline structures such as the anterior white commissure (decussation of the spinothalamic tracts) and the anterior horns (cell bodies of lower motoneurons). Patients with syringomyelia may present with deficits in pain and temperature sensation and a lower motoneuron-pattern of dysfunction in the bilateral upper extremities Exam Section : Item 49 of 50 Clinical Radiation damages the brachia! plexus and presents with symptoms of brachia! neuritis, including pain, paresthesia, and weakness in the distribution of the affected nerves that may occur months or years after the initial insult. Consequent ly, the patient's upper extremity hangs near the body in a medially rotated, extended, and pronated position as shown in the photograph. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, and E. Entrapment of a cervical nerve root (Choice A), which commonly results from cervical spinal stenosis (Choice D), leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesia, and pain in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected root. This patient shows sensorimotor dysfunction that crosses dermatome and myotome boundaries, indicating that multiple nerve roots are affected. Reflex sympathetic dystrophy (Choice C), or complex regional pain syndrome, presents with regional pain that is out of the proportion to the insult. Patients may also experience edema or abnorma l sensory or motor findings in the region. This patient instead possesses a pattern of findings (Erb palsy and lymphedema) consistent with radiation-induced brachia! plexopathy, indicating her symptoms are not out of proportion to the insult. Syringomye lia (Choice E) features a cystic cavity in the central cervical and/or thoracic spinal cord, which affects midline structures such as the anterior white commissure (decussation of the spinothalamic tracts) and the anterior horns (cell bodies of lower motoneurons). Patients with syringomye lia may present with deficits in pain and temperature sensation and a lower motoneuron-pattern of dysfunction in the bilateral upper extremities.

are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. He is awake but is unable to speak due to facial and tongue paralysis. He is able to blink his
eyes and move his eyes vertically on command. He cannot move his eyes laterally. Examination shows complete paralysis of all extremities.

shows extensive infarction of the base of the pons due to basilar artery occlusion. Conservative treatment is recommended . Although he cannot

wants no life support or artificial hydration, and wants to die because of his poor prognosis for recovery. His wife and two sons agree with this

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neurologically impaired patients should not be assumed to lack decisional capacity to make decisions about their care. The medical team should evaluate the decisiona l capacity of this patient who is making decisions about his end-of-life care. This patient is able to communicate a consistent decision and demonstrate an appreciation of the consequences of his decision, and therefore, he appears to possess decisiona l capacity to make the decision to withdraw care. The medical team should respect the patient's autonomy and withdraw care. If a patient lacks decisional capacity, the medical team should identify a surrogate decision-maker. Unless the patient has identified a durable power of attorney, the spouse should serve as decision maker (adult children are typically second in line, followed by parents). Further reassuring in this case is that the patient's wife and adult children corroborate his decision. His estranged daughter's wishes may not reflect the patient's wishes, and given demonstrated decisional capacity with support from surrogates, the patient's wishes should be respected.

distractor_explanations.A: A court order or ethics consult (Choice B) are unnecessary. This patient possesses decisional capacity to make the decision to withdraw care. Neurologically impaired patients should not be assumed to lack decisional capacity to make decisions about their care. The medical team should evaluate the decisiona l capacity of this patient who is making decisions about his end-of-life care. This patient is able to communicate a consistent decision and demonstrate an appreciation of the consequences of his decision, and therefore, he appears to possess decisiona l capacity to make the decision to withdraw care. The medical team should respect the patient's autonomy and withdraw care. If a patient lacks decisional capacity, the medical team should identify a surrogate decision-maker. Unless the patient has identified a durable power of attorney, the spouse should serve as decision maker (adult children are typically second in line, followed by parents). Further reassuring in this case is that the patient's wife and adult children corroborate his decision. His estranged daughter 's wishes may not reflect the patient's wishes, and given demonstrated decisional capacity with support from surrogates, the patient's wishes should be respected. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D. A court order (Choice A) or ethics consult (Choice B) are unnecessary. This patient possesses decisional capacity to make the decision to withdraw care. Court orders and ethical consults may be considered when a patient lacks decisional capacity, refuses needed care, and lacks surrogate decision makers. Leaving the patient on artificial life support (Choice C) or continuing some life sustaining measures (Choice D) counters this patient's autonomy. The medical team should respect the decision of this patient with decisional capacity.

explanation.educational_objective: Physicians should evaluate all patients' decisiona l capacity to make decisions about their care. Patients who possess decisiona l capacity should have the final say in decisions about their care, even if family members disagree with the decision. .,

vignette.presentation:
1. A ?-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of progressive slleepiness, ataxia, and double vision over the past 2 days. She has a 2-year
history of complex partial seizures treated with carbamazepine. One week ago, she developed fever and received erythromycin for pharyngitis. Her
brother has attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder treated with methyllphenidate. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). She appears sleepy. Ocular
movements appear full. She has no weakness, but is moderately ataxic. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her current symptoms?

question_stem: the most likely cause of her current symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Carbamazepine is a common antiepileptic medication. It has been shown to interact with other medications and caution should be exercised when choosing concomitant medications for treating patients. It is a CYP450 inducer, which may increase hepatic clearance of some medications (eg, warfarin, phenytoin, valproic acid), leading to subtherapeutic concentrations in the serum. Other drugs, such as erythromycin, can interfere with the hepatic metabolism of carbamazepine by inhibiting CYP450 enzymes, leading to decreased carbamazepine clearance, increased serum concentration, and toxicity. Carbamazepine toxicity typically presents with altered mental status, drowsiness, ataxia, nystagmus, nausea, and vomiting. Diagnosis can be made by measuring a serum carbamazepine concentration above therapeutic levels, and there is a dose-dependent effect on neurologic depression. Treatment is supportive, with benzodiazepines for seizures or agitation, and involves discontinuation of offending medications.

distractor_explanations.B: Cerebellar astrocytomas are slow-growing and typically benign tumors in children and young adults. Children with astrocytomas can present with headache, nausea, vomiting, irritability, behavioral changes, impaired coordination, and visual impairment, depending on the size and location of the astrocytoma. Typical allergic reactions to medications, including erythromycin (Choice C), would present with rash, urticaria, and, if severe, signs and symptoms of anaphylaxis such as oropharyngeal, lip, or tongue swelling; voice changes; wheezing; shortness of breath; vomiting; or other gastrointestinal disturbances.
distractor_explanations.D: Methylphenidate is a central nervous system stimulant used to treat attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder by blocking norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake in neuronal synapses. The inappropriate ingestion of methylphenidate can present with agitation, anxiety, palpitations, decreased appetite, tremors, hyperreflexia, delirium, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis. Viral encephalitis (Choice E) typically presents with fever, headache, altered mental status, and neurologic abnormalities such as seizure, aphasia, hemiparesis, or cranial nerve deficits. This patient does not demonstrate a fever and a carbamazepine-erythromycin interaction is a more likely cause of this patient's altered mental status.

explanation.educational_objective: Erythromycin can interfere with the hepatic metabolism of carbamazepine by inhibiting CYP450 enzymes, leading to decreased carbamazepine clearance, increased serum concentration, and toxicity. Carbamazepine toxicity typically presents with altered mental status, drowsiness, ataxia, nystagmus, nausea, and vomiting. .,. Waiting for www.starttest.co ~.:. · - - · Clinical

vignette.presentation:
2. A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive billateral leg pain over the past year. The pain is located on the posterior aspect
of the thighs and calves, occurs only when he is standing, and resolv,es within 30 seconds of sitting or lying down. He has noticed that the pain is
less intense if he leans on something as he walks, such as a grocery cart. He can still ride an exercise bicycle without developing any pain. He has
hypertension, hyperlipidemia , and a small abdominal aortic aneurysm. He had a left carotid endarterectomy 3 years ago after several transient
ischemic attacks in the left hemisphere. Medications include lisinopril, lovastatin, and aspirin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for
30 years. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 110 kg (242 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations
are 12/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a right femoral bruit and diminished pedal pulses. Which of the following is
the most likely cause of this patient's lower extremity pain?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's lower extremity pain?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The patient's symptoms are most consistent with neurogenic claudication caused by lumbar spinal stenosis. Spinal stenosis describes narrowing of the central canal, neural foramen, or lateral recesses of the spine with consequent nerve compression. Common causes include degenerative arthritis, spondyloarthropathies, degenerative disc disease, hypertrophy of the ligamentum flavum, and osteophyte formation in the facet joints. Neurogenic claudication describes lower back pain with radiation to the buttocks and lower extremities that results from increased nerve compression, as may occur with extension of the spine during standing and walking downhill. Lengthening the spinal column with spinal flexion as during sitting, walking uphill, or leaning against a grocery cart, tends to relieve the pain. Diagnostic evaluation involves x-rays followed by MRI of the lumbar spine to evaluate the degree of spinal stenosis and whether surgical management is necessary.

distractor_explanations.A: Cerebrovascular disease is a concern in this patient with multiple risk factors and a history of transient ischemic attacks; however, progressive bilateral leg pain that is worsened or relieved by postural changes is more consistent with lumbar spinal stenosis. Persistent or new motor or sensory deficits would be more concerning for cerebrovascular disease. Lumbosacral plexopathy (Choice C) describes a diverse range of motor and sensory disturbances to the lower extremities, including weakness, paresis, pain, numbness, and tingling, resulting from lesions of the lumbosacra l plexus. Patients typically display abnormalities along multiple contiguous nerve root distributions. Diagnostic evaluation includes a thorough neurologic and r ~ -- - - , r, Clinical E) Trochanteric bursitis Correct Answer: B. The patient's symptoms are most consistent with neurogenic claudication caused by lumbar spinal stenosis. Spinal stenosis describes narrowing of the central canal, neural foramen, or lateral recesses of the spine with consequent nerve compression. Common causes include degenerative arthritis, spondyloarthropathies, degenerative disc disease, hypertrophy of the ligamentum flavum, and osteophyte formation in the facet joints. Neurogenic claudication describes lower back pain with radiation to the buttocks and lower extremities that results from increased nerve compression, as may occur with extension of the spine during standing and walking downhill. Lengthening the spinal column with spinal flexion as during sitting, walking uphill, or leaning against a grocery cart, tends to relieve the pain. Diagnostic evaluation involves x-rays followed by MRI of the lumbar spine to evaluate the degree of spinal stenosis and whether surgical management is necessary. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, and E. Cerebrovascular disease (Choice A) is a concern in this patient with multiple risk factors and a history of transient ischemic attacks; however, progressive bilateral leg pain that is worsened or relieved by postural changes is more consistent with lumbar spinal stenosis. Persistent or new motor or sensory deficits would be more concerning for cerebrovascular disease. Lumbosacral plexopathy (Choice C) describes a diverse range of motor and sensory disturbances to the lower extremities, including weakness, paresis, pain, numbness, and tingling, resulting from lesions of the lumbosacral plexus. Patients typically display abnormalities along multiple contiguous nerve root distributions. Diagnostic evaluation includes a thorough neurologic and musculoskeletal examination, imaging of the lumbar spine, electromyography, and nerve conduction studies. Peripheral vascular disease (Choice D) is also a common cause of claudication, and this patient has multiple risk factors including tobacco use, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity. His physical examination findings support the presence of peripheral vascular disease with a right femoral bruit and diminished pedal pulses. However, claudication caused by peripheral vascular disease is commonly relieved by rest rather than postural changes. His symptoms are more likely caused by lumbar spinal stenosis. Trochanteric bursitis (Choice E) classically presents with lateral! hip pain that is exacerbated by activity. Physical examination shows point tenderness over the greater trochanter and increased pain with external rotation of the hip as a result of compression of the bursa. Bilateral, posterior leg pain is not consistent with a diagnosis of trochanteric bursitis.

explanation.educational_objective: Lower extremity pain that is exacerbated by extension of the spinal column and relieved by flexion is suggestive of neurogenic claudication resulting from lumbar spinal stenosis. ., Clinical

vignette.presentation:
3. A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of dribbling fluid from her mouth every time she drinks. She has not had
difficulty swallowing or any other symptoms. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She has an active lifestyle. Vital signs
are within normal limits. Examination shows drooping of the lower lip on the left. The left forehead does not wrinkle on upward gaze. The remainder
of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Bell palsy refers to a facial nerve palsy that leads to unilateral facial paralysis. It is most commonly caused by viral-mediated inflammation or immune reaction in the setting of a herpes simplex or herpes zoster infection, although it can also be idiopathic or caused by other viral infections. It presents acutely with unilateral facial paralysis that includes the forehead, consistent with its lower motoneuron pathologic involvement. It can also be associated with loss of taste on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and decreased lacrimation. Symptoms typically peak around 3 weeks, with slow recovery beginning within 6 months. Diagnosis is most commonly based on clinical symptoms, but electrodiagnostic tests, such as EMG, and imaging of the face and head can be utilized if the diagnosis is unclear. Initial treatment consists of oral glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, and antiviral therapy in severe cases.

distractor_explanations.A: Echocardiography is useful in the evaluation of embolic stroke, since an intracardiac thrombus or patent foramen ovale could explain its cause. However, a stroke that affects the facial musculature would spare the forehead. Additiona lly, this patient has no risk factors for stroke or symptoms such as extremity weakness or numbness to suggest this as an underlying diagnosis. MRI of the brain (Choice B) is useful in the evaluation of stroke, especially early in the course of the disease, before it may be evident on CT scan. This patient's symptoms are not consistent with stroke. Doxycycline therapy (Choice C) can be used in the treatment of Lyme disease, which may present with Bell palsy in disseminated Lyme disease. Lyme disease also typically presents with erythema migrans, fatigue, headache, myalgias, arthralgias, and lymphadenopathy, as well as myocarditis, abnormal liver function tests, and kidney injury. This patient has no other signs or symptoms to suggest Lyme disease. Lumbar puncture (Choice E) is used in the evaluation of central nervous system infections, such as bacterial meningitis and viral meningitis. While these infections can present with focal neurologic deficits, they are commonly associated with fever, nuchal rigidity, headache, and altered mental status.

explanation.educational_objective: Bell palsy is a unilateral, viral-mediated or idiopathic facial nerve palsy that causes facial paralysis that does not spare the forehead. Treatment utilizes glucocorticoids, and occasional ly, antiviral therapy. ., Clinical
