vignette.presentation:
4. A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of imbalance and leg weakness and a 3-day history of difficulty initiating
urination. He also has had mild midthoracic back pain for 5 months, but during the past 2 weeks, the pain has worsened and frequently awakens
him. He has had a 9-kg (20-lb) weight loss since an episode of bronchitis 6 months ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years.
He is cachectic and appears chronically ill. Examination shows scleral icterus. Muscle strength in the lower extremities is decreased in the proximal
and distal muscles bilaterally. There is no muscle atrophy, but tone is increased. Deep tendon reflexes are hyperactive, and Babinski sign is present
bilaterally. Sensation is decreased to pinprick to the umbilicus. Muscle strength, sensation, and reflexes in the upper extremities are normal. Which
of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's presenting signs and symptoms of focal back pain, upper motoneuron signs, and weight loss are suggestive of epidural spinal cord compression caused by metastatic carcinoma. Metastatic disease frequently affects the vertebral column and may cause compression of the spinal cord by extending into the epidural space or by causing bony destruction and fracture of the vertebral bodies. Patients present with back pain, lower extremity weakness, loss of balance, urinary or bowel incontinence, or complete paralysis of the lower extremities. Early detection and treatment are crucial to prevent permanent spinal cord damage and myelopathy. Patients may benefit from short-term treatment with intravenous dexamethasone to decrease spinal cord edema, although definitive treatment often requires a combination of surgical decompression, chemotherapy, and/or radiotherapy.

distractor_explanations.B: syndrome is characterized by the formation of autoantibodies against presynaptic calcium channels, resulting in the impairment of acetylcholine release at the neuromuscu lar junction. It presents with progressive proximal muscle weakness that improves with exercise and does not typically present with upper motoneuron signs. Spinal cord infarction (Choice C) may result from occlusion of the anterior or posterior spinal arteries and presents with abrupt onset myelopathy. Neuroimaging may be required to distinguish this entity from compressive spinal cord lesions. This patient's history of subacute onset and weight loss is more suggestive of a compressive epidural malignant lesion.
distractor_explanations.D: Syringomyelia features a cystic cavity in the central cervical or thoracic spinal cord, which affects midline structures such as the anterior white commissure (decussation of the spinothalamic tracts) and, if large enough, the anterior horns (cell bodies of lower motoneurons). Patients present with deficits in pain and temperature sensation and a potential lower motoneuron pattern of dysfunction in the bilateral upper extremities and torso. The syrinx may progressively expand to affect the lateral corticospinal tract as well, which would result in an upper motoneuron pattern of dysfunction in the lower body. Transverse myelitis (Choice E) refers to inflammation that extends transversely across the spinal cord, leading to bilateral sensory, motor, and/or autonomic dysfunction, often with a clearly identifiable spinal level below which normal function is decreased or absent. It is associated with multiple sclerosis and neuromyelitis optica, the latter of which is associated with the presence of anti-aquaporin-4 antibodies.

explanation.educational_objective: Patients with epidural spinal cord compression present with back pain, lower extremity weakness, loss of balance, urinary or bowel incontinence, or complete paralysis of the lower extremities. Metastatic disease is a frequent cause of epidural spinal cord compression. ., Clinical

vignette.presentation:
5. A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of buttock and leg pain. The pain occurs when she walks for more than
two blocks or stands for more than 10 minutes; sitting or bending forward provides relief within 1 minute. She has not had weakness or loss of
sensation. Bladder function has been normal. She has a 20-year history of lower back pain relieved with rest. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus well
controlled with metformin. Muscle strength is full. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ except for absent ankle reflexes. Sensation is intact. There is
decreased lumbar lordosis; lumbar flexion is full and extension is limited. Straight-leg raising is negative. Peripheral pulses are intact. Which of the
following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The patient's symptoms are best explained by lumbar spinal stenosis. Spinal stenosis describes narrowing of the central canal, neural foramen, or lateral recesses of the spine with consequent nerve compression. Lower back pain with radiation to the buttocks and lower extremities that results from increased nerve compression is called neurogenic claudication. It is exacerbated by extension of the spine during standing and walking downhill. Lengthening the spinal column with spinal flexion as during sitting, walking uphill, or bending forward tends to relieve the pain. The absence of ankle reflexes suggests involvement of the S 1 nerve root.

distractor_explanations.A: Femoropopliteal arterial stenosis is a common complication of atherosclerosis and peripheral vascular disease. Patients may present with vascular claudication, which is more commonly provoked by exertion and relieved by rest. Severe stenosis may result in limb ischemia. A bruit may be appreciated over the femoral artery, and peripheral pulses would be diminished in the affected extremity. The pain is reproduced by flexion, adduction, and internal rotation of the hip, which tenses the piriformis muscle. A negative straight-leg test is less suggestive of the diagnosis. vignette.presentation:
6. An otherwise healthy 77-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of severe dizziness. Several times every day she
has the sudden onset of a spinning sensation and loss of equilibrium that lasts for 20 to 30 seconds. The episodes begin most frequently after she
rolls over in bed or turns her head to the right. Her pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows no
abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Doppler ultrasonography of the carotid arteries

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is a common cause of vertigo and is best diagnosed with positional oculovestibular testing. BPPV occurs when an otolith becomes dislodged from the utricle and enters the semicircular canals. Changes in head posture then cause the malpositioned otolith to move within the semicircular canals, stimulating abnormal movements in endolymph and causing a sensation of vertigo. Patients typically report symptoms of intense, brief episodes of vertigo that occur after changes in position (such as after rolling over or rising from bed), accompanied by visual disturbances (caused by nystagmus), nausea, and vomiting. Positional oculovestibular testing, such as the Dix-Hallpike test, allows the examiner to reproduce the patient's symptoms by repositioning the otolith. Further positional maneuvers, such as the Epley maneuver, can be used to move the malpositioned otolith to its proper position within the utricle. Patients with refractory symptoms may benefit from medical management including scopolamine or meclizine.

distractor_explanations.D: Doppler ultrasonography of the carotid arteries is useful for the diagnosis of carotid stenosis, which may produce position dependent symptoms of presyncope or syncope. However, these symptoms would be more likely to occur upon suddenly standing, rather than while rolling in bed or turning one's head. EEG (Choice E) is useful for the diagnosis of epilepsy. This patient's lack of postictal symptoms or other suggestive symptoms, such as premonitory aura, generalized muscle spasms, or loss of bladder or bowel control, render this a less likely diagnosis.
distractor_explanations.F: Electronystagmography evaluates nystagmus as a method of diagnosing disorders of the vestibular system. While this technique may be indicated for patients with refractory symptoms, it is not necessary for the initial evaluation or treatment of BPPV. Magnetic resonance angiography (Choice G) is useful for the diagnosis of vertebrobasilar insufficiency, which may cause position dependent symptoms of vertigo. Similar to blood pressure-dependent causes of presyncope, such as orthostasis or carotid stenosis, these symptoms would be expected to occur upon suddenly standing, rather than while rolling in bed or turning one's head.

7. A 35-year-old woman has had constant burning pain in her right hand since closing her hand in a car door 1 year ago. Examination immediately
following the injury showed extensive ecchymosis and swelling. No fractures were identified, but the hand was placed in a cast for 1 month. She is
unable to tolerate light touch or any motion of the wrist or finger joints during the current examination. Which of the following is the most likely
explanation for these findings?

question_stem:
the most likely
explanation for these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Abnormal sympathetic neural response, also known as reflex sympathetic dystrophy or complex regional pain syndrome, can potentially occur after traumatic injuries and has a variety of clinical characteristics. Commonly, patients will develop pain out of proportion to the degree of injury in a distinct anatomic location that does not correspond to a single nerve or dermatome. The exact pathophysiology is unknown but is thought to involve either changes in central pain processing or aberrant stimulation of damaged peripheral nerves that release inflammatory substances such as neuropeptide Y and substance P. Common clinical manifestations include pain out of proportion to the injury with severe allodynia, impaired muscle strength in the location of injury, autonomic changes including increased sweating and color or temperature changes, and occasionally atrophy or fibrosis.

distractor_explanations.B: Increased intracarpal canal pressure leads to carpal tunnel syndrome as a result of compression of the median nerve at the wrist. Symptoms include paresthesias in the palmar aspect of the first two or three digits. Median nerve fibrosis (Choice C) can sometimes occur following a bone fracture with injury to the nerve or after surgical intervention. Symptoms include sensory and motor disturbances in the distribution of the median nerve and depend upon the location at which the median nerve is affected. Post-traumatic arthritis (Choice D) describes joint pain that occurs following a traumatic injury to the articular cartilage of a joint. Like most cases of osteoarthritis, pain is localized to the affected joint and worsens with activity but improves with rest. Temperature changes and sensory changes of the skin are not seen unless the traumatic injury also resulted in trauma to local tissues or nerves. Abnormal sympathetic neural response, also known as reflex sympathetic dystrophy or complex regional pain syndrome, can potentially occur after traumatic injuries and has a variety of clinical characteristics. Commonly, patients will develop pain out of proportion to the degree of injury in a distinct anatomic location that does not correspond to a single nerve or dermatome. The exact pathophysiology is unknown but is thought to involve either changes in central pain processing or aberrant stimulation of damaged peripheral nerves that release inflammatory substances such as neuropeptide Y and substance P. Common clinical manifestations include pain out of proportion to the injury with severe allodynia, impaired muscle strength in the location of injury, autonomic changes including increased sweating and color or temperature changes, and occasiona lly atrophy or fibrosis. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E. Increased intracarpal canal pressure (Choice B) leads to carpal tunnel syndrome as a result of compression of the median nerve at the wrist. Symptoms include paresthesias in the palmar aspect of the first two or three digits. Median nerve fibrosis (Choice C) can sometimes occur following a bone fracture with injury to the nerve or after surgical intervention. Symptoms include sensory and motor disturbances in the distribution of the median nerve and depend upon the location at which the median nerve is affected. Post-traumatic arthritis (Choice D) describes joint pain that occurs following a traumatic injury to the articular cartilage of a joint. Like most cases of osteoarthritis, pain is localized to the affected joint and worsens with activity but improves with rest. Temperature changes and sensory changes of the skin are not seen unless the traumatic injury also resulted in trauma to local tissues or nerves. Radial artery thrombosis (Choice E) can occur following trauma or instrumentation, as might occur with the placement of a radial artery catheter. Often, the ulnar artery provides enough collateral blood flow to maintain perfusion to the hand, but in patients where the palmar arch is incomplete, thrombosis can lead to ischemia of the hand.

vignette.presentation:
8. A 25-year-o ld woman has had generalized weakness for 2 days. On quest ioning, she reports numerous hospital admissions for abdominal pain.
One episode occurred after treatment of a urinary tract infection with a sulfonamide. Examination shows global weakness and areflexia; Babinski
sign is absent. Sensation to pinprick is mildly decreased in a stocking-glove distribut ion, and sensation to vibration is decreased over the feet. She
has tachycardia that does not slow with carotid massage. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Acute intermittent porphyria is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with episodic abdominal pain and peripheral neuropathy in a stocking-glove distribution, which is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the porphobilinogen deaminase gene (PBGD). This enzyme catalyzes the third step in heme synthesis, which combines four porphobi linogen (PBG) molecules into hydroxymethylbilane, which is subsequently converted to uroporphyrinogen Ill. Loss of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of PBG, which is toxic to the nervous system. Additionally, increased activity of the upstream enzyme, delta-aminolevulinic acid synthase (ALAS1) leads to accumulation of ALA, which is also toxic. The mutation affects both erythroid cells and hepatocytes. The disease's manifestations are primarily neurologic and include periphera l neuropathy, bladder dysfunction, and autonomic dysfunction. Abdominal pain is classic and results often from ileus. The penetrance is low, so a family history is not often present, which can delay the diagnosis. Disease flares can occur after exposure to certain triggers such as certain medications, tobacco and alcohol, stress, and starvation.

distractor_explanations.B: Alcoholic neuropathy presents with a primary sensory neuropathy that starts in the feet and progresses proximally. A history of chronic alcohol intake is required for this diagnosis. Other nutritional deficiencies are often present as well. Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (Choice C) is a genetic disorder that presents with slowly progressive peripheral neuropathy often in association with foot deformities such as hammertoes and pes cavus. A family history is typical. Diabetic radiculopathy (Choice D) occurs most commonly in patients with recently diagnosed or uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, and is Clinical Correct Answer: A. Acute intermittent porphyria is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with episodic abdominal pain and peripheral neuropathy in a stocking-glove distribution, which is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the porphobilinogen deaminase gene (PBGD). This enzyme catalyzes the third step in heme synthesis, which combines four porphobi linogen (PBG) molecules into hydroxymethylbilane, which is subsequent ly converted to uroporphyrinogen Ill. Loss of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of PBG, which is toxic to the nervous system. Additiona lly, increased activity of the upstream enzyme, delta-aminolevulinic acid synthase (ALAS1) leads to accumulation of ALA, which is also toxic. The mutation affects both erythroid cells and hepatocytes. The disease's manifestations are primarily neurologic and include periphera l neuropathy, bladder dysfunction, and autonomic dysfunction. Abdominal pain is classic and results often from ileus. The penetrance is low, so a family history is not often present, which can delay the diagnosis. Disease flares can occur after exposure to certain triggers such as certain medications, tobacco and alcohol, stress, and starvation. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, E, F, and G. Alcoholic neuropathy (Choice B) presents with a primary sensory neuropathy that starts in the feet and progresses proxima lly. A history of chronic alcohol intake is required for this diagnosis. Other nutritiona l deficiencies are often present as well. Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (Choice C) is a genetic disorder that presents with slowly progressive peripheral neuropathy often in association with foot deformities such as hammertoes and pes cavus. A family history is typical. Diabetic radiculopathy (Choice D) occurs most common ly in patients with recently diagnosed or uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, and is most commonly characterized by acute, asymmetric radicular symptoms involving the proximal leg. Guillain-Barre syndrome (Choice E) manifests as rapidly progressive, ascending weakness and areflexia that often follows a viral or diarrheal illness. It does not affect the arms at the same time as the legs. Patients can develop respiratory insufficiency, which can occasiona lly require mechanical ventilation.
distractor_explanations.F: Leprosy is caused by infection with Mycobacterium leprae and is exceedingly rare in the developed world. It presents with characteristic skin findings in conjunction with peripheral sensory neuropathy commonly involving the ulnar, median, radial, or peroneal nerves. Paraneoplastic neuropathy (Choice G) is most commonly a peripheral sensory neuropathy that is related to an underlying systemic malignancy and is often secondary to the production of autoantibodies. This patient has no evidence of cancer.

explanation.educational_objective: Acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant disease with low penetrance caused by deficiencies in the PBGD gene leading to the accumulation of hepatically synthesized heme intermediates, which are toxic to the nervous system. Typical findings include episodic abdomina l pain, sensory neuropathy, and autonomic dysfunction that occurs after certain triggers Clinical

vignette.presentation:
9. A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of stiffness and pain of her neck, shoulders, and hips. She has difficulty
dressing herself and combing her hair in the morning. She also has had generalized weakness, malaise, and a low-grade fever. She has had a
2.3-kg (5-lb) weight loss during the past month despite no changes in diet. She has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is occasiona l
acetaminophen for pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows pitting edema of the hands and the dorsal aspects of the feet.
Range of motion of the neck, shoulders, and hips is limited. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 110 mm/h. Additiona l laboratory findings, including
her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration, are within the reference ranges. X-rays of the shoulders and feet show no abnormalities.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is an inflammatory condition in which aching and stiffness develop in the shoulders, hip, and neck. The most common risk factors are age (older than 50 years) and being female. It is also frequently associated with giant cell, or temporal arteritis, which presents with unilateral headache and vision loss, if untreated. Other inflammatory signs, such as malaise and fever, are often present, though localized muscle weakness is not typically seen. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates increased inflammatory markers, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein, and thrombocytosis. Polymyalgia rheumatica is responsive to glucocorticoids, which are the first-line therapy for the disease. Low-dose prednisone is the treatment of choice.

distractor_explanations.A: Bursitis is inflammation of one or more bursae and is manifested by pain and swelling over a single joint. Some examples include the subacromial bursa which can cause pain in the shoulder, the trochanteric bursa which can cause pain over the lateral aspect of the hip, and the olecranon bursa which can cause pain and swelling posterior to the elbow. When inflamed or injured, fluid can collect inside the potential space of the bursa causing swelling, which can be appreciated on examination as a fluctuant, tender, circumscribed mass. Muscle stiffness is not a typical feature.
distractor_explanations.B: Dermatomyositis and polymyositis (Choice E) are autoimmune inflammatory myopathies characterized by muscle weakness, rather than stiffness, of the proximal muscles. Dermatomyositis additionally demonstrates cutaneous findings including a light pink- or heliotrope-colored rash on the eyelids and Gottron papules on the dorsal fingers. Unlike PMR, fibromyalgia (Choice C) affects middle-aged women at various anatomica l sites in conjunction with anxiety, stress, and point tenderness. ESR is normal. This patient's limited involvement to the pelvic and hip girdles along with other inflammatory symptoms including generalized weakness, malaise, and fever suggest a diagnosis of PMR over fibromya lgia. Rheumatoid arthritis (Choice F) is a common autoimmune disease characterized by joint destruction, pain, and upregulation of immunomodulatory cytokines. Muscle pain and stiffness are not typical features.

explanation.educational_objective: Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is an inflammatory condition in which aching and stiffness develop in the muscles of the hip and shoulder girdles. Low-dose prednisone is the treatment of choice Exam Section : Item 10 of 50 Clinical 'f 10. A 57-year-o ld woman comes to the physician because of daily headaches for 8 months. The headaches are localized to the right temple and usually worsen throughout the day. At times, the headaches are exacerbated by chewing. She has a history of migraines but has not had one since menopause 6 years ago. She recently divorced and is under a great deal of stress at work. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Her temperatu re is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 144/86 mm Hg. Examination shows pain with movement of the jaw and tenderness under the right zygoma tic arch. The nasal mucosa is normal. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 20 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Bacterial meningitis B) Cluster headache C) Migraine D) Sinusitis E) Temporal arteritis F) Temporomandibu lar joint syndrome G) Tension-type headache H) Trigeminal neuralgia Correct Answer: F. The temporomandibu lar joint (TMJ) forms the articulation between the mandibular condyle and the glenoid fossa of the temporal bone. TMJ syndrome occurs because of a combination of structural damage to the TMJ and a variety of neurologic and psychological factors related to pain and stress. Patients usually present with unilatera l, dull, occasionally sharp or stabbing pain near the TMJ or anterior to the auricle that is exacerbated by chewing or jaw clenching. Patients may also experience popping or clicking sensations associated with movement of the jaw and a decreased range of jaw motion. Treatment includes physical therapy, cognitive behavior therapy or biofeedback therapy to treat underlying stress, and pharmacologic therapy including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or tricyclic antidepressants. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, E, G, and H. Bacterial meningitis (Choice A) presents with fever and signs of meningeal irritation (nausea, irritability, confusion, anorexia, headache, and nuchal rigidity). This patient's absence of fever and meningismus renders this diagnosis unlikely. Cluster headache (Choice B) are primary headaches that typical ly present with short-lived, unilateral, severe, often lancinating pain in the orbital, supraorbital, or tempora l region of the head and are accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (eg, lacrimation, mydriasis, perspiration, nasal congestion) Exam Section : Item 10 of 50 Clinical Correct Answer: F. The temporomandibu lar joint (TMJ) forms the articulation between the mandibular condyle and the glenoid fossa of the temporal bone. TMJ syndrome occurs because of a combination of structural damage to the TMJ and a variety of neurologic and psychological factors related to pain and stress. Patients usually present with unilateral, dull, occasionally sharp or stabbing pain near the TMJ or anterior to the auricle that is exacerbated by chewing or jaw clenching. Patients may also experience popping or clicking sensations associated with movement of the jaw and a decreased range of jaw motion. Treatment includes physical therapy, cognitive behavior therapy or biofeedback therapy to treat underlying stress, and pharmacologic therapy including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or tricyclic antidepressants. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, E, G, and H. Bacterial meningitis (Choice A) presents with fever and signs of meningeal irritation (nausea, irritability, confusion, anorexia, headache, and nuchal rigidity). This patient's absence of fever and meningismus renders this diagnosis unlikely. Cluster headache (Choice B) are primary headaches that typically present with short-lived, unilateral, severe, often lancinating pain in the orbital, supraorbital, or temporal region of the head and are accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (eg, lacrimation, mydriasis, perspiration, nasal congestion). Migraines (Choice C) are a common cause of headache in adult patients. They may present with visual aura of scintillating scotoma or fortification spectra but are not associated with focal tenderness of the jaw or pain with chewing. Sinusitis (Choice D) may be associated with bilateral, pressure-like, periorbital headaches and nasal congestion. Patients may experience focal tenderness and tenderness to percussion overlying the affected sinus (typically overlying the brow or maxilla) but rarely experience focal jaw tenderness overlying the TMJ. Temporal arteritis (Choice E), also known as giant cell arteritis, is a vasculitis of medium and large vessels in elderly patients and commonly presents with systemic symptoms, headache, jaw claudication, proximal muscle stiffness, and sudden, irreversible vision loss. This patient's chronic course, lack of associated systemic symptoms, and normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate render this diagnosis less likely. Tension-type headache (Choice G) typically presents with bilateral dull, pressure-like or band-like pain across the bilateral frontal and temporal areas. It does not tend to present with focal tenderness of the jaw or pain with chewing. Trigeminal neuralgia (Choice H), also known as tic douloureux, presents with brief, recurrent, sudden episodes of pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve. This is typically triggered by minor stimulation to the affected area, such as light touch, cold air, talking, or brushing one's teeth. Patients often describe the pain as sharp, stabbing, or electric Exam Section : Item 10 of 50 Clinical Please Walt • • I • • • • • • I. • I I J. • i, I I • ,, • t - • • • J. • e • · t • • • t e t t t e • t • • e • e • • t with movement of the jaw and a decreased range of jaw motion. vignette.presentation:
11. A 42-year-old man comes to the physician with his wife because of a 6-month history of increasing clumsiness and a 1-month history of irritability.
His wife has noticed jerkiness of his limbs when he walks down stairs or walks quickly. During the past month, he has had the same involuntary
movements at rest after stressful days at work. He has not had fever, chills, or night sweats. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use
illicit drugs. He goes camping several times yearly. He does not appear to be in distress. Examination shows involuntary movements of the right
upper extremity, which the patient is able to suppress when made aware of them. His gait is ataxic. Additional testing is most likely to show which
of the following abnormalities?

question_stem:
most likely to show which
of the following abnormalities?

choices.text: Atrophy of the caudate nucleus on brain imaging
Increased oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid
Increased serum acetylcholine esterase inhibitor concentration
Increased oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid
Increased serum acetylcholine esterase inhibitor concentration

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Atrophy of the caudate nucleus on brain imaging would be expected in this patient who most likely has Huntington disease, a progressive neurodegenerat ive condition that arises from misfolded proteins as the result of a trinucleotide expansion in the Huntington gene. Patients develop choreiform movements, which are characterized by involuntary flailing motions of the upper extremities. Eventually, these motor disturbances and others, including ataxic gait, greatly interfere with daily life. Concomitant psychiatric disturbances such as emotional !ability, anxiety, depression, and psychosis may also occur in the later stages of the disease. Many patients exhibit a family history of similar symptoms, but the disease can also arise de novo. Since this is an autosomal dominant disease, there is a 50% chance that an affected individual will pass it on to offspring. Anticipation, whereby symptoms manifest at progressive ly earlier ages and/or more severely in subsequent generations, is also typical of this disease.

distractor_explanations.B: concentration is not correct. High concentrations of MMA are seen in vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency, which can lead to subacute combined degeneration of the spine. 12 Dilated ventricles on brain imaging (Choice C) are seen in patients with hydrocephalus, which can either be communicating or noncommunicating. Patients can present with headaches, nausea, vomiting, or gait instability but would not typically exhibit choreiform movemen.ts Exam Section : Item 11 of 50 Clinical J. • • • .. .. • • D) Increased oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid E) Increased serum acetylcholine esterase inhibitor concentration F) Positive serum lgM Lyme titer Correct Answer: A. Atrophy of the caudate nucleus on brain imaging would be expected in this patient who most likely has Huntington disease, a progressive neurodegenerative condition that arises from misfolded proteins as the result of a trinucleotide expansion in the Huntington gene. Patients develop choreiform movements, which are characterized by involuntary flailing motions of the upper extremities. Eventually, these motor disturbances and others, including ataxic gait, greatly interfere with daily life. Concomitant psychiatric disturbances such as emotional !ability, anxiety, depression, and psychosis may also occur in the later stages of the disease. Many patients exhibit a family history of similar symptoms, but the disease can also arise de novo. Since this is an autosomal dominant disease, there is a 50% chance that an affected individual will pass it on to offspring. Anticipation, whereby symptoms manifest at progressive ly earlier ages and/or more severely in subsequent generations, is also typical of this disease. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, E, and F. Decreased serum methylma lonic acid (MMA) concentration (Choice B) is not correct. High concentrations of MMA are seen in vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency, which can lead to subacute combined degeneration of the spine. 12 Dilated ventricles on brain imaging (Choice C) are seen in patients with hydrocepha lus, which can either be communicating or noncommunicating. Patients can present with headaches, nausea, vomiting, or gait instability but would not typically exhibit choreiform movements. Increased oligoclona l bands in cerebrospinal fluid (Choice D) is characteristic of multiple sclerosis (MS). Patients can develop a variety of sensory and motor symptoms but characteristical ly present with internuclear ophthalmoplegia. They do not exhibit choreiform movements. Increased serum acetylcholine esterase inhibitor concentration (Choice E) is seen in patients with organophosphate poisoning. Cholinergic toxicity presents with excess salivation, bradycardia, emesis, and central nervous system depression. Positive serum lgM Lyme titer (Choice F) can be seen in acute Lyme disease, which presents with erythema migrans following a tick bite. Late neurologic manifestations of Lyme disease include cranial nerve palsies, but choreiform movements would not be expected.

explanation.educational_objective: Huntington disease presents with progressive neurodegeneration leading to choreiform movement, ataxia, and neuropsychiatric decline. On MRI, the caudate nucleus often appears atrophic Exam Section : Item 12 of 50 Clinical

vignette.presentation:
12. A previously healthy 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of difficulty communicat ing. His wife
reports that when he awoke this morning, he seemed slightly confused and "did not make sense." He has hyperlipidemia treated with simvastatin.
He does not appear to be in distress. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 35 kg/m2 . His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F),
pulse is 85/min and irregular, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Examination shows mild right pronator drift. During the
examination, he is attentive but has some difficulty naming objects correctly and following two-step commands. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation.
Which of the following is this patient's greatest risk factor for his neurologic condition?

choices.text: Recommendation that the patient move to an assisted living community
Brachia! plexus compression G) Median nerve compress ion at the wrist
Central nervous system compression H) Radial nerve compression at the elbow
Central nervous system demyelination I) Radial nerve compression at the spiral groove
Central nervous system ischemia J) Ulnar nerve compression at the elbow
Cervical nerve root compression K) Ulnar nerve compression at the wrist
Median nerve compress ion at the elbow

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The acute onset of focal neurologic deficits, motor weakness, confusion, and dysphasia is concerning for a thromboembo lic cerebral infarction, or stroke. Atrial fibrillation is a major independent risk factor for strokes, and stroke prevention is an essential aspect of management. The loss of coordinated atrial contraction in this dysrhythmia results in blood stasis within the atrial compartment and promotion of thrombus formation. Embolism to the cerebral arteries results in ischemic stroke. The presence of right-sided hemiplegia and expressive dysphasia are suggestive of a lesion involving the left middle cerebral artery distribution. The middle cerebral arteries are the most common cerebral arteries involved in acute thromboembolic stroke.

distractor_explanations.E: and weight are all additional risk factors for cardiovascular disease and stroke. Other risk factors include tobacco use, diabetes mellitus, presence of mechanical heart valves, hypercoagu lable conditions, patent foramen ovale (allowing for passage of paradoxical venous thromboembo lism to the systemic circulation), heart failure with severely decreased ejection fraction, and a personal or family history of prior stroke. The presence of atrial fibrillation in this patient is the greatest risk factor for a stroke.

explanation.educational_objective: Atrial fibrillation is a major independent risk factor for ischemic stroke. Preventative anticoagulation should be considered for patients with additional risk factors, such as congestive heart failure, hypertension, advanced age, diabetes mellitus, prior stroke or transient ischemic attack, and atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease Clinical "t 13. A 77-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because he has become increasingly forgetful during the past 6 months. His daughter states that his short-term memory is quite impaired, and he says that he is frustrated with his memory. He lives alone and is able to perform activities of daily living independently. On questioning, he reports a 1-month history of a mild nonproductive cough, constipation, mild pain in his hips with movement, mild numbness of the toes of both feet, and a few episodes of urinary incontinence. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. His wife died 6 years ago. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/72 mm Hg. Muscle strength is normal. Cranial nerves are intact. Deep tendon reflexes are normal. Sensation to vibration is mildly decreased over the distal lower extremities. Proprioception is intact. His gait is wide based, and he has impaired tandem walking. His Mini-Mental State Examination score is 24/30; he recalls one of three objects after 5 minutes. An MRI of the brain shows slightly enlarged ventricles with minimal cortical atrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A) Recommendation that the patient move to an assisted living community B) Discontinuation of atorvastatin therapy C) Discontinuation of metformin therapy D) Addition of donepezil therapy E) Addition of paroxetine therapy F) Lumbar puncture ~- Correct Answer: F. The patient is presenting with findings concerning for normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), with the characteristic combination of dementia (eg, frontal executive dysfunction), gait instability, and urinary incontinence. NPH refers to a type of communicating (nonobstructive) hydrocephalus in which the ventricles are enlarged, leading to damage of the white matter tracts connecting the frontal lobes and basal ganglia. Signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, papilledema, postural headaches) are typically absent. Many cases of NPH are idiopathic, though some are secondary to a defect in cerebrospinal fluid drainage from the ventricles as a result of scarring or obstruction of the ventricular lining from prior hemorrhage or meningitis. The diagnosis is primarily clinical, although ventriculomegaly on brain imaging is suggestive. The most appropriate next step in management is a lumbar puncture to assess the opening pressure and clinical response to removing cerebrospinal fluid. Placement of a ventricular shunt may be needed for long-term management. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, and E. Recommendation that the patient move to an assisted living community (Choice A) is inappropriate prior to a thorough evaluation for intervenable causes. Recovery of executive function in patients with NPH that has progressed to dementia is uncertain. It may be appropriate to refer to assisted living if the patient continues to decline and is unable to manage activities of daily living. . r ~- - - , r - - - , Clinical Please Walt F) Lumbar puncture Correct Answer: F. The patient is presenting with findings concerning for normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), with the characteristic combination of dementia (eg, frontal executive dysfunction), gait instability, and urinary incontinence. NPH refers to a type of communicating (nonobstructive) hydrocepha lus in which the ventricles are enlarged, leading to damage of the white matter tracts connecting the frontal lobes and basal ganglia. Signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, papilledema, postural headaches) are typically absent. Many cases of NPH are idiopathic, though some are secondary to a defect in cerebrospinal fluid drainage from the ventricles as a result of scarring or obstruction of the ventricular lining from prior hemorrhage or meningitis. The diagnosis is primarily clinical, although ventriculomegaly on brain imaging is suggestive. The most appropriate next step in management is a lumbar puncture to assess the opening pressure and clinical response to removing cerebrospinal fluid. Placement of a ventricular shunt may be needed for long-term management. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, and E. Recommendation that the patient move to an assisted living community (Choice A) is inappropriate prior to a thorough evaluation for intervenable causes. Recovery of executive function in patients with NPH that has progressed to dementia is uncertain. It may be appropriate to refer to assisted living if the patient continues to decline and is unable to manage activities of daily living. Discontinuation of atorvastatin therapy (Choice B) and discontinuation of metformin therapy (Choice C) may be considered later in the patient's course depending on the degree of recovery. Medications that confer long-term benefits are often discontinued in patients with progressive dementia or life-limiting conditions to avoid unnecessary side effects and pill burden. Addition of donepezil therapy (Choice D) may be considered in the future if the patient's cognitive symptoms do not improve. The next best initial step in management for this patient is to perform a lumbar puncture and assess his clinical response to the removal of cerebrospinal fluid. Addition of paroxetine therapy (Choice E) would not be indicated currently. Cognitive impairment and memory disturbances may be manifestations of depression, especially in older adults, and patients should be screened for depression as part of the initial evaluation. Initiating an antidepressant would not be appropriate at this time. Educational Objective: The triad of cognitive impairment, urinary incontinence, and gait instability should raise concern for normal pressure hydrocephalus. Initial evaluation should include neuroimaging and a lumbar puncture to assess the patient's opening pressure and clinical response to the removal of cerebrospinal fluid Exam Section : Item 14 of 50 Clinical "t 14. A previously healthy 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of intermittent pain and tingling that radiates from his right shoulder blade to his right thumb and index finger. These symptoms worsen with coughing and sneezing. There is no history of neck, shoulder, or arm injury. His pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnorma lities. The cranial nerves are intact. Muscle strength is normal in all extremities. Deep te ndon reflexes are 1 + in the right biceps muscle and 2+ elsewhere. Babinski sign is absent. Sensation to pinprick is decreased over the dorsal aspect of the right thumb and index finger. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's symptoms? A) Brachia! plexus compression G) Median nerve compress ion at the wrist B) Central nervous system compression H) Radial nerve compression at the elbow C) Central nervous system demyelination I) Radial nerve compression at the spiral groove D) Central nervous system ischemia J) Ulnar nerve compression at the elbow E) Cervical nerve root compression K) Ulnar nerve compression at the wrist F) Median nerve compress ion at the elbow Correct Answer: E. Cervical nerve root compression explains this patient's symptoms of cervical radiculopathy. Radiculopathy refers to pathology affecting a specific spinal nerve root that leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesias, and pain in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected root. C6 radiculopathy will result in pain that radiates from the neck into the arm along with decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in the lateral forearm and the lateral two digits. Additional ly, C6 radiculopathy causes motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension, and a diminished or absent biceps reflex. Radiculopathy symptoms may worsen with activities that increase pressure such as coughing and sneezing. Radiculopathy may be caused by spondylosis (degenerative changes of the spine), disc herniation, infection, tumor, demyelination, or infarction. Dermatomes and myotomes are components of the embryonic somite, a paired segment of paraxial mesoderm. When fully developed, the dermatome is an area of skin whose afferent fibers travel within a single spinal nerve, and myotome is a group of muscles innervated by the efferent fibers from a single spinal nerve. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, F, G, H, I, J, and K. Brachia! plexus compression (Choice A) typically presents with weakness, numbness, and/or paresthesias of the majority of the upper extremity. Brachia! plexus compression typical ly affects multiple nerve roots and motor dysfunction typically predominates over sensory dysfunction and pain early in the disease process. Central nervous system (CNS) compression (Choice B), demyelination (Choice C), or ischemia (Choice D) typically affects major central nervous system tracts, leading to sensory, motor, and/or autonomic dysfunction contralateral to the lesion. This patient instead demonstrates deficits that are localized to a single spinal nerve root Exam Section : Item 14 of 50 Clinical Cervical nerve root compression explains this patient's symptoms of cervical radiculopathy. Radiculopathy refers to pathology affecting a specific spinal nerve root that leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesias, and pain in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected root. C6 radiculopathy will result in pain that radiates from the neck into the arm along with decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in the lateral forearm and the lateral two digits. Additional ly, C6 radiculopathy causes motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension, and a diminished or absent biceps reflex. Radiculopathy symptoms may worsen with activities that increase pressure such as coughing and sneezing. Radiculopathy may be caused by spondylosis (degenerative changes of the spine), disc herniation, infection, tumor, demyelination, or infarction. Dermatomes and myotomes are components of the embryonic somite, a paired segment of paraxial mesoderm. When fully developed, the dermatome is an area of skin whose afferent fibers travel within a single spinal nerve, and myotome is a group of muscles innervated by the efferent fibers from a single spinal nerve. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, F, G, H, I, J, and K. Brachia! plexus compression (Choice A) typically presents with weakness, numbness, and/or paresthesias of the majority of the upper extremity. Brachia! plexus compression typically affects multiple nerve roots and motor dysfunction typically predominates over sensory dysfunction and pain early in the disease process. Central nervous system (CNS) compression (Choice B), demyelination (Choice C), or ischemia (Choice D) typically affects major central nervous system tracts, leading to sensory, motor, and/or autonomic dysfunction contralateral to the lesion. This patient instead demonstrates deficits that are localized to a single spina l nerve root. Median nerve compression at the elbow (Choice F) typically causes anterior interosseous syndrome, a pure motor neuropathy leading to a decreased ability to pinch the first two digits and form a fist. Median nerve compression at the wrist (Choice G) initially leads to pain and paresthesias in the first three digits and may progress to hand weakness, known as carpal tunnel syndrome. Radial nerve compression at the elbow (Choice H) presents primarily with pain of the elbow and dorsal forearm that may radiate to the dorsum of the fingers. Motor and sensory symptoms are less prominent. Radial nerve compression at the spiral groove (Choice I) results in extensor muscle dysfunction of the elbow, wrist, and fingers. Numbness, pain, and/or paresthesias from the triceps to the fingers may occur. The triceps reflex, not the biceps reflex, would be affected. While ulnar nerve compression at the elbow (Choice J) typically results in numbness and paresthesias of the medial hand and wrist, ulnar nerve compression at the wrist (Choice K) typically leads to weakness of the intrinsic hand muscles and the consequent loss of hand dexterity. Patients may demonstrate a decreased ability to abduct and adduct the digits. Educationa l Objective: Radiculopathy refers to pathology affecting a specific spinal nerve root that leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesias, and pain in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected root. C6 radiculopathy will cause decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in the lateral forearm and the lateral two digits. Additionally, C6 radiculopathy causes motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension, along with an absent biceps reflex Clinical "t 15. A 67-year-old man with hypertension is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a stroke. Examination shows Horner syndrome and paralysis of the palate on the right. Sensation is decreased to pain over the right side of the face and left side of the body, and sensation is absent to hot and cold over the right face and left side of the body. There is no paralysis of the extremities. Which of the following is the most likely site of infarction? A) Right brachium pontis B) Right lateral medulla C) Right midbrain D) Right temporal lobe E) Right thalamus Correct Answer: B. Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome is caused by occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery, leading to an ischemic stroke of the lateral medulla. Five main structures are affected, which include the nucleus ambiguus, vestibular nuclei, lateral spinothalamic tract, spinal trigeminal nucleus, sympathetic fibers, and inferior cerebellar peduncle. Loss of the nucleus ambiguus leads to dysphagia, a decreased gag reflex, and hoarseness. The vestibular nucleus loss causes vomiting, vertigo, and nystagmus. The contralateral body and ipsilateral face will develop decreased pain and temperature sensation from involvement of the lateral spinothalamic tract. Horner syndrome may result if the sympathetic fibers are damaged. Additiona lly, ataxia and dysmetria from the involvement of the cerebellar peduncles will also be present. However, a patient with lateral medullary syndrome may not necessarily demonstrate all of these findings in equal proportion, as in this case. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, and E. The brachium pontis (Choice A), or middle cerebellar peduncles projecting from the pons, may be affected by ischemic events involving the anterior inferior cerebellar artery. Similar to lateral medullary syndrome, symptoms of an infarct involving the brachium pontis include ataxia and dysmetria, which are absent in this case. Infarction of the midbrain (Choice C) occurs when the basilar artery becomes occluded. This would impact the oculomotor and trochlear nerves. This patient does not demonstrate any eye movement impairment. Infarction of the right temporal lobe (Choice D), depending on the side of the patient's dominant hemisphere, may impact regions such as the Wernicke area of speech and Meyer loop of the visual pathway. As well, it may impact the primary auditory cortex, resulting in varying degrees of hearing impairment depending on the extent of infarction. Infarction of the right thalamus (Choice E) may develop from occlusion of one of four different arteries, the tuberothalamic artery, paramedian artery, inferolateral artery, or posterior choroidal artery. Symptoms include a combination of dysphagia, decreased gag reflex, hoarseness, vertigo, nystagmus, decreased pain and temperature sensation on the ipsilateral face and contralatera l body, Horner syndrome, ataxia, and dysmetria. ., Exam Section : Item 16 of 50 Clinical A 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of a 4-hour history of unsteady gait and two episodes of vomiting. Three weeks ago, she had an upper respiratory tract infection that did not require treatment. There is no history of trauma or evidence of toxic ingestion. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 36. 7°C (98°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Examination shows slight horizontal nystagmus. Funduscopic examination shows no abnorma lities. The patient is able to sit without support but is unable to walk without support. Deep tendon reflexes are normal, and sensation is intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A) Re-examination in 24 hours B) Complete blood count C) CT scan of the head D) EEG E) Lumbar puncture Correct Answer: C. The patient is showing signs and symptoms concerning for cerebellar ataxia, including gait disturbance and nystagmus. Other associated findings may include dysarthria, speech abnormalities, impaired coordination, vomiting, and headache. Patients typically do not present with a fever, meningismus, or seizures. Acute cerebellar ataxia usually occurs following an acute febrile illness in children under 6 years of age. In the setting of an acute presentation with neurologic deficits, CT scan of the head is effective to evaluate for acute intracranial hemorrhage, tumor, or hydrocephalus that may require emergent management. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E. Re-examination in 24 hours (Choice A) would not be appropriate, as the patient is showing concerning neurologic findings that should be evaluated urgently. Complete blood count (Choice B) could be helpful in evaluating for infection or anemia, neither of which would be the likely cause of the patient's cerebellar neurologic symptoms. An EEG (Choice D) would be helpful in evaluating seizures, which are typically characterized by involuntary rhythmic movements, lapse of consciousness, a posticta l state, and may be accompanied by tongue biting and/or incontinence. This patient's symptoms are taking place while she is awake, alert, and following commands, making seizures unlikely. A lumbar puncture (Choice E) would be the test of choice to evaluate for meningitis. Meningitis is characterized by fever, neck rigidity, and headache. While meningitis can cause focal neurologic deficits, they are typically cranial nerve abnormalities. In addition, this patient is not showing associated signs of meningitis. r ~, - . r,

vignette.presentation:
13. A 77-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because he has become increasingly forgetful during the past 6 months. His
daughter states that his short-term memory is quite impaired, and he says that he is frustrated with his memory. He lives alone and is able to
perform activities of daily living independently. On questioning, he reports a 1-month history of a mild nonproductive cough, constipation, mild pain
in his hips with movement, mild numbness of the toes of both feet, and a few episodes of urinary incontinence. He has hypertension,
hyperlipidemia, and well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. His wife
died 6 years ago. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood
pressure is 128/72 mm Hg. Muscle strength is normal. Cranial nerves are intact. Deep tendon reflexes are normal. Sensation to vibration is mildly
decreased over the distal lower extremities. Proprioception is intact. His gait is wide based, and he has impaired tandem walking. His Mini-Mental
State Examination score is 24/30; he recalls one of three objects after 5 minutes. An MRI of the brain shows slightly enlarged ventricles with
minimal cortical atrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Recommendation that the patient move to an assisted living community

17. A 37-year-old woman with a 10-year history of HIV infection comes to the physician because of headache and fever for 2 days. Her temperature is
38.9°C (102°F). Examination shows confusion and mild weakness of the left upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are increased, and
Babinski sign is present on the left. Her CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 4/mm3 (Normal~500), and plasma HIV viral load is 60,000 copies/ml. Which
of the following is the most likely finding on MRI of the brain?

question_stem: the most likely finding on MRI of the brain?

choices.text: Diffuse leukoaraiosis with periventricular white matter changes
Markedly enlarged sulci with generalized loss of brain matter
Markedly enlarged ventricles with minimal changes in sulci
Mass lesion within the substance of the right frontal cortex with shift to the left of midline structures
Opaque mass over convexity of left frontal cortex with compress ion of brain substance

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Toxop/asma gondii is an intracellular protozoan parasite. Transmission can occur through the ingestion of oocysts from cat feces or infected meat, direct transmission between a mother and fetus, or from organ transplantation, which leads to invasion followed by dissemination of the parasite where it typically lies dormant. It is a ubiquitous organism and nearly 10% of individuals will be seropositive for T gondii, but the parasite does not usually cause severe disease in immunocompetent individuals. In patients with HIV infection and CD4+ cell counts less than 100 cells/mm 3, however, reactivation can occur with several distinct clinical syndromes of which cerebral toxoplasmosis results in the most morbidity. Cerebral toxoplasmosis typically presents with multiple ring-enhancing lesions within the substance of the cerebral cortex, most commonly the frontal and parietal lobes, although single lesions can occur. It is commonly associated with cerebral edema, which may result in mass effect and shifting of adjacent structures. Seizures, focal neurologic deficits, and systemic symptoms are common, as are signs of increased intracranial pressure. Patients with HIV and positive toxoplasma lgG antibodies are typically treated empirically with a sulfonamide and pyrimethamine if cerebral toxoplasmosis is suspected. If necessary, the confirmatory diagnosis occurs through a brain biopsy, which will demonstrate a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells, along with the presence of the T gondii organisms. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an AIDS defining disease.

It is associated with chronic vascular pathology, such as hypertension, diabetes, and vascular dementia. Markedly enlarged sulci with generalized loss of brain matter (Choice B) occurs in cerebral atrophy associated with age, dementia, and alcohol use disorder. Markedly enlarged ventricles with minimal changes in sulci (Choice C) is seen in normal pressure hydrocephalus, which classically presents with dementia, urinary incontinence, and ataxia. These symptoms do not describe this patient's clinical presentation. An opaque mass over convexity of left frontal cortex with compression of brain substance (Choice E) describes a meningioma, which is a benign brain tumor that develops from the meninges. Symptoms are dependent on the location of the tumor, and patients are often asymptomatic. Common presenting symptoms include seizures, vision changes, altered mental status, and focal neurologic deficits. However, it does not cause a fever, as seen in this patient.

explanation.educational_objective: Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxop/asma gondii, an intracellular protozoan parasite that is most commonly transmitted via ingestion of cat feces or infected meat. In immunocompromised patients, particularly AIDS patients with CD4+ T lymphocyte counts less than 100 cells/mm 3, it can cause cerebral toxoplasmosis, which presents with seizures, focal neurologic deficits, systemic symptoms, and increased intracranial pressure. Neuroimaging will show one or more ring-enhancing lesions within the cerebral cortex, and empiric treatment is with pyrimethamine and sulfonamide therapy Exam Section : Item 18 of 50 Clinical "t 18. An 87-year-old man comes to the physician because of headaches over the past 6 weeks; they fluctuate in severity during the day and occasionally awaken him from sleep. He describes the pain as an aching pressure that is worse in the front. His vision is unchanged. He takes aspirin for cervical osteoarthr itis. His son died 3 months ago. He is lethargic and yawns during the interview. His temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 88/min and regular, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Funduscopic examination shows cataracts. There is moderate stiffness of the neck with flexion and when the head is turned to the left and right. There is a pronator drift of the right upper extremity. Reflexes are 3+ at the biceps and triceps muscles and knees and 1+ at the ankles. Babinski sign is present bilaterally. He has a slow unsteady gait with short steps. No other abnormalities are noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Craniopharyngioma B) Hypertensive encephalopathy C) Major depressive disorder D) Migraine E) Subdural hematoma F) Temporal arteritis Correct Answer: E. Head trauma, the use of anticoagulants, physical abuse, alcohol use disorder, cerebral atrophy, and malignancy are associated with an increased risk for developing a subdural hematoma (SDH). Elderly patients are at risk for cerebral atrophy, which places traction on dural bridging cortical veins. In this setting, minor trauma such as falls can result in shearing of the veins leading to hemorrhage. In some cases, patients may not report a history of trauma. Patients may present with headaches, vomiting, meningismus, or hemiparesis, or they may manifest upper motoneuron examination findings such as spasticity, hyperreflexia, and extensor plantar reflex (Babinski sign). In some cases, the SDH may be large enough to compress adjacent brain parenchyma; the displacement of the cerebral hemisphere can result in neurologic deficits, altered mental status, seizures, herniation syndromes, and signs of increased intracranial pressure. On imaging, SDH appears as a crescent-shaped fluid collection abutting the internal surface of the skull, not bound by suture lines. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, and F. Craniopharyngioma (Choice A) is a rare pituitary mass derived from remnants of the Rathke pouch that may present with bitemporal hemianopsia. It is usually detected in youth. Hypertensive encephalopathy (Choice B) may result from acute and severe increases in blood pressure and may manifest with headache, vomiting, agitation, altered mental status, and seizure. It may progress to obtundation and coma. This patient's blood pressure is mildly increased but not severe enough to cause hypertensive encephalopathy Exam Section : Item 18 of 50 Clinical Please Walt 1graine E) Subdural hematoma F) Temporal arteritis Correct Answer: E. Elderly patients are at risk for cerebral atrophy, which places traction on dural bridging cortical veins. In some cases, the SDH may be large enough to compress adjacent brain parenchyma; the displacement of the cerebral hemisphere can result in neurologic deficits, altered mental status, seizures, herniation syndromes, and signs of increased intracranial pressure. On imaging, SDH appears as a crescent-shaped fluid collection abutting the internal surface of the skull, not bound by suture lines. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, and F. Craniopharyngioma (Choice A) is a rare pituitary mass derived from remnants of the Rathke pouch that may present with bitemporal hemianopsia. It is usually detected in youth. Hypertensive encephalopathy (Choice B) may result from acute and severe increases in blood pressure and may manifest with headache, vomiting, agitation, altered mental status, and seizure. It may progress to obtundation and coma. This patient's blood pressure is mildly increased but not severe enough to cause hypertensive encephalopathy. Major depressive disorder (Choice C) may cause cognitive impairment in older patients, which can improve with antidepressant treatment. It would not cause foca l neurologic deficits or upper motoneuron signs. Migraine (Choice D) is a type of primary headache that usually does not typically cause neurologic deficits and would be unlikely to cause altered mental status or upper motoneuron signs. Temporal arteritis (Choice F) is a common vasculitis of medium and large vessels in elderly patients and commonly presents with systemic symptoms, headache, jaw claudication, proximal muscle stiffness, and sudden, irreversible vision loss. Treatment is with immediate, high-dose corticosteroids. Educational Objective: Elderly patients are at risk for cerebral atrophy, which causes traction on dural bridging cortical veins such that minor trauma can result in venous injury leading to a subdural hematoma Exam Section : Item 19 of 50 Clinical "t 19. A 67-year-o ld woman is brought to the physician because of progressive imbalance and memory difficulties over the past year. Two years ago, she began to have episodes of sudden imbalance with a tendency to fall backwards. She has developed progressive slowness of thought and movement and has had brief episodes of double vision. Examination shows mildly decreased short-term memory and slowness of verbal responses. Downward gaze and upward gaze are markedly impaired. There is marked rigidity of the neck and mild rigidity of the limbs. The gait is broad based with short shuffling steps, and she easily loses her balance, falling backwards. All movements are performed slowly. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows moderate, diffuse atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Creutzfe ldt-Jakob disease B) Dementia, Alzheimer type C) Hydrocep halus D) Hypothyroidism E) Multi-infarct (vascular) dementia F) Parkinson disease with dementia G) Progressive supranuclear palsy; H) Syphilis I) Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome Correct Answer: G. Progressive supranuclear palsy, an atypical parkinsonian disorder, is a neurodegenerative disease associated with tau-positive neurofibri llary tangles in the basal ganglia, cortex, and brainstem. Patients typically present at an average age of 65 years with gait instability, oculomotor deficits (classically vertical gaze palsy), frontal lobe deficits, bradykinesia, and muscle rigidity. The gait pattern varies in step length and base width, though patients typically walk and pivot too quickly (as a result of impulsivity from frontal lobe damage), leading to backward falls. Definitive diagnosis occurs by neuropathologic examination illustrating a pattern of neurofibrillary tangles in the characteristic distribution. Neuroimaging illustrating midbrain and/or cerebral cortex atrophy supports the diagnosis. Death typically occurs 6 to 9 years after disease onset. Management is supportive and includes physical and occupational therapy along with advanced care planning. Incorrect Answer: A, B, C, D, E, F, H, and I. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (Choice A) is a human prion disease that presents with rapidly progressing dementia, neuropsychiatric symptoms, cerebellar dysfunction, corticospinal tract dysfunction, basal ganglia dysfunction, and stimulus-induced myoclonus. Vertical gaze palsy would be atypical. r ~•-··-·, - ! ·- ··- ·- •• - : ·- •••• - - -· •••••• - • - -· ••••••• - - ••• - ·- ·-r•- ,•• •- - •

distractor_explanations.A: Jakob disease is a human prion disease that presents with rapidly progressing dementia, neuropsychiatric symptoms, cerebellar dysfunction, corticospinal tract dysfunction, basal ganglia dysfunction, and stimulus-induced myoclonus. Vertical gaze palsy would be atypical. r ~•-··-·, - ! ·- ··- ·- •• - : ·- •••• - - -· •••••• - • - -· ••••••• - - ••• - ·- ·-r•- ,•• •- - • Exam Section : Item 19 of 50 Clinical Correct Answer: G. Progressive supranuclear palsy, an atypical parkinsonian disorder, is a neurodegenerative disease associated with tau-positive neurofibrillary tangles in the basal ganglia, cortex, and brainstem. Patients typically present at an average age of 65 years with gait instability, oculomotor deficits (classically vertical gaze palsy), frontal lobe deficits, bradykinesia, and muscle rigidity. The gait pattern varies in step length and base width, though patients typically walk and pivot too quickly (as a result of impulsivity from frontal lobe damage), leading to backward falls. Definitive diagnosis occurs by neuropathologic examination illustrating a pattern of neurofibrillary tangles in the characteristic distribution. Neuroimaging illustrating midbrain and/or cerebral cortex atrophy supports the diagnosis. Death typically occurs 6 to 9 years after disease onset. Management is supportive and includes physical and occupational therapy along with advanced care planning. Incorrect Answer: A, B, C, D, E, F, H, and I. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (Choice A) is a human prion disease that presents with rapidly progressing dementia, neuropsychiatric symptoms, cerebellar dysfunction, corticospinal tract dysfunction, basal ganglia dysfunction, and stimulus-induced myoclonus. Vertical gaze palsy would be atypical. Dementia, Alzheimer type (Choice B) is the most prevalent dementia, presenting with progressive cognitive decline that culminates in the inability to perform basic activities of daily living. Vertical gaze palsy, bradykinesia, and muscle rigidity would be atypical.
distractor_explanations.C: Hydrocephalus may present acutely with signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, positional headache, papilledema, nausea, vomiting). This patient's chronic progressive course and lack of ventriculomegaly on MRI are inconsistent with hydrocephalus.
distractor_explanations.D: Hypothyroidism is associated with mood changes but does not lead to focal neurologic deficits. Multi-infarct (vascular) dementia (Choice E) refers to cognitive impairment caused by cerebrovascular disease. Patients typically demonstrate stepwise, not progressive, focal neurologic deficits and functional decline. MRI of the brain usually demonstrates multiple infarcts. Parkinson disease with dementia (Choice F) presents with dysfunction of voluntary movements in the form of bradykinesia, resting tremor, rigidity, and postural instability. Dementia may occur late in the disease course. Vertical gaze palsy would be atypical, and the gait pattern is typically narrow based.
distractor_explanations.H: Neurosyphilis typically presents with a progressive dementia or tabes dorsalis (disease of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord). Vertical gaze palsy, muscle rigidity, and bradykinesia would be atypical. Patients may demonstrate a tabetic gait (a wide-based, purposeful gait). Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome (Choice I), caused by thiamine deficiency, most often in association with chronic alcohol abuse, is characterized by altered mental status, ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and retrograde and anterograde amnesia. A narrow-based gait and a purely vertical gaze palsy would be atypical, since ophthalmoplegia typically manifests as nystagmus or horizontal gaze palsy. Further, bradykinesia and muscle rigidity would be atypical. MRI of the brain would likely show focal atrophy (eg, mammillary bodies).

Patients typically present at an average age of 65 years with gait instability, oculomotor deficits (classically vertical gaze, palsy), frontal lobe deficits, bradykinesia, and muscle rigidity Clinical

vignette.presentation:
20. An 80 year old man briefly loses consciousness and falls to the floor in a grocery store. He awakens within 1 minute and feels dizzy, but after
several minutes the dizziness passes. His pulse is 80/min; his blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg while supine and 150/86 mm Hg while standing.
Cardiac examination and ECG show no abnormalities. During the physical examination , when his head is turned to the right, he suddenly loses
consciousness and motor tone. While unconscious, his pulse is 40/min. He awakens within 20 seconds and feels slightly dazed, but this feeling
passes after 1 minute. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Carotid sinus hypersensitivity syndrome is characterized by an exaggerated response to carotid baroreceptor stimulation, presenting with resultant sinus bradycardia, hypotension, and syncope. Baroreceptors located at the carotid bifurcations and the aortic arch are important in regulating cardiac output and maintaining adequate perfusion pressures to the brain and organs of the upper body. Baroreceptors are sensitive to mechanical pressure; normally, an increase in blood pressure stimulates baroreceptor activity, which activates a reflex arc resulting in parasympathetic innervation of the sinoatrial and atrioventricular nodes, and inhibition of sympathetic vascular tone. This results in a decreased heart rate and periphera l vascular resistance and may result in syncope, especially in older adults. In carotid sinus hypersensitivity syndrome, this response may be triggered by mechanical compression of the carotid sinus from external palpation or with movement of the muscles of the neck. Cardiac examination and diagnostic studies are often unrevealing.

distractor_explanations.C: Idiopathic orthostatic hypotension is unlikely to explain this patient's symptoms given normal orthostatic vital signs on examination. Orthostatic hypotension is characterized by tachycardia in response to the decreased preload, rather than bradycardia as observed in this patient. Vasodepressor syncope (Choice D), also called vasovagal syncope, is common and results from an acute decrease in peripheral vascular resistance with an inadequate responsive increase in cardiac output to maintain perfusion pressure to the brain. Common triggers include standing for long periods of time, heat, and intense emotion or pain. In this case, the onset of symptoms when the patient's head is turned to the right raises concern for carotid sinus hypersensitivity Clinical Correct Answer: A. Carotid sinus hypersensitivity syndrome is characterized by an exaggerated response to carotid baroreceptor stimulation, presenting with resultant sinus bradycardia, hypotension, and syncope. Baroreceptors located at the carotid bifurcations and the aortic arch are important in regulating cardiac output and maintaining adequate perfusion pressures to the brain and organs of the upper body. Baroreceptors are sensitive to mechanical pressure; normally, an increase in blood pressure stimulates baroreceptor activity, which activates a reflex arc resulting in parasympathetic innervation of the sinoatrial and atrioventricu lar nodes, and inhibition of sympathetic vascular tone. This results in a decreased heart rate and periphera l vascular resistance and may result in syncope, especially in older adults. In carotid sinus hypersensitivity syndrome, this response may be triggered by mechanical compression of the carotid sinus from external palpation or with movement of the muscles of the neck. Cardiac examination and diagnostic studies are often unrevealing. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E. Complex partial seizure disorder (Choice B), also called focal onset impaired awareness seizures, is characterized by localized motor or sensory symptoms associated with loss of awareness during episodes. Generalized loss of motor tone and bradycardia are more suggestive of carotid sinus hypersensitivity. Idiopathic orthostatic hypotension (Choice C) is unlikely to explain this patient's symptoms given normal orthostatic vital signs on examination. Orthostatic hypotension is characterized by tachycardia in response to the decreased preload, rather than bradycardia as observed in this patient. Vasodepressor syncope (Choice D), also called vasovagal syncope, is common and results from an acute decrease in peripheral vascular resistance with an inadequate responsive increase in cardiac output to maintain perfusion pressure to the brain. Common triggers include standing for long periods of time, heat, and intense emotion or pain. In this case, the onset of symptoms when the patient's head is turned to the right raises concern for carotid sinus hypersensitivity. Vertebrobasilar insufficiency (Choice E) describes inadequate perfusion of the posterior cerebral circulation and may present with vertigo, light-headedness, disequilibrium, ataxia, and nystagmus (caused by transiently decreased blood supply to the vestibular nuclei). It is most commonly caused by atherosclerosis and may be provoked by prolonged neck extension. This patient does not demonstrate vestibular symptoms.

explanation.educational_objective: Baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch detect changes in mean arterial pressure to appropriate ly regulate perfusion pressures to the brain and body organs. Carotid sinus hypersensitivity can result in the abnormal provocation of this reflex arc, causing sinus bradycardia and syncope. ., Exam Section : Item 21 of 50 Clinical
