vignette.presentation:
21. An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a 5-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure. She has a 1-year
history of sudden jerking movements of her hands and arms; the episodes frequently occur while she is getting ready for work in the morning. On
arrival, she is confused but gradually becomes oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 80/min,
respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 114/68 mm Hg. On examinat ion, ocular movements are full. The remainder of the examination
shows no abnormalities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ throughout. In addition to valproic acid therapy, supplementation with which of the following
is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Supplementation with folic acid should be prescribed in all women of child-bearing age taking anti-epileptic drugs, particularly valproic acid. Valproic acid increases sodium channel inactivation and increases y-aminobutyric acid (GABA) concentration, leading to anti epileptic effects. However, it also increases the risk for neural tube defects by twenty-fold when taken during the first trimester of pregnancy. Supplementation of folic acid prior to conception is effective in lowering the risk of neural tube defects. Patients without other risk factors can take the standard dose of folic acid, 0.4 mg daily, while patients on anti-epileptics other than valproic acid should take 1 mg daily, and patients on valproic acid should take 4 mg daily. Valproic acid is also used to treat migraines and bipolar disorder, and the same folic acid supplementation should be recommended in those cases.

distractor_explanations.B: Riboflavin deficiency may cause cheilitis and corneal vascularization. It does not have a role in epilepsy management and is not needed in conjunction with valproic acid. Vitamin B (thiamine) (Choice C) deficiency causes variable manifestations including dry beriberi (peripheral neuropathy with mental 1 status change), wet beriberi (dilated cardiomyopathy leading to heart failure), and Wernicke encephalopathy (confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia). Since the patient does not demonstrate any of these findings, supplementation with thiamine is unnecessary. Vitamin B (pyridoxine) (Choice D) supplementation is needed in patients taking isoniazid. Without it, pyridoxine deficiency develops, 6 which is characterized by peripheral neuropathy, dermatitis, sideroblastic anemia, glossitis, and seizures. Vitamin D (Choice E) is a steroid hormone involved in calcium and phosphorus homeostasis, and bone mineral density maintenance. Vitamin D supplementation is needed in patients using chronic glucocorticoids, which may lead to decreased bone mineral density. Vitamin E (Choice F) is an antioxidant that protects cells from free radical damage. Deficiency may present with hemolytic anemia and generalized muscle weakness. Its supplementation is not needed in patients taking valproic acid.

explanation.educational_objective: Valproic acid increases the risk of neural tube defects by twenty-fold when taken during the first trimester of pregnancy. All women of childbearing age on anti-epileptic medications, particular ly valproic acid, should take folic acid supplementation. ., Clinical

vignette.presentation:
22. A 67-year-old man with a 30-year history of alcoholism is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after he was found confused and lethargic
by his daughter. He appears malnourished and ill. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg.
Scattered rhonchi are heard. Abdominal examination shows no tenderness , a liver span of 18 cm, and a palpable spleen tip. Neurologic
examination shows a disconjugate gaze. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Vitamin B , or thiamine, deficiency causes two potential syndromes: Wernicke encephalopathy and Korsakoff dementia. The classic 1 triad of Wernicke encephalopathy demonstrates encephalopathy, ataxia, and oculomotor dysfunction. If Wernicke syndrome is allowed to progress without treatment, Korsakoff syndrome may develop, which is manifest by retrograde and anterograde amnesia, confabulation, and horizontal nystagmus. Wernicke encephalopathy develops in patients with extreme malnourishment and/or alcohol use disorder. While a serum thiamine concentration may be decreased, this is not useful in managing patients as it cannot be checked quickly. Thus, diagnosis is clinical and should be rapidly treated with intravenous thiamine administration.

distractor_explanations.A: Intensive physical therapy would not address the underlying diagnosis of Wernicke encephalopathy. Delayed diagnosis of this condition potentially leads to coma and death. Intravenous glucose therapy (Choice B) should not be administered until after thiamine has been given in the setting of Wernicke encephalopathy, since glucose alone can theoretical ly worsen symptoms. Once thiamine has been replenished, then intravenous glucose may be given. Intravenous vitamin B (cyanocoba lamin) therapy (Choice D) may be utilized in the treatment of megaloblastic anemia resulting from 12 vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency. This most commonly occurs in the context of vegan ism, pernicious anemia, and Crohn disease. It is 12 not necessary to supplement in the case of Wernicke encephalopathy. Oral lactulose therapy (Choice E) is the treatment of choice for hepatic encephalopathy. This is most commonly seen in patients with cirrhosis whose ability to process ammonia from the gastrointestina l tract is impaired. This patient's liver is enlarged, not cirrhotic on r ~ - - - - , " r, Clinical A . A--~ i . -~- · ••• I • C) Intravenous vitamin B (thiamine) therapy; 1 D) Intravenous vitamin B (cyanocobalam in) therapy 12 E) Oral lactulose therapy Correct Answer: C. Vitamin B , or thiamine, deficiency causes two potential syndromes: Wernicke encephalopathy and Korsakoff dementia. The classic 1 triad of Wernicke encephalopathy demonstrates encephalopathy, ataxia, and oculomotor dysfunction. If Wernicke syndrome is allowed to progress without treatment, Korsakoff syndrome may develop, which is manifest by retrograde and anterograde amnesia, confabulation, and horizontal nystagmus. Wernicke encephalopathy develops in patients with extreme malnourishment and/or alcohol use disorder. While a serum thiamine concentration may be decreased, this is not useful in managing patients as it cannot be checked quickly. Thus, diagnosis is clinical and should be rapidly treated with intravenous thiamine administration. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E. Intensive physical therapy (Choice A) would not address the underlying diagnosis of Wernicke encephalopathy. Delayed diagnosis of this condition potentially leads to coma and death. Intravenous glucose therapy (Choice B) should not be administered until after thiamine has been given in the setting of Wernicke encephalopathy, since glucose alone can theoretical ly worsen symptoms. Once thiamine has been replenished, then intravenous glucose may be given. Intravenous vitamin B (cyanocoba lamin) therapy (Choice D) may be utilized in the treatment of megaloblastic anemia resulting from 12 vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency. This most commonly occurs in the context of vegan ism, pernicious anemia, and Crohn disease. It is 12 not necessary to supplement in the case of Wernicke encephalopathy. Oral lactulose therapy (Choice E) is the treatment of choice for hepatic encephalopathy. This is most commonly seen in patients with cirrhosis whose ability to process ammonia from the gastrointestina l tract is impaired. This patient's liver is enlarged, not cirrhotic on physical examination. As well, disconjugate gaze would be absent in hepatic encephalopathy.

explanation.educational_objective: Vitamin B , or thiamine, deficiency causes Wernicke encephalopathy, characterized by encephalopathy, ataxia, 1 and oculomotor dysfunction. Diagnosis is clinical and should be rapidly treated with intravenous thiamine administration to avoid progression to Korsakoff syndrome. ., Clinical

vignette.presentation:
23. A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after an episode of flaccid paralysis and numbness of the left upper and lower
extremities that lasted 2 hours. During the episode, she was unable to see objects in her left visual field. Neurologic examination now shows no
abnormalities. A CT scan of the head shows no lesions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Rupture of a cerebral artery aneurysm

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is defined as a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction lasting less than 24 hours caused by focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischemia without evidence of infarction. This patient has developed focal neurologic deficits that resolved after 2 hours, qualifying as a TIA. TIA can be induced by either an embolus arising from a proximal site or from temporarily decreased blood flow to a watershed area in the brain. A hypotensive TIA typically lasts until resolution of the low-flow event while an embolic TIA lasts hours, as in this case. An embolic ischemic stroke involves an event in which a clot breaks off and travels to the brain, occluding blood flow within a cerebral artery. Emboli most commonly originate from proximal vessels, such as the internal carotid artery, or from an atrial thrombus. If the embolus successfully undergoes physiologic thrombolysis, blood flow is restored to the affected area and reverses the clinical symptoms. After a TIA, measures for prevention of an ischemic stroke should be enacted, along with evaluation for the potential source of embolus, such as carotid artery doppler and echocardiography.

distractor_explanations.A: Rupture of an arteriovenous malformation or cerebral artery aneurysm (Choice G) in the brain are causes of intracranial bleeding and hemorrhagic stroke. Hemorrhage is not a typical cause of TIA and is less likely to be transient. lntracranial neoplasms, including cerebellar glioma (Choice B), frontal lobe meningioma (Choice D), and temporal lobe astrocytoma (Choice H) may cause focal neurologic deficits such as ataxia and dysmetria, social disinhibition, or motor and sensory impairment, respectively, because of mass effect. However, these effects are not transient ···- Clinical - - -, .,_ .,, H) Temporal lobe astrocytoma Correct Answer: C. Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is defined as a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction lasting less than 24 hours caused by focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischemia without evidence of infarction. This patient has developed focal neurologic deficits that resolved after 2 hours, qualifying as a TIA. TIA can be induced by either an embolus arising from a proximal site or from temporarily decreased blood flow to a watershed area in the brain. A hypotensive TIA typically lasts until resolution of the low-flow event while an embolic TIA lasts hours, as in this case. An embolic ischemic stroke involves an event in which a clot breaks off and travels to the brain, occluding blood flow within a cerebral artery. Emboli most commonly originate from proximal vessels, such as the internal carotid artery, or from an atrial thrombus. If the embolus successfully undergoes physiologic thrombolysis, blood flow is restored to the affected area and reverses the clinical symptoms. After a TIA, measures for prevention of an ischemic stroke should be enacted, along with evaluation for the potential source of embolus, such as carotid artery doppler and echocardiography. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, E, F, G, and H. Rupture of an arteriovenous malformation (Choice A) or cerebral artery aneurysm (Choice G) in the brain are causes of intracranial bleeding and hemorrhagic stroke. Hemorrhage is not a typical cause of TIA and is less likely to be transient. lntracranial neoplasms, including cerebellar glioma (Choice B), frontal lobe meningioma (Choice D), and temporal lobe astrocytoma (Choice H) may cause focal neurologic deficits such as ataxia and dysmetria, social disinhibition, or motor and sensory impairment, respectively, because of mass effect. However, these effects are not transient. Lacunar infarct (Choice E) causes ischemia to the deep cerebral white matter, pons, or basal ganglia, which is not transient. A lacunar stroke may present with purely motor symptoms, purely sensory symptoms, ataxic hemiparesis, or dysarthria. Occlusion of these deep penetrating vessels is typically secondary to hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia.
distractor_explanations.F: Migraine presents with recurrent primary headaches that are typically severe, unilateral, throbbing, and associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia. Migraines m1ay present with visual aura symptoms of scintillating scotoma or fortification spectra but do not generally cause loss of visual acuity. A sensory aura is sometimes seen, but flaccid paralysis of the entire left side is more consistent with an ischemic event instead.

explanation.educational_objective: TIA is defined as a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction lasting less than 24 hours caused by focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischemia without evidence of infarction. TIA is most commonly induced by a cerebral embolic event. ., Clinical

vignette.presentation:
24. A 25-year-old farm worker is brought to the emergency department because of the sudden onset of headache, dizziness, nausea, and vomiting
while picking peaches. His pulse is 52/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. He has generalized weakness, diaphoresis, and pinpoint pupils.
Which of the following precautions should medical professiona ls take while caring for this patient?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Organophosphates are commonly found in insecticides and exposure to them can occur transcutaneously, or via inhalation or ingestion. Organophosphates bind to and are inhibitors of acetylcholinesterase, preventing the breakdown of acetylcholine (ACh), which leads to excess concentrations of ACh in the neuromuscular junction. ACh acts on both nicotinic and muscarinic ACh receptors. Nicotinic ACh receptors are found in autonomic ganglia, adrenal medulla, and skeletal muscle, whereas muscarinic ACh receptors are found in heart, brain, smooth muscle, exocrine glands, and sweat glands. Resultant cholinergic excess leads to bronchospasm, bronchorrhea, bradycardia, diarrhea, lacrimation, and salivation. Because of the potential for organophosphate toxicity via transcutaneous exposure, medical professionals should always wear rubber gloves when treating the patient. Treatment involves decontamination of the patient, along with atropine to antagonize the muscarinic receptors, and 2-pralidoxime to regenerate functional acetylcholinesterase.

distractor_explanations.A: thus wearing protective goggles or wearing a surgical mask (Choice C) would not be as protective as wearing gloves. This patient was likely transcutaneously exposed to organophosphates while picking peaches, so wearing protective rubber gloves is a priority. Wearing no protective equipment (Choice D) would not be advised, since medical professionals treating the patient could inadvertently be exposed to organophosphates by touching the patient.

explanation.educational_objective: Organophosphates are commonly found in insecticides and exposure to them can occur transcutaneously, or via inhalation or ingestion. Because of the potential for organophosphate toxicity via transcutaneous exposure, medical professionals should always wear rubber gloves when treating the patient Clinical

vignette.presentation:
25. A 62-year-o ld man with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive shortness of breath. The
shortness of breath is exacerbated when he is supine. His only medication is an 81-mg aspirin tablet daily. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes
daily for 30 years but stopped 10 years ago. His pulse is 76/min and regular, respirations are 18/min while sitting and 26/min while supine, and
blood pressure is 112/78 mm Hg. There is no jugular venous distention. Scattered rhonchi are heard on auscultation; they resolve with coughing.
An S is heard. Abdom inal examination shows retractio ns of the abdom inal walls with inspiration. There is no peripheral edema. Which of the
4
following is the most likely cause of his shortness of breath?

question_stem: the most likely cause of his shortness of breath?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder arising in midlife that affects both lower motoneurons arising from the anterior horn and upper motoneurons of the lateral corticospina l tract within the brain and spinal cord. Neurons degenerate as the result of an unknown cause that may involve RNA processing and/or excitotoxicity. Patient presentations are variable, though typically feature a combination of upper motoneuron (eg, increased muscle tone, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign) and lower motoneuron findings (eg, decreased muscle tone, hyporeflexia, early muscle atrophy) in an asymmetric distribution that may include the bulbar muscles. Some patients may experience cognitive or behavioral changes, though other patients are cognitively normal. The diagnosis is primarily clinical but may be supported by electromyographic findings of acute and chronic denervation. ALS is a progressive disease with death usually occurring within 3 to 5 years of diagnosis, most commonly secondary to neuromuscular respiratory failure. This patient's dyspnea with lying supine is most likely secondary to diaphragmatic paralysis caused by his ALS. Symptoms of diaphragmatic paralysis worsen in the supine position, as gravity no longer assists in contracting and moving the diaphragm downward.

distractor_explanations.A: Bronchospasm occurs most commonly in the setting of reactive airway disease, such as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. It typically presents with shortness of breath and wheezing on auscultation that is not position-dependent. While this patient may have some degree of reactive airway disease secondary to his significant smoking history, his symptoms are more consistent with diaphragmatic paralysis. Failure of the intercostal muscles (Choice C) may also occur in the late stages of ALS or in other neuromuscular diseases. lntercostal muscle weakness can lead to dyspnea, given their role in chest expansion, but this shortness of breath would not be dependent on positioning. Left ventricular failure (Choice D) can cause shortness of breath secondary to pulmonary edema and is commonly associated with lower extremity edema, weight gain, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, rales on lung auscultation, and increased jugular venous pressure. This patient has no signs of heart failure, and his shortness of breath with lying supine is more consistent with diaphragmatic paralysis. Panacinar emphysema (Choice E) more commonly presents with exertional dyspnea, chronic cough, and sputum production. Dyspnea is not typically exacerbated in the supine position. Pleural effusions (Choice F) can potentially cause dyspnea with supine positioning and are common in congestive heart failure. However, they would be associated with diminished breath sounds on auscultation, not rhonchi as in this patient.

explanation.educational_objective: ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that affects both lower and upper motoneurons. Death typically occurs secondary to neuromuscular respiratory failure, with diaphragmatic paralysis presenting with dyspnea that is worse in the supine position Clinical
explanation.concept: ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that affects both lower and upper motoneurons. Death typically occurs secondary to neuromuscular respiratory failure, with diaphragmatic paralysis prese

vignette.presentation:
26. A 14-month-old infant is brought to the physician because of four episodes of loss of consciousness over the past month. While in the office, the
infant has a typical episode. Prior to onset, the infant became fretful when his pacifier was taken away. He cried for 30 seconds, then stopped
crying and breathing and became rigid and cyanotic. There are no clonic movements and no response to noxious stimuli. His eyes deviate upward
conjugately; the pupils do not respond to direct or consensual light. Faint heart sounds are heard on apical auscultation; a pulse cannot be located.
He recovers without intervention and returns to normal behavior within 10 minutes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Syncope triggered by emotional distress in this infant was likely caused by a breath-holding episode. Breath-holding episodes are common paroxysmal events that occur between ages 6 months and 6 years and are typically triggered by stress-induced autonomic dysfunction in the form of transient profound bradycardia. The typical sequence of events is crying, followed by breath holding in forced expiration and cyanosis, then muscle rigidity and shaking, and finally atonia and loss of consciousness. The eyes may deviate upward, and the pupils may dilate. Episodes may recur several times (weekly on average). Physicians should assess patients for iron deficiency anemia, which is commonly associated with breath-holding episodes, and treat with iron if deficient. Breath-holding episodes typically remit spontaneously.

distractor_explanations.A: Absence seizures are generalized seizures that cause transient staring episodes with intact consciousness after the seizure. This patient transiently lost consciousness (did not respond to noxious stimuli), and the characteristic sequence of events for a breath holding episode would be atypical for an absence seizure. No medications (Choice B) are known to cause breath-holding episodes. Carotid artery trauma (Choice D) may lead to carotid artery dissection and ischemic stroke. However, this patient does not demonstrate persistent neurologic deficits consistent with a stroke. Nor does he present symptoms of carotid sinus syncope which results from pressure against the carotid sinus baroreceptors Clinical F) Ventricular tachyarrhythmia Correct Answer: C. Syncope triggered by emotional distress in this infant was likely caused by a breath-holding episode. The typical sequence of events is crying, followed by breath holding in forced expiration and cyanosis, then muscle rigidity and shaking, and finally atonia and loss of consciousness. The eyes may deviate upward, and the pupils may dilate. Episodes may recur several times (weekly on average). Physicians should assess patients for iron deficiency anemia, which is commonly associated with breath-holding episodes, and treat with iron if deficient. Breath-holding episodes typically remit spontaneously. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, E, and F. Absence seizures (Choice A) are generalized seizures that cause transient staring episodes with intact consciousness after the seizure. This patient transiently lost consciousness (did not respond to noxious stimuli), and the characteristic sequence of events for a breath holding episode would be atypical for an absence seizure. No medications (Choice B) are known to cause breath-holding episodes. Carotid artery trauma (Choice D) may lead to carotid artery dissection and ischemic stroke. However, this patient does not demonstrate persistent neurologic deficits consistent with a stroke. Nor does he present symptoms of carotid sinus syncope which results from pressure against the carotid sinus baroreceptors. Narcolepsy-cataplexy (Choice E) is a chronic sleep disorder characterized by daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, and sleep paralysis. Cataplexy refers to a sudden loss of muscle tone and usually occurs in response to a positive emotion. Cyanosis would be atypical for cataplexy, and narcolepsy-cataplexy does not typically occur in infants. Ventricular tachyarrhythmia (Choice F) may rarely lead to syncope in children. Breath-holding episodes are much more common and are consistent with this patient's self-resolving, stress-triggered episode.

explanation.educational_objective: Breath-holding episodes are common paroxysmal events in infants and toddlers typically arising from stress induced autonomic dysfunction. Patients typically present with breath holding in forced expiration, acute cyanosis, muscle shaking and atonia, and loss of consciousness, which occur after crying. ., Clinical

vignette.presentation:
27. A 22-year-o ld woman comes to the physician because she has had a black spot that occludes her vision in her right eye fo r 1 day. She also has
pain in the right eye. There is no history of trauma. Exam ination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye; the best corrected vision in the right
eye is 20/200. The left pupil is normal; the right reacts sluggish ly to direct light but consensua lly. Funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities.
The eyes are not injected . Which of the following is the most likely site of the lesion?

question_stem: the most likely site of the lesion?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Optic neuritis results from autoimmune demyelinating inflammation of the optic nerve (crania l nerve II) and presents in young, often female, patients with unilatera l vision loss and pain that is exacerbated with extraocular movements. Ocular examination demonstrates decreased visual acuity and color vision, a relative afferent pupillary defect (rAPD), and possibly optic disc edema. Diagnosis is confirmed with MRI demonstrating hyperintensity of the optic nerve. Patients with optic neuritis are at an increased risk for multiple sclerosis (MS), and optic neuritis is a common initial finding in patients with MS. Recently, autoantibodies against myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG) and aquaporin-4 (AQP4) have been identified as a causative factor of some cases of optic neuritis. Patients who develop optic neuritis because of antibodies against MOG and AQP4 often have severe presentations but also have a decreased risk for subsequent MS compared with patients with optic neuritis who lack these autoantibodies. The Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial demonstrated that a short course of treatment with high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone speeds the rate of visual recovery and delays the onset of MS, although it does not impact final visual acuity, and demonstrated that the presence and quantity of periventricular white matter lesions on MRI imaging is the most important prognostic risk factor for the subsequent development of MS.

distractor_explanations.A: The cerebellum coordinates ocular saccades, pursuit movements, and gaze holding. Cerebel lar lesions do not cause an a r ~I• , r, Clinical Correct Answer: B. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, E, F, G, H, and I. The cerebellum (Choice A) coordinates ocular saccades, pursuit movements, and gaze holding. Cerebellar lesions do not cause an rAPD. Cranial nerve Ill (Choice C), the oculomotor nerve, is responsible for motor innervation of the levator palpebrae superioris; the superior, medial, and inferior rectus muscles; and the inferior oblique muscle. Deficits of the oculomotor nerve present with ptosis, exotropia, and hypotropia. Cranial nerve IV (Choice D), the trochlear nerve, is responsible for motor innervation of the superior oblique muscle. Deficits of the trochlear nerve present with diplopia, hypertropia, and compensatory head tilt. Cranial nerve VI (Choice E), the abducens nerve, is responsible for motor innervation of the lateral rectus muscle. Deficits of the abducens nerve present with esotropia and diplopia worst during horizontal gaze. Extraocular muscles (Choice F) may cause diplopia in the setting of thyroid ophthalmopathy, orbital mass lesions, or entrapment within a fractured orbital bone. Dysfunction of the extraocular muscles does not produce a rAPD. Lesions of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) (Choice G) cause internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), which presents with an ipsilateral adduction deficit, characterized by an inability of the affected eye to cross midline, and an associated contralateral abduction saccade. Defects of the neuromuscular junction (Choice H) occur in the setting of myasthenia gravis, which presents with diplopia and ptosis that Clinical of periventricular white matter lesions on MRI imaging is the most important prognostic risk factor for the subsequent development of MS. Deficits of the oculomotor nerve present with ptosis, exotropia, and hypotropia. Cranial nerve IV (Choice D), the trochlear nerve, is respons ible for motor innervation of the superior oblique muscle. Deficits of the trochlear nerve present with diplopia, hypertropia, and compensatory head tilt. Cranial nerve VI (Choice E), the abducens nerve, is responsible for motor innervation of the lateral rectus muscle. Deficits of the abducens nerve present with esotropia and diplopia worst during horizontal gaze. Extraocular muscles (Choice F) may cause diplopia in the setting of thyroid ophthalmopathy, orbital mass lesions, or entrapment within a fractured orbital bone. Dysfunction of the extraocular muscles does not produce a rAPD. Lesions of the medial longitudina l fascicu lus (MLF) (Choice G) cause internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), which presents with an ipsilateral adduction deficit, characterized by an inability of the affected eye to cross midline, and an associated contralateral abduction saccade. Defects of the neuromuscular junction (Choice H) occur in the setting of myasthenia gravis, which presents with diplopia and ptosis that worsens toward the end of the day. Defects of the retina (Choice I) may produce visual field deficits and a rAPD but are usually visible on fundoscopy and are rarely painful.

explanation.educational_objective: Optic neuritis is an autoimmune, inflammatory disorder of the optic nerve (cranial nerve II) that presents with acute onset vision loss and ocular pain that is exacerbated with extraocular movements. Patients typically present with profound ly decreased visual acuity and color vision, along with a relative afferent pupillary defect. Diagnosis is confirmed with MRI and with testing for serum autoantibodies. MRI provides importan t prognostic information regarding the subsequent risk for developing multiple sclerosis, which commonly occurs in association with optic neuritis. Treatmen t with high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone speeds visual recovery and delays the onset of multiple sclerosis Clinical
explanation.concept: Optic neuritis is an autoimmune, inflammatory disorder of the optic nerve (cranial nerve II) that presents with acute onset vision loss and ocular pain that is exacerbated with extraocular movements.

vignette.presentation:
28. A 22-year-old college student comes to the student health center after an episode during which he found himself unable to move for several
seconds after awakening. The episode occurred during the college's spring break 2 weeks ago, when he awoke after having fallen asleep on the
beach. He has no history of similar symptoms. The patient is not having academic difficulties, although he admits to recent stress caused by the
examinations that he took just before the spring break. His medical history is noncontributory. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination
shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Polysomnography and multiple sleep latency test

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Sleep paralysis, a manifestation of the atonia that primarily occurs during REM sleep, happens during the transition from sleep to wakefulness at least once in most people's lives. The precise mechanism of sleep paralysis during the transition to wakefulness is unknown, but stress, psychiatric disorders, sleep deprivation, and substance use may increase the risk. This patient's preceding stress and potential sleep deprivation and substance use during spring break may have contributed to his sleep paralysis episode. Patients are typically distressed during the episode and may experience an associated feeling of impending doom. Other features of REM sleep may also intrude into transitions from sleep to wakefulness or wakefulness to sleep (eg, hypnopompic or hypnagogic hallucinations). Management of an isolated sleep paralysis episode consists of reassurance and education about normal sleep behavior. If sleep paralysis episodes persist, then the patient should be evaluated for narcolepsy.

distractor_explanations.B: Polysomnography and multiple sleep latency test would confirm a diagnosis of narcolepsy. Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder that involves deficient orexin secretion, leading to the repeated intrusion of sleep phenomena (eg, sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, sleep paralysis) into times of wakefulness. An isolated episode would not be concerning for narcolepsy. Psychiatric assessment (Choice C) and toxicology screening (Choice D) are unnecessary. Though this patient experienced stress, possibly contributing to the sleep paralysis, a single episode of sleep paralysis during wakefulness is common and not an indication of a psychiatri.c o r .su bstance use disorder atients with a normal standard EEG when the h Clinical D) Toxicology screening E) Sleep-deprived EEG F) MRI of the brain Correct Answer: A. The precise mechanism of sleep paralysis during the transition to wakefulness is unknown, but stress, psychiatric disorders, sleep deprivation, and substance use may increase the risk. This patient's preceding stress and potential sleep deprivation and substance use during spring break may have contributed to his sleep paralysis episode. Patients are typically distressed during the episode and may experience an associated feeling of impending doom. Other features of REM sleep may also intrude into transitions from sleep to wakefulness or wakefulness to sleep (eg, hypnopompic or hypnagogic hallucinations). Management of an isolated sleep paralysis episode consists of reassurance and education about normal sleep behavior. If sleep paralysis episodes persist, then the patient should be evaluated for narcolepsy. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, E, and F. Polysomnography and multiple sleep latency test (Choice B) would confirm a diagnosis of narcolepsy. Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder that involves deficient orexin secretion, leading to the repeated intrusion of sleep phenomena (eg, sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, sleep paralysis) into times of wakefulness. An isolated episode would not be concerning for narcolepsy. Psychiatric assessment (Choice C) and toxicology screening (Choice D) are unnecessary. Though this patient experienced stress, possibly contributing to the sleep paralysis, a single episode of sleep paralysis during wakefulness is common and not an indication of a psychiatric or substance use disorder. Sleep-deprived EEG (Choice E) is utilized to detect epileptiform discharges in patients with a normal standard EEG when the physician has a high clinical suspicion of a seizure disorder. A single episode of sleep paralysis during wakefulness is common and not an indication of a seizure disorder. MRI of the brain (Choice F) is unnecessary. A single episode of sleep paralysis during wakefulness is common and not an indication of central nervous system damage.

explanation.educational_objective: Sleep paralysis, a manifestation of the atonia that primarily occurs during rapid eye movement (REM) sleep, happens during the transition from sleep to wakefulness at least once in most people's lives. After a single episode of sleep paralysis, reassurance is appropriate, but if sleep paralysis recurs, narcolepsy should be ruled out. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Sleep paralysis, a manifestation of the atonia that primarily occurs during rapid eye movement (REM) sleep, happens during the transition from sleep to wakefulness at least once in most people's lives

vignette.presentation:
29. An 82-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of a 6-month history of neck pain radiating to her left hand. She has also had neck
stiffness and difficulty maintaining her balance while walking. She has osteoarthr itis, Crohn disease, gastroesophagea l reflux disease, and
hyperlipidemia. Current medications include ranitidine, cholestyramine, mesalamine, and ibuprofen. Examination shows moderately decreased
range of motion of the neck. There is mild weakness and atrophy of the hands and forearms and increased muscle tone of the lower extremities.
The triceps reflexes are absent, the biceps and brachioradia lis reflexes are intact, and the knee and ankle jerk reflexes are increased. Babinski
sign is present bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick and temperature is decreased over the dorsal forearms and hands. Her gait is broad based and
stiff. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cervical spondylotic myelopathy is a spinal cord syndrome caused by compression of the cervical spinal cord by degenerated vertebral bodies, facet joints, and/or herniated intervertebral discs. The process begins with progressive degeneration of these surrounding bony structures, which then causes impingement on the central spinal canal. Depending on the level of involvement, the exact symptoms will differ. In most cases, compression of the spinal nerves at the level of the degenerative changes will cause lower motoneuron findings including weakness, hyporeflexia, and atrophy, as seen in the upper extremities of this patient. In contrast, compression of the tracts within the spinal cord, including the lateral corticospinal tract, will cause weakness with upper motoneuron findings in the levels inferior to the degenerative changes. As in this patient, hyperreflexia and an upgoing Babinski sign will be present. The spinothalamic tract may also be compressed, leading to impaired pain and temperature sensation.

distractor_explanations.A: plexopathy and bilateral median and ulnar mononeuropathy (Choice B) are both pathologies involving peripheral nerves. Impairment of peripheral motor nerves causes lower motoneuron signs including weakness, fasciculations, hyporeflexia, hypotonia, and atrophy. However, neither of these pathologies would explain the patient's upper motoneuron signs in the lower extremities. Parasagittal meningioma (Choice D) is an intracranial tumor that grows along the falx cerebri and may compress the adjacent cerebral cortex, possibly including the primary motor cortex in the lower extremity portion of the motor homunculus. This has the potential to cause weakness of the lower extremities with findings of upper motoneuron disease. However, this patient also has lower motoneuron r ~ - - - , r, Clinical C) Cervical spondylotic myelopathy; D) Parasagittal meningioma E) Subacute combined degeneration Correct Answer: C. The process begins with progressive degeneration of these surrounding bony structures, which then causes impingement on the central spinal canal. Depending on the level of involvement, the exact symptoms will differ. In most cases, compression of the spinal nerves at the level of the degenerative changes will cause lower motoneuron findings including weakness, hyporeflexia, and atrophy, as seen in the upper extremities of this patient. In contrast, compression of the tracts within the spinal cord, including the lateral corticospinal tract, will cause weakness with upper motoneuron findings in the levels inferior to the degenerative changes. As in this patient, hyperreflexia and an upgoing Babinski sign will be present. The spinothalamic tract may also be compressed, leading to impaired pain and temperature sensation. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E. Bilateral brachia! plexopathy (Choice A) and bilateral median and ulnar mononeuropathy (Choice B) are both pathologies involving peripheral nerves. Impairment of peripheral motor nerves causes lower motoneuron signs including weakness, fasciculations, hyporeflexia, hypotonia, and atrophy. However, neither of these pathologies would explain the patient's upper motoneuron signs in the lower extremities. Parasagittal meningioma (Choice D) is an intracranial tumor that grows along the falx cerebri and may compress the adjacent cerebral cortex, possibly including the primary motor cortex in the lower extremity portion of the motor homunculus. This has the potential to cause weakness of the lower extremities with findings of upper motoneuron disease. However, this patient also has lower motoneuron findings, which would not be explained by a parasagittal meningioma. Subacute combined degeneration (Choice E), caused by demyelination of the dorsal columns, lateral corticospinal tracts, and spinocerebellar tracts, is a feature of vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency. Subacute combined degeneration causes a combination of 12 motor and sensory symptoms including ataxic gait, muscle weakness, paresthesias, and loss of proprioception and vibration sense.

explanation.educational_objective: Cervical spondylotic myelopathy is a spinal cord syndrome caused by compression of the cervical spinal cord by degenerated vertebral bodies, facet joints, and/or herniated intervertebral discs. Motor weakness with lower motoneuron findings at the level of degenerative compression are accompanied by upper motoneuron findings below the level of the compression. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Cervical spondylotic myelopathy is a spinal cord syndrome caused by compression of the cervical spinal cord by degenerated vertebral bodies, facet joints, and/or herniated intervertebral discs. Motor

vignette.presentation:
30. A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of urinary hesitancy, leg weakness, and difficulty walking;
he says that he falls occasionally. He has a 1-month history of sharp right-sided abdominal pain that is exacerbated by coughing, sneezing, and
lying flat; the pain now radiates posteriorly to the interscapular region. At his last examination 3 days ago, testing for gallbladder disease was
negative. He has hypertension treated with atenolol. His temperature is 37.1 °C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg.
Examination shows tenderness to percussion over the midthoracic spine. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the iliopsoas, hamstrings, and anterior tibialis
muscles bilaterally; it is otherwise full. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ in the upper extremities and 3+ in the knees and ankles. Babinski sign is
present bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick and temperature is decreased below the costal margin, and sensation to vibration is absent below the
ankles. Intravenous administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's presenting signs and symptoms of focal back pain and upper motoneuron signs are suggestive of epidural spinal cord compression, which often results from degenerative joint disease or metastatic disease. Metastatic disease frequently affects the vertebral column and may cause compression of the spinal cord by extending into the epidural space or by causing bony destruction and fracture of the vertebral bodies. Patients present with back pain, lower extremity weakness, loss of balance, urinary or bowel incontinence, or complete paralysis of the lower extremities. Early detection and treatment are crucial to prevent permanent spinal cord damage and myelopathy. Patients may benefit from short-term treatment with intravenous dexamethasone to decrease spinal cord edema, although definitive treatment often requires a combination of surgical decompression in the case of a bony structural lesion or chemotherapy, and/or radiotherapy in the case of malignancy.

distractor_explanations.A: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin and is effective for the treatment of osteomyelitis. While osteomyelitis may lead to spinal cord compression as a result of the formation of an epidural abscess, this is usually accompanied by fever.
distractor_explanations.D: Heparin is an anticoagulant and is useful for the treatment of deep venous thrombosis (DVT). While DVTs may cause lower extremity swelling, pain, and discoloration, they are unlikely to cause focal spinal tenderness with upper motoneuron signs.
distractor_explanations.E: Mannitol is an osmotic agent that is useful for the treatment of cerebral edema. While cerebral edema may cause upper motoneuron signs, patients usually have other signs and symptoms including altered mental status, headache, nausea, and vomiting. Mannitol is not commonly used to decrease swelling in the setting of epidural spinal cord compression.

explanation.educational_objective: Dexamethasone is useful for decreasing spinal cord edema and inflammation secondary to epidural spinal cord compression prior to definitive treatment. Patients with epidural spinal cord compression present with back pain, lower extremity weakness, loss of balance, urinary or bowel incontinence, or paralysis of the lower extremities. ., Exam Section : Item 31 of 50 Clinical
explanation.concept: Dexamethasone is useful for decreasing spinal cord edema and inflammation secondary to epidural spinal cord compression prior to definitive treatment. Patients with epidural spinal cord compression pr

vignette.presentation:
31. A 67-year-o ld woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of right facial weakness. She has hypertension
treated with lisinopril and hyperlipidemia treated with atorvastatin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Her pulse is 76/min,
and blood pressure is 168/90 mm Hg. Examination shows right facial weakness of the forehead and lower face. There is decreased hearing and
tinnitus on the right. Finger-nose testing shows mild ataxia on the right. An MRI of the brain is most likely to show an infarction in which of the
following areas?

question_stem:
most likely to show an infarction in which of the
following areas?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cerebral infarctions, also known as strokes, occur as a result of ischemic or hemorrhagic loss of blood supply to the brain. Approximately 80% to 85% of strokes are ischemic, commonly arising from thromboembolic disease (eg, middle cerebral artery occlusion from a thrombus), whereas 15% to 20% of strokes are hemorrhagic as a result of blood vessel rupture (eg, hypertension related intraparenchymal hemorrhage from a perforating artery). Risk factors for stroke include smoking, hypertension, diabetes, carotid or intracrania l atherosclerotic disease, history of hypercoagulability, atrial fibrillation, and advanced age. Classically, strokes manifest as a neurologic deficit related to the affected part of the brain. Infarction in the distribution of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery affects several cranial nerve nuclei within the pons, which together are referred to as the lateral pontine syndrome. Involvement of the facial nucleus leads to facial droop caused by muscle paralysis, decreased lacrimation, decreased salivation, and decreased taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Involvement of the vestibular nucleus causes vomiting, vertigo, and nystagmus. Involvement of the middle and inferior cerebellar peduncles will lead to ataxia and dysmetria. lpsilatera l Horner syndrome and contralateral pain and temperature sensation impairment, though not present in this patient, may also result.

distractor_explanations.A: An infarct in the internal capsule will lead to both motor and sensory deficits of the contralateral side of the body. Occlusion of the lenticulostriate artery can cause this constellation of findings. Infarction of the medulla (Choice B) causes either medial medullary syndrome, if the anterior spinal artery is affected, or lateral medullary syndrome, if the posterior inferior cerebellar artery is affected. In the former, the lateral corticospinal tract, medial lemniscus, and hypoglossal nerve are affected, leading to contralateral muscle weakness, contralateral impaired proprioception, and ipsilateral tongue deviation, respectively. In lateral medullary syndrome, dysphagia, hoarseness, and decreased gag reflex occur because of r ~- - , r - - - , Exam Section : Item 31 of 50 Clinical E) Temporal lobe Correct Answer: D. Cerebral infarctions, also known as strokes, occur as a result of ischemic or hemorrhagic loss of blood supply to the brain. Approximately 80% to 85% of strokes are ischemic, commonly arising from thromboembolic disease (eg, middle cerebral artery occlusion from a thrombus), whereas 15% to 20% of strokes are hemorrhagic as a result of blood vessel rupture (eg, hypertension related intraparenchymal hemorrhage from a perforating artery). Risk factors for stroke include smoking, hypertension, diabetes, carotid or intracranial atherosclerotic disease, history of hypercoagulability, atrial fibrillation, and advanced age. Classically, strokes manifest as a neurologic deficit related to the affected part of the brain. Infarction in the distribution of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery affects several cranial nerve nuclei within the pons, which together are referred to as the lateral pontine syndrome. Involvement of the facial nucleus leads to facial droop caused by muscle paralysis, decreased lacrimation, decreased salivation, and decreased taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Involvement of the vestibular nucleus causes vomiting, vertigo, and nystagmus. Involvement of the middle and inferior cerebellar peduncles will lead to ataxia and dysmetria. lpsilateral Horner syndrome and contralateral pain and temperature sensation impairment, though not present in this patient, may also result. Incorrect Answer: A, B, C, and E. An infarct in the internal capsule (Choice A) will lead to both motor and sensory deficits of the contralateral side of the body. Occlusion of the lenticulostriate artery can cause this constellation of findings. Infarction of the medulla (Choice B) causes either medial medullary syndrome, if the anterior spinal artery is affected, or lateral medullary syndrome, if the posterior inferior cerebellar artery is affected. In the former, the lateral corticospinal tract, medial lemniscus, and hypoglossal nerve are affected, leading to contralateral muscle weakness, contralateral impaired proprioception, and ipsilateral tongue deviation, respectively. In lateral medullary syndrome, dysphagia, hoarseness, and decreased gag reflex occur because of involvement of the nucleus ambiguus. The vestibular nucleus and lateral spinothalamic tract are also impaired. These findings are not seen in this patient. Infarction of the midbrain (Choice C) would impact the function of the oculomotor and trochlear nerves. This patient does not demonstrate any eye movement deficits. Infarction of the temporal lobe (Choice E) may impact regions such as the Wernicke area of speech and Meyer loop of the visual pathway. As well, it may impact the primary auditory cortex, resulting in varying degrees of hearing impairment depending on the extent of infarction.

explanation.educational_objective: Infarction in the pons will affect several cranial nerve nuclei, including that of the facial and vestibular nerves. Facial paralysis is the most common symptom of cerebrovascular hemorrhage or infarction in this distribution Clinical

vignette.presentation:
32. A 52-year-o ld man is brought to the emergency department from work 30 minutes after the sudden onset of blindness. He is unable to remember
all the events leading up to his visual loss, but he states that earlier in the day he saw his boss in a compromising position; he is uncomfortable
speaking about this and quickly changes the subject. He has not had any eye pain but says that he has a headache. He has a history of migraines
treated with sumatriptan. Ophthalmic examination shows no evidence of trauma, erythema, or infection. He flinches when the physician rapidly
raises her hand toward his face. Funduscopic examination shows no evidence of papilledema, optic neuritis, or retinal hemorrhage or detachment.
A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he appears unaffected by his vision loss. His speech is normal, and
he does not have any delusional behavior. When his wife arrives at the emergency department, he asks if he can go home and inquires about
when he can return to work. Which of the following is the most likely diagnos is?

question_stem: the most likely diagnos is?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurologic disorder, involves neurologic symptoms such as sensory or motor dysfunction that are not fully explained by objective findings on physical examination or imaging. This patient's flinching in response to a visual stimulus indicates a subconscious ability to see and makes a neurologic injury unlikely. Though the symptoms disrupt daily life, patients with functional neurologic disorder may or may not be preoccupied with their symptoms. Functiona l neurologic disorder is postulated to represent the subconscious conversion of intolerable emotional distress into physical symptoms as indicated by this patient quickly changing the subject when asked about a stressor. Psychiatric comorbidities such as depression are common but not present in all patients. Physicians should conduct a thorough history and physica l examination, and obtain laboratory and imaging studies to evaluate for medical or neurologic disease that may explain or partially explain the symptoms. Treatment of functiona l neurologic disorder involves education about the diagnosis, physical therapy, and cognitive-behavioral therapy.

distractor_explanations.A: Acute stress disorder refers to psychologica l stress responses (eg, dissociation, intrusive thoughts, depressed mood, avoidance, hyperarousa l) occurring within a month of a traumatic event. This patient's response to stress instead manifests as a neurologic symptom Clinical Correct Answer: C. Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurologic disorder, involves neurologic symptoms such as sensory or motor dysfunction that are not fully explained by objective findings on physical examination or imaging. This patient's flinching in response to a visual stimulus indicates a subconscious ability to see and makes a neurologic injury unlikely. Though the symptoms disrupt daily life, patients with functional neurologic disorder may or may not be preoccupied with their symptoms. Functional neurologic disorder is postulated to represent the subconscious conversion of intolerable emotional distress into physical symptoms as indicated by this patient quickly changing the subject when asked about a stressor. Psychiatric comorbidities such as depression are common but not present in all patients. Physicians should conduct a thorough history and physical examination, and obtain laboratory and imaging studies to evaluate for medical or neurologic disease that may explain or partially explain the symptoms. Treatment of functional neurologic disorder involves education about the diagnosis, physical therapy, and cognitive-behavioral therapy. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, E, and F. Acute stress disorder (Choice A) refers to psychological stress responses (eg, dissociation, intrusive thoughts, depressed mood, avoidance, hyperarousal) occurring within a month of a traumatic event. This patient's response to stress instead manifests as a neurologic symptom. Brief psychotic disorder (Choice B) is characterized by at least one acute psychotic symptom (eg, delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, disorganized behavior) lasting less than 1 month. This patient demonstrates a neurologic symptom, not a psychotic symptom.
distractor_explanations.D: Malingering refers to the conscious production of symptoms for a conscious purpose. This conscious purpose is known as secondary gain and includes motives such as obtaining disability payments or missing work. There is no clear secondary gain for this patient who is not focused on his symptoms and wishes to return to work.
distractor_explanations.E: Migraine is a primary headache associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. Ocular migraine is a rare condition producing abrupt, transient monocular vision loss. However, the vision loss would be demonstrated on physical examination and the patient would not flinch in response to a visual stimulus. An occipital lobe infarct (Choice F) could lead to vision loss presenting as a contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. This patient instead endorses loss of the entire visual field, and CT scan of the head was negative for occipital lesions.

explanation.educational_objective: Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurologic disorder, involves neurologic symptoms such as sensory or motor dysfunction that are not fully explained by objective findings on physical examination or imaging. Functional neurologic disorder is postulated to represent the subconscious conversion of intolerable emotional distress into physical symptoms Clinical
explanation.concept: Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurologic disorder, involves neurologic symptoms such as sensory or motor dysfunction that are not fully explained by objective findings on physical exam

vignette.presentation:
33. A 72-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of a 24-hour history of severe right ear pain, drooping of the right side of her face, and
tearing of the right eye. She had a mild upper respiratory tract infection 1 week ago. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus currently treated with
glyburide. She is in distress. Her temperatu re is 37°C (98.6°F). Examination shows rotatory nystagmus on lateral gaze. There is severe palsy of
the right peripheral facial nerve with an inability to close the right eye. Examination shows a rash in the external auditory canal and hearing loss on
the right. There is no nuchal rigidity. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

question_stem: the most likely cause of these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's presenting signs and symptoms of unilateral facial nerve palsy, ear pain and rash, hearing loss, nystagmus , and tearing, are consistent with a diagnosis of Ramsay Hunt syndrome, also known as zoster oticus. Ramsay Hunt syndrome is caused by reactivation of a latent infection with herpes zoster virus within the geniculate ganglion. Viral reactivation within the geniculate ganglion leads to facial nerve palsy, which causes paralysis of the muscles of facial expression (including the forehead) and may cause lagophthalmos and corneal dryness. In addition, the proximity of the vestibulocochlear nerve to the geniculate ganglion increases the risk for its involvement, which causes a characteristic presentation of ear pain and vesicular rash of the external ear canal or auricle, and may also cause hearing loss, vertigo, and nystagmus. The diagnosis is clinical but may be confirmed with PCR amplification testing. Treatment includes oral prednisone and acyclovir.

distractor_explanations.A: Borrelia burgdorferi infection causes Lyme disease, which is a common cause of facial nerve palsy. Lyme disease rarely causes palsy of the vestibulocochlear nerve or a rash of the external ear.
distractor_explanations.C: Measles is a highly contagious paramyxovirus that presents with fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and a confluent maculopapular rash that starts at the head or neck and spreads to the trunk, excluding the palms and soles. In severe cases, it may cause subacute sclerosing panencepha litis. It does not typically cause facial or vestibulocochlear nerve palsy.
distractor_explanations.D: Mucormycosis is caused by an invasive infection with fungal organisms such as Mucor or Rhizopus, and results in aggressive infections of the sinuses, nasal cavity, orbits, or lungs, primarily in patients with a history of immunocompromise (eg, diabetes mellitus). Patients present with a necrotic eschar of the affected area and there are fungal hyphae on tissue biopsy. Mucormycosis rarely affects the ear canal. Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection (Choice E) and Staphylococcal infection (Choice F) are the most common causes of otitis externa, also known as swimmer's ear. Otitis externa presents with erythema, discharge, and edema of the external ear canal and auricle, but it rarely causes facial or vestibulocochlear nerve palsy.

explanation.educational_objective: Ramsay Hunt syndrome, also known as zoster oticus, is caused by reactivation of latent herpes zoster viral infection within the geniculate ganglion with subsequent cranial nerve palsy of the facial and vestibulocochlear nerves. Patients present with facial paralysis, lagophthalmos, exposure keratopathy, hearing loss, vertigo, nystagmus, and a vesicular rash of the external ear canal and auricle. Treatment is with oral prednisone and acyclovir. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Ramsay Hunt syndrome, also known as zoster oticus, is caused by reactivation of latent herpes zoster viral infection within the geniculate ganglion with subsequent cranial nerve palsy of the facial an

vignette.presentation:
34. A 47-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of a severe headache that began suddenly while she was
exercising at the gym. She rates her pain as a 10 on a 10-point scale and says it is present over her entire head. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus
controlled with metformin. She is 172 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (158 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2 . She is alert and oriented. Vital signs are within
normal limits. On examination, the right pupil is 5 mm and not reactive to light. Meningismus is present. The remainder of the examination,
including neurologic examination, shows no abnormalities. The most likely cause of these findings is a lesion in which of the following arteries?

question_stem: The most likely cause of these findings is a lesion in which of the following arteries?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) refers to bleeding into the subarachnoid space. It most commonly occurs secondary to trauma, although aneurysmal rupture is the most common cause of nontraumatic SAH. Patients typically present with an acute, severe headache often described as the worst headache of their life, along with neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma in severe cases. Aneurysms can occur at various locations within the intracranial vasculature. This patient presents with oculomotor nerve palsy, raising suspicion for a posterior communicating artery aneurysm. Oculomotor nerve palsy is a common presenting sign of a posterior communicating artery aneurysm because of its location and compression of the oculomotor nerve. The oculomotor nerve carries parasympathetic fibers allowing for pupillary constriction and motor fibers innervating the levator palpebrae superioris and several extraocular muscles. Patients with an oculomotor nerve palsy can present with pupillary dilation, ptosis, and extraocular muscle paresis leading to diplopia.

distractor_explanations.A: The anterior cerebral arteries are connected by the anterior communicating artery, the most common site for aneurysms in the circle of Willis. Because of its location near the optic chiasm, it can cause visual field defects such as bitemporal hemianopsia. Basilar artery (Choice B) and middle cerebral artery (Choice C) aneurysms can also rupture and cause an acute headache, intracranial hemorrhage, and/or subarachnoid hemorrhage, but oculomotor nerve palsy would be atypical. Proximal internal carotid artery (Choice E) aneurysms within the neck are much less common than aneurysms of the posterior communicating artery. As well, aneurysmal rupture of the proximal internal carotid artery would not cause cranial nerve palsies, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or findings of meningismus Clinical A) Anterior cerebral B) Basilar C) Middle cerebral D) Posterior communicating E) Proximal internal carotid Correct Answer: D. Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) refers to bleeding into the subarachnoid space. It most commonly occurs secondary to trauma, although aneurysmal rupture is the most common cause of nontraumatic SAH. Patients typically present with an acute, severe headache often described as the worst headache of their life, along with neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma in severe cases. Aneurysms can occur at various locations within the intracranial vasculature. This patient presents with oculomotor nerve palsy, raising suspicion for a posterior communicating artery aneurysm. Oculomotor nerve palsy is a common presenting sign of a posterior communicating artery aneurysm because of its location and compression of the oculomotor nerve. The oculomotor nerve carries parasympathetic fibers allowing for pupillary constriction and motor fibers innervating the levator palpebrae superioris and several extraocular muscles. Patients with an oculomotor nerve palsy can present with pupillary dilation, ptosis, and extraocular muscle paresis leading to diplopia. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and E. The anterior cerebral arteries (Choice A) are connected by the anterior communicating artery, the most common site for aneurysms in the circle of Willis. Because of its location near the optic chiasm, it can cause visual field defects such as bitemporal hemianopsia. Basilar artery (Choice B) and middle cerebral artery (Choice C) aneurysms can also rupture and cause an acute headache, intracranial hemorrhage, and/or subarachnoid hemorrhage, but oculomotor nerve palsy would be atypical. Proximal internal carotid artery (Choice E) aneurysms within the neck are much less common than aneurysms of the posterior communicating artery. As well, aneurysmal rupture of the proximal internal carotid artery would not cause cranial nerve palsies, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or findings of meningismus.

explanation.educational_objective: Patients with SAH typically present with an acute, severe headache often described as the worst headache of their life, along with neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma in severe cases. Oculomotor nerve palsy is a common presenting sign of a posterior communicating artery aneurysm because of its location and compression of the oculomotor nerve. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Patients with SAH typically present with an acute, severe headache often described as the worst headache of their life, along with neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma in severe ca

vignette.presentation:
35. A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of difficulty walking and a tremor of the right arm. He says that his
movements have been slower. He has hypertension, schizophrenia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Current medications include
hydrochlorothiazide, fluphenazine, benztropine, and ranitidine. His blood pressure is 108/72 mm Hg. Examination shows increased muscle tone in
the right upper extremity; there is a resting tremor of the right hand and decreased right arm swing. His gait is short based. Mental status
examination shows a restricted affect. Which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's symptoms?

question_stem: most likely to improve this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Adding donepezil to the medication regimen
Adding risperidone to the medication regimen

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Fluphenazine, a first-generation antipsychotic medication, is a dopamine-2 (D ) receptor antagonist. By decreasing mesolimbic 2 dopamine signaling, fluphenazine treats the psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia. D antagonism in the basal ganglia can cause acute 2 dystonic reactions and parkinsonism, leading to this patient's bradykinesia (manifesting as a decreased right arm swing while walking), resting tremor, increased muscle tone, and postural instability (manifesting as a short, or shuffling, gait). The chronic use of antidopaminergic agents may also upregulate D receptors in the basal ganglia, leading to tardive dyskinesia. Management of 2 medication-induced parkinsonism typically involves adding an anticholinergic medication such as benztropine, which counteracts antidopaminergic activity and addresses parkinsonism. In this patient with schizophrenia already on an anticholinergic medication (benztropine ), the next step is decreasing or discontinuing the dose of the offending medication and switching to an antipsychotic medication that causes less potent D antagonism. 2

distractor_explanations.A: Donepezil is a cholinesterase inhibitor utilized in dementia that increases cholinergic signaling in the cortex. Benztropine (Choice C) is an anticholinergic medication that antagonizes muscarinic acetylcholine receptors in the central nervous system (CNS), modulating the dopamine-acetylcholine balance in the basal ganglia, and thus treats parkinsonism and acute dystonic reaction. An increase in cholinergic signaling through adding donepezil or discontinuing benztropine would not address this patient's parkinsonism (and in the case of discontinuing benztropine, would likely exacerbate parkinsonism).
distractor_explanations.B: Risperidone is a second-generation antipsychotic that antagonizes the D receptor and modulates serotonin signaling. Of 2 the second-generation antipsychotics, risperidone demonstrates the most potent D antagonism and would likely exacerbate this 2 patient's parkinsonism.
distractor_explanations.E: Ranitidine is a histamine-2 (H ) receptor antagonist that decreases gastric acid secretion and is utilized to relieve reflux 2 symptoms or dyspepsia. H antagonists may act on the CNS to cause somnolence and confusion but do not lead to motor dysfunction. 2 Therefore, discontinuing ranitidine would not be helpful.

explanation.educational_objective: Fluphenazine, a first-generation antipsychotic medication, is a dopamine-2 (D ) receptor antagonist. D 2 2 antagonism in the basal ganglia can potentially cause acute dystonic reactions and parkinsonism. To address drug-induced parkinsonism in patients with schizophrenia, anticholinergic medications should be added, or the offending medication should be discontinued in favor of an antipsychotic that causes less potent D receptor antagonism. 2 ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Fluphenazine, a first-generation antipsychotic medication, is a dopamine-2 (D ) receptor antagonist. D 2 2 antagonism in the basal ganglia can potentially cause acute dystonic reactions and parkinsoni

vignette.presentation:
36. A 25-year-o ld woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of depressed mood and episodes of daytime sleepiness despite getting
an adequate amount of sleep at night. She takes daily naps that are marked by visions of bloody bodies before she falls asleep or upon
awakening. She is frightened by these visions but cannot control her urge to sleep; she wakes up refreshed. She has smoked one pack of
cigarettes daily for 8 years and drinks one to two cups of coffee daily. She does not use illicit drugs. She is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs
75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2 . Her temperatu re is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Neurologic examination
shows no focal findings. Mental status examinat ion shows anxiety and a mildly depressed mood. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the
following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Narcolepsy is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with hypnagogic hallucinations and daytime somnolence. The pathogenesis of narcolepsy involves the loss of orexin-A and orexin-B, which are neurotransmitters found primarily in the hypothalamus that promote wakefulness and inhibit REM sleep. Loss of these neurotransmitters permits abnormal transition from wakefulness to REM sleep with the consequent development of hallucinations and other features of narcolepsy, including cataplexy and sleep paralysis. Diagnosis can be made in patients with daytime somnolence and cataplexy or, in cases where cataplexy is not present, with sleep latency testing, which shows a shorter time from wakefulness to the initiation of REM sleep. Occasionally patients undergo lumbar puncture to directly measure concentrations of orexin-A in the cerebrospinal fluid. Pharmacotherapy is directed as promoting wakefulness and avoiding cataplexy.

distractor_explanations.A: Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech or behavior, or catatonia that lasts more than 1 day but less than a month and is not secondary to a mood disorder or substance abuse. Major depressive disorder (Choice B) is diagnosed when patients meet at least five of the nine criteria, including impaired sleep (either insomnia or hypersomnolence ), loss of interest, guilt, loss of energy, poor concentration, poor appetite, psychomotor retardation, or suicidal ideation. This patient does not meet the criteria. Nightmare disorder (Choice D) describes the presence of recurrent disturbing dreams. This disorder is not characterized by daytime r ~ - - -- -, r, Clinical i J. .. I i•• J.• i Ii• A C) Narcoleps D) Nightmare disorder E) Sleep apnea Correct Answer: C. Narcolepsy is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with hypnagogic hallucinations and daytime somnolence. The pathogenesis of narcolepsy involves the loss of orexin-A and orexin-B, which are neurotransmitters found primarily in the hypothalamus that promote wakefulness and inhibit REM sleep. Loss of these neurotransmitters permits abnormal transition from wakefulness to REM sleep with the consequent development of hallucinations and other features of narcolepsy, including cataplexy and sleep paralysis. Diagnosis can be made in patients with daytime somnolence and cataplexy or, in cases where cataplexy is not present, with sleep latency testing, which shows a shorter time from wakefulness to the initiation of REM sleep. Occasionally patients undergo lumbar puncture to directly measure concentrations of orexin-A in the cerebrospinal fluid. Pharmacotherapy is directed as promoting wakefulness and avoiding cataplexy. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E. Brief psychotic disorder (Choice A) is characterized by hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech or behavior, or catatonia that lasts more than 1 day but less than a month and is not secondary to a mood disorder or substance abuse. Major depressive disorder (Choice B) is diagnosed when patients meet at least five of the nine criteria, including impaired sleep (either insomnia or hypersomnolence ), loss of interest, guilt, loss of energy, poor concentration, poor appetite, psychomotor retardation, or suicidal ideation. This patient does not meet the criteria. Nightmare disorder (Choice D) describes the presence of recurrent disturbing dreams. This disorder is not characterized by daytime somnolence or cataplexy. Sleep apnea (Choice E) commonly presents in obese patients with daytime somnolence and morning headaches. A history of snoring is typical, and diagnosis is made by observing periods of apnea during a sleep study. Treatment is with the use of continuous airway pressure devices.

explanation.educational_objective: Narcolepsy should be suspected in patients with daytime somnolence but restorative sleep with the concurrent presence of hypnagogic hallucinations or cataplexy. Diagnosis can be made clinically if cataplexy is present but otherwise requires sleep latency testing, which shows a shorter time from wakefulness to the initiation of REM sleep. ., Exam Section : Item 37 of 50 Clinical

vignette.presentation:
37. A 56-year-o ld woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after a simple partial seizure. A CT scan of the head shows a 1.5-cm,
uniformly and intensely enhancing parasag ittal mass in the left frontal region. Further evaluation for a primary lesion is negative. Examination
shows mild weakness of the right lower extremity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnos is?

question_stem: the most likely diagnos is?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Meningioma is a common, benign central nervous system (CNS) tumor derived from the meninges that occurs along the surfaces of the brain and spinal cord, often in the parasagittal region. They occur in women more often than men and are associated with neurofibromatosis 2 and multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 1. Patients may be asymptomatic, or they may experience seizures or focal neurologic deficits related to the tumor location. Meningiomas are typically benign but can be malignant. Malignant meningiomas may grow rapidly, leading to symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (postural headache, nausea, papilledema). Meningiomas appear as well-circumscribed, extra-axia l (outside of the brain parenchyma) masses that compress the underlying parenchyma. They demonstrate uniform enhancement on CT imaging. Definitive diagnosis requires histologic examination of the tissue, which will demonstrate spindle cells arranged in a whorled pattern with psammoma bodies. Treatment may include radiation and/or surgica l resection to alleviate the tumora l mass effect, if significant.

distractor_explanations.A: Astrocytoma is a primary CNS neoplasm that can occur as a benign pilocytic astrocytoma in children or malignant glioblastoma multiforme (Choice C) in adults. These highly malignant tumors appear as intra-axial masses in the cerebral hemispheres, which typically demonstrate areas of necrosis and can spread to the opposite hemisphere across the corpus callosum.
distractor_explanations.B: Ependymoma is a CNS neoplasm formed from ependymal cells. Location typical ly involves the fourth ventricle. Histologic characteristics include perivascular pseudorosettes formed by malignant cells arranged around a blood vessel.
distractor_explanations.E: Schwannoma are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells in peripheral nerve sheaths. They commonly affect the facial and vestibulococh lear nerves, and mass effect may result in sensorineural hearing loss or ataxia. They are associated with neurofibromatosis 2.

explanation.educational_objective: Meningiomas are benign CNS tumors arising from the meninges that may compress the brain or spinal cord, and cause focal neurological deficits as well as seizures. Neuroimaging typically demonstrates a spherica l and well-circumscribed uniformly enhancing mass that indents the parenchyma. ., Clinical
