vignette.presentation:
38. A 72-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation comes to the emerge ncy departme nt 2 hours after the sudden onset of visual problems. He
states that he was fine until this afternoon when he started walking into objects that were located on his right side. While driving himself to the
hospital, he sideswiped a parked car. His only medication is daily aspirin. On arrival, his pulse is 68/min and irregular, and blood pressure is
140/70 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows a right homonymous hemianopia. Pupils are equal and reactive, and funduscopic examination
shows no abnormalities. Muscle strength and sensation are normal. Mental status examination shows no abnormal ities. Which of the following
arteries is most likely to be occluded?

question_stem: most likely to be occluded?

choices.text: Left anterior cerebral H) Right internal carotid
Left internal carotid I) Right middle cerebral
Left middle cerebral J) Right ophthalmic
Left ophthalmic K) Right posterior cerebral

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cerebral infarctions, or strokes, occur as a result of ischemic or hemorrhagic loss of blood supply to the brain. Approximately 80% to 85% of strokes are ischemic, common ly arising from thromboembo lic disease, whereas 15% to 20% of strokes are hemorrhagic because of blood vessel rupture. Risk factors for stroke include smoking, hypertension, diabetes, carotid or intracranial atherosclerotic disease, history of hypercoagulability, atrial fibrillation, and advanced age. Classically, strokes manifest as a neurologic deficit related to the affected part of the brain. Occlusion of the left posterior cerebra l artery (PCA) explains this patient's deficits. The PCA supplies much of the occipita l lobes as well as the inferomedia l temporal lobe, posteromedia l parietal lobe, thalamus, and parts of the brainstem. Occlusion of the left PCA typically leads to right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing (as a result of damage of the left primary visual cortex). Right homonymous hemianopia likely explains this patient's car accident. Occlusion of the left PCA may also result in right hemisensory deficit (caused by thalamus damage) and right hemiparesis (caused by damage to the cerebral peduncles in the midbrain). As well, damage to the left parietal cortex may occur and lead to agraphia, acalculia, finger agnosia, and left-right disorientation (Gerstmann syndrome).

vignette.presentation:
39. A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 14-day history of progressively severe headaches, mild neck soreness, and
photophobia. Twelve weeks ago, she was treated with x-ray radiation therapy and methotrexate, vincristine, procarbazine, and prednisone for
stage IVB Hodgkin disease with a large anterior mediastinal mass; the only complication of therapy was a brief episode of fever and neutropenia.
Her temperature now is 37.8°C (100°F). She does not appear acutely ill. Examination shows a mildly rigid neck. Neurologic examination shows no
papilledema. Lymph nodes, liver, and spleen are not palpable. Cardiopulmonary exam ination and x-rays of the chest show normal findings. Serum
glucose concentration is 70 mg/dL. Results of lumbar puncture show:
Glucose 15 mg/dL
Protein 120 mg/dL
Leukocyte count 500/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 10%
Monocytes 90%
Erythrocyte count 0/mm3
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Amphotericin B is the most appropriate therapy for Cryptococcus neoformans, which is an encapsulated, nondimorphic yeast and common opportunistic pathogen in immunocompromised patients. Malignancy (especially lymphoma or leukemia), HIV/AIDS, solid organ transplantation, sarcoidosis, cirrhosis, and chronic corticosteroid therapy are risk factors for infection. It can cause cryptococcal meningitis, encephalitis, and pulmonary cryptococcosis. Transmission is through inhalation, with risk for dissemination to the brain and meninges, as well as other distal sites. Pulmonary cryptococcosis typically presents with a low-grade, intermittent fever and nonspecific respiratory symptoms. Central nervous system involvement can cause headache, nuchal rigidity, photophobia, and progressive encephalopathy. Dermatologic spread can occur with pustular, papular, nodular, or ulcerated lesions. Diagnosis is made by analysis of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), sputum, urine, and/or blood. Histologic examination may show yeast cells with narrow-based budding and a bright red inner capsule on staining with mucicarmine or periodic acid-Schiff. In cryptococcal meningitis, lumbar puncture classically demonstrates an increased opening pressure, increased CSF protein, and a mononuclear cell pleocytosis. Amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for cryptococca l meningitis or severe pulmonary cryptococcosis in an immunocompromised patient Clinical Correct Answer: B. distractor_explanations.A: Intramuscular meperidine is an opioid used to manage acute pain or postoperative shivering. It does not play a role in the management of cryptococcal meningitis. Intravenous ceftriaxone (Choice C) is utilized in the treatment of bacterial meningitis, along with vancomycin and, depending on patient age, ampicillin. Bacterial meningitis presents acutely with fever, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status in a toxic-appearing patient. While immunosuppressed patients are at risk for bacterial meningitis, this patient's subacute history of mild symptoms is more consistent with cryptococca l meningitis. Additionally, CSF analysis in bacterial meningitis would show a neutrophilic predominance. Intravenous methylprednisolone (Choice D) is used in the treatment of allergic or autoimmune reactions, multiple sclerosis exacerbations, and a variety of other conditions. Multiple sclerosis presents with various neurologic lesions occurring over varying periods of time, with an acute exacerbation defined as a new neurologic impairment associated with a new brain or spinal cord lesion on MRI. It does not typically present with signs of meningeal irritation. Additionally, CSF in multiple sclerosis consists of a lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal protein concentration, and the presence of oligoclonal bands. Intravenous penicillin G (Choice E) can be used to treat a variety of bacterial infections, including neurosyphilis, which can present with headache, altered mental status, vision changes, cranial neuropathies, progressive dementia, and possible brain gummas (eg, focal areas of inflammation). Arteritis can also occur, leading to brain ischemia and infarction. CSF evaluation will show a lymphocytic pleocytosis and increased protein concentration.

vignette.presentation:
40. A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of moderate pain, numbness, and tingling in her right hand. She states
that the pain is worse at night and is not relieved with acetaminophen or ibuprofen. She has a 10-year history of chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto)
thyroiditis treated with thyroid hormone therapy. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, tapping the palmar surface of the right wrist
elicits a tingling sensation in the thumb and index fingers. Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone concentratio n is 2 µU/ml. Which of the following
is the most likely mechanism of this patient's symptoms?

question_stem: the most likely mechanism of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Immunologic damage to the brachia! nerve
Immunologic damage to the median nerve
Immunologic damage to the radial nerve
Immunologic damage to the ulnar nerve
Mechanical entrapment of the brachia I nerve
Mechanical entrapment of the median nerve
Mechanical entrapment of the radial nerve
Mechanical entrapment of the ulnar nerve

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Mechanical entrapment of the median nerve leading to carpal tunnel syndrome is the most likely mechanism of this patient's symptoms. The carpal tunnel describes a conduit in the wrist that is formed by the flexor retinaculum anteriorly and the carpal bones posteriorly. Both the median nerve and the flexor tendons of the fingers travel through this canal. Increased pressure in this canal can lead to compression of the median nerve, resulting in paresthesias of the first three digits, primarily on the palmar surface. When severe, weakness of the thumb with atrophy of the thenar eminence may occur. The Tinel test involves tapping the volar surface of the wrist in the midline. A positive test, as in this case, leads to tingling in the first two digits and occasionally the third digit, which corresponds with the distribution of the median nerve. This condition occurs commonly in those with jobs that involve repetitive wrist movement such as typing, but it can be idiopathic. It commonly develops in obese patients and is more common in women. Nighttime symptoms are frequently encountered, and the initial treatment requires wrist splints worn at night. Refractory or severe symptoms may be referred for surgical intervention.

distractor_explanations.D: or ulnar nerves may occur in neuralgic amyotrophy, also called Parsonage-Turner syndrome, which is thought to be related to immune-mediated damage of the nerves of the brachia! plexus. It most commonly involves the nerves of the upper or middle brachia! plexus but can involve more distal, singular nerves. Patients develop debilitating pain and weakness that gradually improve over months Clinical Correct Answer: F. Mechanical entrapment of the median nerve leading to carpal tunnel syndrome is the most likely mechanism of this patient's symptoms. The carpal tunnel describes a conduit in the wrist that is formed by the flexor retinaculum anteriorly and the carpal bones posteriorly. Both the median nerve and the flexor tendons of the fingers travel through this canal. Increased pressure in this canal can lead to compression of the median nerve, resulting in paresthesias of the first three digits, primarily on the palmar surface. When severe, weakness of the thumb with atrophy of the thenar eminence may occur. The Tinel test involves tapping the volar surface of the wrist in the midline. A positive test, as in this case, leads to tingling in the first two digits and occasional ly the third digit, which corresponds with the distribution of the median nerve. This condition occurs commonly in those with jobs that involve repetitive wrist movement such as typing, but it can be idiopathic. It commonly develops in obese patients and is more common in women. Nighttime symptoms are frequently encountered, and the initial treatment requires wrist splints worn at night. Refractory or severe symptoms may be referred for surgical intervention. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, E, G, and H. Immunologic damage to the brachia! (Choice A), median (Choice B), radial (Choice C), or ulnar (Choice D) nerves may occur in neuralgic amyotrophy, also called Parsonage-Turner syndrome, which is thought to be related to immune-mediated damage of the nerves of the brachia! plexus. It most commonly involves the nerves of the upper or middle brachia! plexus but can involve more distal, singular nerves. Patients develop debilitating pain and weakness that gradually improve over months. Mechanical entrapment of the brachia! nerve (Choice E), or the brachia! plexus, can result in several distinct clinical syndromes depending upon the location of entrapment. Lower trunk entrapment can result in myotomal weakness in the distribution of CB to T1 while entrapment of the upper trunk causes weakness in muscles innervated by the CS and C6 nerve roots. Mechanical entrapment of the radial nerve (Choice G) commonly occurs at the spiral groove where the radial nerve wraps posteriorly around the humerus. It results in wrist drop, impaired finger extension, and loss of sensation over the dorsum of the hand and forearm. Mechanical entrapment of the ulnar nerve (Choice H) commonly occurs at the medial epicondyle of the elbow and results in sensory loss of the fourth and fifth digits, with occasional weakness of the interosseous muscles in the hand, resulting in impaired grip strength. Compression can occur at the wrist but is less common.

explanation.educational_objective: Carpal tunnel syndrome commonly results from compression of the median nerve within the carpal tunnel, which is formed by the carpal bones and the flexor retinaculum. Symptoms include paresthesias of the first three digits of the affected hand. Treatment is initially with wrist splints, but surgical intervention and carpal tunnel release may be required in some cases. ., Exam Section : Item 41 of 50 Clinical

vignette.presentation:
41. After falling from a horse during a steeplechase, a 42-year-old man has immediate paralysis in all four extremities and has loss of sensation below
the clavicles bilaterally. On examination by paramedics , he is alert, dyspneic, and unable to move his extremities or trunk. His pulse is 98/min,
respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. After transport to a trauma center, his sensory examination returns to normal, and
he regains normal strength of the arms and forearms, although the hands and lower extremities remain weak. Examination shows bladder
distention. An MRI of the cervical spine shows contusion with edema of the spinal cord at C3 and C4. Plain x-rays of the cervical spine show a
nondisplaced fracture of the vertebral body of C3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Surgical exploration of the cervical spine

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Spinal cord compression can occur in the setting of trauma, malignancy with vertebral metastases, and infections (eg, epidural abscess). Its presentation depends on the level of the lesion and the degree of spinal cord compression. Traumatic spinal cord injury is typically caused by fracture or dislocation of the vertebrae. Acute traumatic spinal cord injuries typically cause immediate compression or shearing of the spinal cord, with a secondary injury of the spinal cord occurring after the initial injury because of consequent inflammation, edema, and ischemia. Symptoms include back or neck pain, flaccid paralysis, numbness, bowel and bladder incontinence or retention, and hyporeflexia. Patients may also develop neurogenic shock, depending on the level of injury, with bradycardia and hypotension secondary to injury to the sympathetic outflow tract, as well as respiratory failure caused by diaphragmatic paralysis. Diagnosis is classically made using MRI of the spine, as well as spinal x-rays or CT to visualize skeletal abnormalities. Management includes clinical stabilization, and the use of intravenous glucocorticoid therapy to decrease spinal cord edema. Patients may also require intubation and mechanical ventilation, vasopressor support, cardiac pacing, and/or surgical spine stabilization.

distractor_explanations.A: Intravenous ceftriaxone therapy is used in the treatment of bacterial meningitis, along with vancomycin and, depending on patient age, ampicillin. Bacterial meningitis presents acutely with fever, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status in a toxic-appearing patient, althoug.h i.t .ca n also cause focal neurologic deficits • . - - •• • - • •• •• - - . • - - - • . • • • • • • • - , • . • • ••• • :1 • • • • •• . - . . • • •• , - • r r Exam Section : Item 41 of 50 Clinical Correct Answer: D. Its presentation depends on the level of the lesion and the degree of spinal cord compression. Traumatic spinal cord injury is typically caused by fracture or dislocation of the vertebrae. Acute traumatic spinal cord injuries typically cause immediate compression or shearing of the spinal cord, with a secondary injury of the spinal cord occurring after the initial injury because of consequent inflammation, edema, and ischemia. Symptoms include back or neck pain, flaccid paralysis, numbness, bowel and bladder incontinence or retention, and hyporeflexia. Patients may also develop neurogenic shock, depending on the level of injury, with bradycardia and hypotension secondary to injury to the sympathetic outflow tract, as well as respiratory failure caused by diaphragmatic paralysis. Diagnosis is classically made using MRI of the spine, as well as spinal x-rays or CT to visualize skeletal abnormalities. Management includes clinical stabilization, and the use of intravenous glucocorticoid therapy to decrease spinal cord edema. Patients may also require intubation and mechanical ventilation, vasopressor support, cardiac pacing, and/or surgical spine stabilization. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, E, and F. Intravenous ceftriaxone therapy (Choice A) is used in the treatment of bacterial meningitis, along with vancomycin and, depending on patient age, ampicillin. Bacterial meningitis presents acutely with fever, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status in a toxic-appearing patient, although it can also cause focal neurologic deficits. Intravenous labetalol therapy (Choice B) is used in hypertensive urgency and emergency, which present with increased blood pressures, typically with the systolic blood pressure greater than 180 mm Hg. End-organ damage is characteristic of hypertensive emergency. This patient's blood pressure is near normal and does not require correction with intravenous medication. Intravenous mannitol therapy (Choice C) can be used to decrease cerebral edema in the setting of traumatic brain injury, since it is an osmotic diuretic that draws excess fluid out from tissues and excretes it from the body. It plays less of a role in controlling edema of the spinal cord, and its onset of action is longer than that of methylprednisolone. Oral prednisone therapy (Choice E) is used in rheumatic diseases, allergic reactions, and inflammatory or immune reactions. While it could decrease the spinal cord edema seen in this patient because of its anti-inflammatory properties, its onset of action is longer than methylprednisolone. Surgical exploration of the cervical spine (Choice F) is typically performed in the setting of an unstable vertebral fracture or dislocation. It may be necessary in this case; however, glucocorticoids can be administered immediately to begin temporizing the effect of the lesion.

explanation.educational_objective: Acute traumatic spinal cord injury occurs in the setting of compression or shearing of the spinal cord; however, subsequent injury can occur because of inflammation, edema, and ischemia of the cord. Initial treatment with intravenous glucocorticoids is critical, and some patients with unstable fractures or dislocation may require surgical stabilization Clinical
explanation.concept: Acute traumatic spinal cord injury occurs in the setting of compression or shearing of the spinal cord; however, subsequent injury can occur because of inflammation, edema, and ischemia of the cord. I

vignette.presentation:
42. A 47-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police after he was found in a state of confusion outside a convenience store. He
says he feels anxious. He has not had fever, headache, abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. He has a 3-year history of uncontrolled
hypertension. He has no allergies and takes no medications. He does not smoke. He usually drinks 12 to 14 beers daily. He says he has never
used illicit drugs. He is disheveled and agitated and picks at imaginary things in the air. He is disoriented to person, place, and time. His
temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 160/105 mm Hg. Examination shows diaphoresis and tremulousness.
There is seborrhea and rosacea of the face. There are no signs of head trauma. The neck is supple. There is diffuse hyperreflexia. Babinski sign is
absent bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient has developed delirium tremens, a serious complication of alcohol withdrawal. Alcohol increases the central nervous system activity of y-aminobutyric acid (GABA), the main inhibitory neurotransmitter. Abrupt discontinuation of alcohol therefore leads to sympathetic overdrive. Uncomplicated alcohol withdrawal typically presents with tremors, anxiety, restlessness, diffuse hyperreflexia, headache, nausea, and diaphoresis, which can occur hours after the cessation of alcohol use. Delirium tremens, the most concerning and life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal, involves severe confusion and disorientation, fluctuations in consciousness, agitation, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instability (variable heart rate and blood pressure with hyperthermia). Delirium tremens typically begins 2 to 5 days after the patient's last alcoholic drink. Delirium tremens is managed supportively with benzodiazepines (GABAA receptor agonists) to address the psychomotor agitation associated with withdrawal and prevent the worsening of withdrawal manifestations. Management also includes fluid resuscitation, nutritional supplementation, and frequent assessment including vital sign checks.

distractor_explanations.A: Acute subdural hematoma refers to bleeding between the dura and arachnoid membranes, most commonly caused by head trauma in elderly patients and persons with alcohol use disorder. Patients typically present with a declining neurologic status or coma Clinical Correct Answer: E. This patient has developed delirium tremens, a serious complication of alcohol withdrawal. Alcohol increases the central nervous system activity of y-aminobutyric acid (GABA), the main inhibitory neurotransmitter. Abrupt discontinuation of alcohol therefore leads to sympathetic overdrive. Uncomplicated alcohol withdrawal typically presents with tremors, anxiety, restlessness, diffuse hyperreflexia, headache, nausea, and diaphoresis, which can occur hours after the cessation of alcohol use. Delirium tremens, the most concerning and life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal, involves severe confusion and disorientation, fluctuations in consciousness, agitation, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instability (variable heart rate and blood pressure with hyperthermia). Delirium tremens typically begins 2 to 5 days after the patient's last alcoholic drink. Delirium tremens is managed supportively with benzodiazepines (GABAA receptor agonists) to address the psychomotor agitation associated with withdrawal and prevent the worsening of withdrawal manifestations. Management also includes fluid resuscitation, nutritional supplementation, and frequent assessment including vital sign checks. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, F, G, and H. Acute subdural hematoma (Choice A) refers to bleeding between the dura and arachnoid membranes, most commonly caused by head trauma in elderly patients and persons with alcohol use disorder. Patients typically present with a declining neurologic status or coma. This patient does not demonstrate signs of head trauma on physical examination, and sympathetic overdrive is more consistent with alcohol withdrawal. Alcohol intoxication (Choice B) can cause slurred speech, ataxia, emotional !ability, and memory lapses. Sympathetic overdrive is more consistent with alcohol withdrawal. Brief psychotic disorder (Choice C) is characterized by at least one acute psychotic symptom (eg, delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, disorganized behavior) lasting less than 1 month. Sympathetic overdrive and disorientation are more consistent with delirium tremens. Cocaine intoxication (Choice D) presents with euphoria and increased sympathetic tone, manifesting as tachycardia and hypertension, pupillary dilation, and restlessness. Hallucinations may occur, though disorientation is more consistent with delirium tremens. This patient endorses alcohol but not cocaine use.
distractor_explanations.F: Encephalitis refers to inflammation (caused by infection or autoimmune response) of the brain parenchyma and may present with confusion, agitation, and/or hallucinations, along with headache, photophobia, and/or seizures. However, sympathetic overdrive and a history of heavy alcohol use are more consistent with delirium tremens.
distractor_explanations.G: Hypoglycemia may manifest with sympathoadrenal symptoms (eg, tremors, palpitations, diaphoresis, mild hypertension, mild tachycardia) along with cognitive impairment. This patient lacks known risk factors for hypoglycemia and has a history of heavy alcohol use.

explanation.educational_objective: Delirium tremens is a life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal related to decreased GABA activity that presents with severe confusion, agitation, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instability along with other features of sympathetic overdrive (eg, diaphoresis, tremors, diffuse hyperreflexia). Benzodiazepines are GABAA receptor agonists utilized to treat agitation during withdrawal and prevent the worsening of withdrawal manifestations Clinical
explanation.concept: Delirium tremens is a life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal related to decreased GABA activity that presents with severe confusion, agitation, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instab

vignette.presentation:
43. A 6-month-o ld boy is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of spasms. The child's father and a paternal aunt are mildly retarded and have
seizures. The father has acneiform lesions on his cheeks, but without comedones. Examination of the patient shows five 1- to 2-cm depigmented
areas on the chest and flexor surfaces of the upper and lower extremities. A CT scan of the head shows a subependyma l calcification near the
foramen of Monro on the left. Which of the following is the most likely diagnos is?

question_stem: the most likely diagnos is?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder characterized by benign tumors in several organ systems. Hamartomas can form in the soft tissue (leading to Shagreen patches, or subcutaneous oval nodules) or brain (leading to epilepsy and intellectua l disability). Cardiac rhabdomyomas (leading to mitral regurgitation) and renal angiomyolipomas are also common. Other typical dermatologic findings include ash leaf spots (hypomelanotic macules) and angiofibromas, which are acneiform lesions without comedones (clogged hair follicles). Subependymal giant cell tumors are common, which typically demonstrate calcification and may increase the likelihood of developing seizures. Though these tumors are benign, patients are at risk for developing malignancies in the soft tissues, brain, or kidney. Diagnosis is typically clinical but may be confirmed by genetic testing indicating a mutated TSC gene. Management requires anticonvulsant medication for seizures and surgica l resection of rapidly growing or symptomatic tumors.

distractor_explanations.A: Idiopathic hypercalcemia is a rare condition that typically presents in infancy with developmenta l delay, constipation, polyuria, vomiting, feeding problems, and weight loss. Adults can rarely demonstrate an idiopathic increase in vitamin D and consequen tly become hypercalcemic. Neither variant is hereditary nor associated with dermatologic findings.
distractor_explanations.B: Neurofibromatosis is a hereditary neurocutaneous disorder. Type 1 presents with cutaneous neurofibromas (benign neoplasms derived from neural crest cells), cafe au lait spots, pigmented iris hamartomas (Lisch nodules), optic gliomas, and pheochromocytomas. Type 2 presents with cutaneous neurofibromas, bilateral vestibular schwannomas, additional schwannomas of the cranial nerves or in the spinal cord, intracranial meningiomas, and neuropathy. Subependymal brain lesions are atypical, and the dermatologic findings differ between tuberous sclerosis and neurofibromatosis. Sturge-Weber syndrome (Choice C) is a neurocutaneous disorder that presents with the proliferation of capillary-size blood vessels, seen on examination as nevus flammeus (a benign birthmark also known as a port-wine stain), angiomatosis of the leptomeninges (leading to seizures, intellectual disability, focal neurologic deficits), and episcleral hemangioma. The causative activating mutation of the GNAQ gene is typically sporadic rather than inherited. TORCH syndrome (Choice D) refers to fetal infection by any of a group of organisms: Toxop/asma gondii, rubella virus, cytomegalovirus, or Herpes simplex virus, and others. Newborns may demonstrate a variety of consequent symptoms, which often include fever, feeding difficulties, petechiae, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, deafness, and/or vision abnormalities. The combination of characteristic dermatologic findings and seizures 6 months after birth (outside of the perinatal period) is more consistent with tuberous sclerosis.

explanation.educational_objective: Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder characterized by benign tumors in several organ systems. Patients typically present with hamartomas of the skin and brain, cardiac rhabdomyomas, and renal angiomyolipomas. Dermatologic findings include hypomelanotic macules (ash leaf spots) and acneiform lesions called angiofibromas, and neurologic findings include subependymal giant cell tumors, which may lead to seizures Clinical

vignette.presentation:
44. A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive difficulty climbing stairs, generalized muscle pain, and dry
mouth. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia . Current medications include atorvastatin, atenolol, and glyburide. He
has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. At his last visit 6 weeks ago, an x-ray of the chest showed a solitary lung nodule. Today, his
pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 136/82 mm Hg. Examination of the lower extremities shows bilateral proximal
weakness and hyporeflexia. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies show an incremental increase in the amplitude of evoked motor
response. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented these symptoms?

question_stem: most likely to have prevented these symptoms?

choices.text: More aggressive treatment of high blood pressure
More aggressive treatment of high blood pressure

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is an uncommon neurologic condition that affects neuromuscu lar junction transmission. Normally, action potentials lead to depolarization in the terminal bouton of the axon. Voltage-gated calcium channels consequently open and allow calcium influx, which triggers the exocytosis of neurotransmitter-filled vesicles into the synaptic cleft. Patients with LEMS possess antibodies to voltage-gated calcium channels on presynaptic lower motoneurons, which decreases calcium influx and the subsequent release of acetylcholine. This patient with a smoking history and proximal muscle weakness, with a known lung nodule, likely has paraneoplastic autoantibody production against voltage-gated calcium channels, causing LEMS in the setting of small cell lung cancer. Patients may also have depressed or absent deep tendon reflexes. The muscle weakness typically improves with exercise as small amounts of acetylcholine accumulate in the synaptic cleft over time, increasing the frequency of postsynaptic action potentials in skeletal muscle cells. This can be seen on nerve conduction studies, as well. Autonomic symptoms such as decreased salivation (and consequent dry mouth) may also occur. The diagnosis may be confirmed with nerve conduction studies and electromyography with exercise testing. In this patient, smoking cessation would have prevented the development of lung cancer and consequent LEMS.

distractor_explanations.B: Daily aspirin therapy is used in the prophylaxis and treatment of cardiovascu lar disease, such as coronary artery disease and stroke. It does not play a role in the prevention of lung cancer development. Discontinuing atenolol therapy (Choice C) or atorvastatin therapy (Choice D) would not have prevented this patient from developing lung cancer and subsequent LEMS. While ~-adrenergic blocker therapy can cause fatigue and statin therapy can cause myopathy, neither causes hyporeflexia Clinical i ~.. • . - .. -~ C) Discontinuing atenolol therapy D) Discontinuing atorvastat in therapy E) More aggressive treatment of high blood pressure Correct Answer: A. Patients may also have depressed or absent deep tendon reflexes. The diagnosis may be confirmed with nerve conduction studies and electromyography with exercise testing. Daily aspirin therapy (Choice B) is used in the prophylaxis and treatment of cardiovascu lar disease, such as coronary artery disease and stroke. It does not play a role in the prevention of lung cancer development. Discontinuing atenolol therapy (Choice C) or atorvastatin therapy (Choice D) would not have prevented this patient from developing lung cancer and subsequent LEMS. While ~-adrenergic blocker therapy can cause fatigue and statin therapy can cause myopathy, neither causes hyporeflexia. More aggressive treatment of high blood pressure (Choice E) is an incorrect choice, as it would not have prevented this patient from developing lung cancer. Additionally, this patient's blood pressure is well-controlled.

explanation.educational_objective: Patients with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome possess antibodies to voltage-gated calcium channels on presynaptic lower motoneurons, which decrease calcium influx and acetylcholine release. vignette.presentation:
45. A 30-year-old construction worker comes to the physician because of constant midlower back pain for 1 month. He has no leg pain. Straight-leg
raising causes discomfort only in the low back. Sensorimotor examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in
management?

question_stem:
the most appropriate next step in
management?

choices.text: Restriction of heavy lifting until the pain resolves and instruction in proper body mechanics
Vocational rehabilitation and change in occupation
Epidural injection of corticosteroids and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Low back pain is a common condition that is self-limited for many individuals. There are many causes of low back pain, and it rarely can be caused by a serious illness that requires medical treatment or surgical intervention. Risk factors for low back pain include strenuous work, heavy lifting, trauma, obesity, and age. Most patients present with a lumbosacral strain caused by heavy lifting or extended periods of sitting. In patients with a history of trauma or osteoporosis, vertebral compression fractures or other vertebral fractures are a consideration. Signs and symptoms that increase the risk for an urgent medical or surgical cause of low back pain include fever, focal midline spinal tenderness, weight loss, pain increased at night, focal neurologic symptoms, and urinary incontinence or urinary retention. In this patient with no sensorimotor abnormalities, the most likely cause of his low back pain is a lumbosacral strain from heavy lifting and construction work. Most patients with lumbosacral pain will improve within 4 weeks with short-term symptomatic therapy, including pain control, restriction of heavy lifting, physical therapy, and instructions on proper body mechanics, allowing for an early return to activity. Prolonged periods of inactivity and bed rest are to be avoided.

distractor_explanations.B: Bed rest and oral analgesics would not be the most appropriate management. While oral analgesics can help with pain, early movement and physical therapy has been shown to decrease pain and expedite return of function. Bed rest will increase pain and prolong time to recovery. Vocational rehabilitation and change in occupation (Choice C) would not be appropriate before a trial of physical therapy. The patient is young and will likely recover after a period of restricting heavy lifting and physical therapy to prevent further injuries. Epidural injection of corticosteroids and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (Choice D) would also be inappropriate prior to a period of physical therapy and restriction of heavy lifting. Typically, physical therapy and rehabilitation are sufficient to treat lumbosacral strain in a majority of patients Clinical Correct Answer: A. This patient does not demonstrate any signs of neurologic dysfunction.

vignette.presentation:
46. A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of deep aching neck and shoulder pain, progressive weakness of his
hands, and poor coordination. Two years ago, he had a whiplash injury that resolved without treatment over a 3-month period. Neurologic
examination shows hyporeflexia of the upper extremities. He has atrophy of intrinsic hand muscles bilaterally. There is asymmetr ic decreased
strength of grip and finger abduction and extension. Sensation to pinprick is decreased over the upper torso and shoulders. Which of the following
is the most likely cause of these findings?

question_stem: the most likely cause of these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Syringomyelia refers to a progressive ly expanding cystic lesion involving midline spinal cord structures, most commonly in the cervical or thoracic spinal cord. Syringomyelia may be associated with congenita l malformations such as Chiari malformation type I, spinal cord infections, autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, neoplasms, or spinal cord trauma. Syringomyelia typically compresses spinothalamic fibers decussating in the anterior white commissure. Consequent ly, patients present with deficits in pain and temperature sensation in the bilateral upper extremities and/or torso. (Since the ascending spinothalamic tracts in the lateral spinal cord are unaffected, sensation in the lower body is intact.) Neuropathic pain in the upper extremities may occur. The lesion can expand to compress the bilateral anterior horns (the location of the cell bodies of lower motoneurons). Therefore, patients may present with a lower motoneuron pattern of dysfunction in the bilateral upper extremities (eg, decreased muscle tone, hyporeflexia, early muscle atrophy). The cyst may progressively expand to compress the lateral corticospinal tract in severe cases, leading to an upper motoneuron pattern of dysfunction in the lower body.

distractor_explanations.A: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that affects the anterior horns and the lateral corticospinal tract. Subsequent ly, patients demonstrate a combination of upper and lower motoneuron findings in an asymmetric distribution. Sensory impairment is atypical, and a pattern of dysfunction that can be localized to a single lesion within the cervical or thoracic spinal cord is more consistent with a syringomye lia. Anterior spinal cord syndrome (Choice B) results from ischemia of the anterior spinal artery (eg, by thrombosis or trauma), leading to dama e to the cortices inal, s inothalamic, and autonomic tracts. The s ndrome manifests with loss of ain and tern erature sensation Clinical Correct Answer: F. Syringomyelia may be associated with congenita l malformations such as Chiari malformation type I, spinal cord infections, autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, neoplasms, or spinal cord trauma. Syringomyelia typically compresses spinothalamic fibers decussating in the anterior white commissure. Consequent ly, patients present with deficits in pain and temperature sensation in the bilateral upper extremities and/or torso. (Since the ascending spinothalamic tracts in the lateral spinal cord are unaffected, sensation in the lower body is intact.) Neuropathic pain in the upper extremities may occur. The lesion can expand to compress the bilateral anterior horns (the location of the cell bodies of lower motoneurons). Therefore, patients may present with a lower motoneuron pattern of dysfunction in the bilateral upper extremities (eg, decreased muscle tone, hyporeflexia, early muscle atrophy). The cyst may progressively expand to compress the lateral corticospinal tract in severe cases, leading to an upper motoneuron pattern of dysfunction in the lower body. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, and E. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Choice A) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that affects the anterior horns and the lateral corticospinal tract. Subsequent ly, patients demonstrate a combination of upper and lower motoneuron findings in an asymmetric distribution. Sensory impairment is atypical, and a pattern of dysfunction that can be localized to a single lesion within the cervical or thoracic spinal cord is more consistent with a syringomye lia. Anterior spinal cord syndrome (Choice B) results from ischemia of the anterior spinal artery (eg, by thrombosis or trauma), leading to damage to the corticospina l, spinothalamic, and autonomic tracts. The syndrome manifests with loss of pain and temperature sensation and motor function below the level of the lesion, along with autonomic dysfunction. Syringomyelia causes loss of pain and temperature sensation localized to the upper extremities, and autonomic dysfunction is uncommon in syringomyelia because of the lateral location of autonomic cell bodies. Brown-Sequard syndrome (Choice C), hemisection of the spinal cord, damages the anterior horn along with the corticospina l tract, dorsal column-medial lemniscus tract, and spinothalamic tract. Patients typically present with contralateral impairment in pain and temperature sensation, ipsilateral deficits in other sensory domains, and an ipsilateral upper motoneuron pattern of dysfunction below the level of the lesion. The dorsal column-medial lemniscus (DCML) tract is typically unaffected in syringomye lia. Posterior cord syndrome (Choice D) results from ischemia of the posterior spinal artery, leading to ipsilateral DCML tract damage. Patients present with ipsilateral sensory loss of proprioception, fine touch, and vibration below the level of the lesion. The DCML tract is typically unaffected in syringomyelia. Subacute combined degeneration (Choice E), resulting from vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency, occurs as a result of demyelination of 12 the spinocerebel lar tracts, lateral corticospinal tracts, and dorsal columns. explanation.educational_objective: Syringomyelia features a cystic cavity in the central cervical or thoracic spinal cord, which affects midline structures such as the anterior white commissure (decussation of the spinothalamic tracts) and the anterior horns (cell bodies of lower motoneurons). Patients with syringomyelia may present with deficits in pain and temperature sensation and a lower motoneuron pattern of dysfunction in the bilateral upper extremities and/or torso Exam Section : Item 47 of 50 Clinical
explanation.concept: Syringomyelia features a cystic cavity in the central cervical or thoracic spinal cord, which affects midline structures such as the anterior white commissure (decussation of the spinothalamic tracts)

vignette.presentation:
47. A previously healthy 13-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department
1 hour after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that occurred at school. Her teacher
noted that the seizure was preceded by jerking of the right arm. She had a similar
episode 8 months ago. Examination at that time showed no abnormalities, and no
treatment was begun. She was born in Mexico, and she and her parents have
made occasional trips to rural Mexico; their last visit was 2 years ago. She was
lethargic on arrival to the emergency department, but she is now awake and alert.
Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). The neck is supple. Neurologic examination
shows no abnormalities. Her leukocyte count is 6400/mm3. A CT scan of the head
is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate screening test for family
members of this patient?

question_stem:
the most appropriate screening test for family
members of this patient?

choices.text: Examination of the stool for ova and parasites

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neurocysticercosis is a central nervous system (CNS) infection caused by the pork tapeworm Taenia so/ium that occurs most common ly in endemic rural regions of Latin America, Asia, and Africa. Symptoms include headache, seizures, signs of increased intracranial pressure, and, rarely, altered vision. Some patients are asymptomatic, while other patients may present with muscle or subcutaneous nodules. Typical manifestations on CT or MRI include cystic, ring-enhancing, calcified lesions in the brain parenchyma, meninges, ventricles, spinal cord, and/or orbit. A scolex (larval head) may also be demonstrated on imaging. Treatment includes symptomatic management of increased intracranial pressure and seizures, antiparasitic therapy, and/or steroids. As this patient has primarily traveled with her family, they are Exam Section : Item 47 of 50 Clinical Correct Answer: A. Neurocysticercosis is a central nervous system (CNS) infection caused by the pork tapeworm Taenia so/ium that occurs most common ly in endemic rural regions of Latin America, Asia, and Africa. Symptoms include headache, seizures, signs of increased intracranial pressure, and, rarely, altered vision. Some patients are asymptomatic, while other patients may present with muscle or subcutaneous nodules. Typical manifestations on CT or MRI include cystic, ring-enhancing, calcified lesions in the brain parenchyma, meninges, ventricles, spinal cord, and/or orbit. A scolex (larval head) may also be demonstrated on imaging. Treatment includes symptomatic management of increased intracranial pressure and seizures, antiparasitic therapy, and/or steroids. As this patient has primarily traveled with her family, they are similarly at an increased risk for neurocysticercosis and should be screened for the infection with examination of the stool for ova and parasites.

distractor_explanations.B: Rapid plasma reagin is used to screen for infection with Treponema pal/idum, which causes syphilis. Neurosyphilis may present with headache, altered mental status, vision changes, cranial neuropathies, progressive dementia, and possible brain gummas (eg, focal areas of inflammation). Gummas can be seen on neuroimaging as large, enhancing lesions, but they are not typically calcified. Stool culture for Coccidioides immitis (Choice C), a dimorphic fungus present in the Southwestern United States and Central and South America, could be used to evaluate for coccidioidomycosis. Coccidioidal meningitis presents subacutely or chronically with headache, nausea and emesis, vision changes, and altered mental status. Neuroimaging may show hydrocephalus or vasculitis with associated infarctions, but it rarely demonstrates intracranial, ring enhancing, or calcified lesions. Stool culture for Histop/asma capsu/atum (Choice D) can be used to screen for histoplasmosis. H. capsu/atum, an endemic mycosis, is Exam Section : Item 47 of 50 Clinical Stool culture for Histop/asma capsu/atum (Choice D) can be used to screen for histoplasmosis. H. capsu/atum, an endemic mycosis, is primarily found in the Midwestern United States. Disseminated infection most commonly occurs in immunosupp ressed patients, whereas isolated infection of the lungs is more common in immunocompetent patients. While disseminated histoplasmosis can present with multiple enhancing brain lesions, it would be unlikely in this otherwise healthy young patient. Stool culture for Toxop/asma gondii (Choice E) can be used to screen for toxoplasmosis. In immunocompeten t patients, the infection is generally asymptomatic, although it can present with a flu-like illness. In immunocomp romised patients, however, toxoplasmosis can lead to cerebral infection with multiple ring-enhancing brain lesions. This would be unlikely in this otherwise healthy young patient. Urine culture for cytomegalovirus (CMV) (Choice F) would not be useful in this scenario. While CMV can cause encephalitis in rare circumstances, it more commonly causes mononucleosis with fevers, fatigue, and cervical lymphadenopathy in an immunocompetent host. It does not present with brain lesions on neuroimaging. CT scan of the head (Choice G) could evaluate for neurocysticercosis in this patient's family members. However, it would unnecessarily expose them to radiation that could be avoided by utilizing the stool examination for ova and parasites to diagnose an infection, making it a less appropriate next step in management.

explanation.educational_objective: Neurocysticercosis is a CNS infection caused by the pork tapeworm Taenia so/ium that occurs in endemic rural regions of Latin America, Asia, and Africa and may infect immunocompetent patients. Typical manifestations on CT or MRI include cystic, ring-enhancing, calcified lesions in the brain parenchyma, meninges, ventricles, spinal cord, and/or orbit. Screening for the infection can be performed by examining the stool for ova and parasites Clinical
explanation.concept: Neurocysticercosis is a CNS infection caused by the pork tapeworm Taenia so/ium that occurs in endemic rural regions of Latin America, Asia, and Africa and may infect immunocompetent patients. Typical

vignette.presentation:
48. A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-week history of progressive weakness and numbness of the legs. This morning, she
had urinary incontinence. One year ago, she underwent resection of a medulloblastoma and placement of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt for residual
hydrocephalus; her postoperative course had been uncomplicated. Currently, she is drowsy and irritable. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F),
pulse is 82/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 126/54 mm Hg. Funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Examination of
the lower extremities shows weakness and diffuse sensory loss; deep tendon reflexes are decreased. Which of the following is the most likely
underlying mechanism for these symptoms?

question_stem:
the most likely
underlying mechanism for these symptoms?

choices.text: Metastatic spread of the cancer hematogenously
Metastatic spread of the cancer through cerebrospinal fluid pathways
Radiation necrosis of the brain stem
Thrombosis of the anterior spinal artery
Thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Metastatic spread of cancer through cerebrospina l fluid pathways is the mechanism behind this patient's development of cauda equina syndrome. Cauda equina syndrome occurs as a result of compression of the spinal nerve roots comprising the cauda equina. Often, such compression occurs because of malignancy (as in this case), trauma, disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spinal epidural abscess, or spinal epidural or subdural hematoma. Symptoms include lower extremity numbness, weakness, paralysis, hyporeflexia, perinea! anesthesia, fecal incontinence with poor rectal tone, and overflow incontinence marked by an inability to void with associated urinary retention. Emergent MRI of the lumbosacral spine is indicated to investigate the cause of cauda equina syndrome and to determine the necessity of surgical decompression. Initial treatment for patients with epidural spinal cord compression and neurologic deficits include symptomatic treatment, pain control, and glucocorticoid therapy prior to operative therapy. High-dose glucocorticoid therapy is helpful as a bridge to definitive therapy and may transiently improve neurologic function by decreasing edema at the site of cord compression.

distractor_explanations.A: Local recurrence of the medulloblastoma would cause neurologic deficits specific to the region of the brain being affected by the tumor. While, depending on the location, this could cause lower extremity weakness, it would cause hyperreflexia rather than hyporeflexia because of the involvement of the upper motoneuron. This patient's lower extremity hyporeflexia indicates a peripheral cause affecting the lower motoneuron. Metastatic spread of the cancer hematogenous ly (Choice B) would be more likely to cause foci of malignancy to develop in other or ans includin the bones, liver, or lun s. This is an uncommon com lication of medulloblastoma since extraneural metastases are Clinical Correct Answer: C. Metastatic spread of cancer through cerebrospinal fluid pathways is the mechanism behind this patient's development of cauda equina syndrome. Cauda equina syndrome occurs as a result of compression of the spinal nerve roots comprising the cauda equina. Often, such compression occurs because of malignancy (as in this case), trauma, disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spinal epidural abscess, or spinal epidural or subdural hematoma. Symptoms include lower extremity numbness, weakness, paralysis, hyporeflexia, perinea! anesthesia, fecal incontinence with poor rectal tone, and overflow incontinence marked by an inability to void with associated urinary retention. Emergent MRI of the lumbosacral spine is indicated to investigate the cause of cauda equina syndrome and to determine the necessity of surgical decompression. Initial treatment for patients with epidural spinal cord compression and neurologic deficits include symptomatic treatment, pain control, and glucocorticoid therapy prior to operative therapy. High-dose glucocorticoid therapy is helpful as a bridge to definitive therapy and may transiently improve neurologic function by decreasing edema at the site of cord compression. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, E, and F. Local recurrence of the medulloblastoma (Choice A) would cause neurologic deficits specific to the region of the brain being affected by the tumor. While, depending on the location, this could cause lower extremity weakness, it would cause hyperreflexia rather than hyporeflexia because of the involvement of the upper motoneuron. This patient's lower extremity hyporeflexia indicates a peripheral cause affecting the lower motoneuron. Metastatic spread of the cancer hematogenously (Choice B) would be more likely to cause foci of malignancy to develop in other organs including the bones, liver, or lungs. This is an uncommon complication of medulloblastoma since extraneural metastases are rare with this particular tumor. Radiation necrosis of the brain stem (Choice D) would cause symptoms of midbrain, pons, and medulla infarcts. The cranial nerve nuclei along with ascending and descending spinal tracts would be affected. Symptoms would include impaired cranial nerve function and decreased sensorimotor function of the ipsilateral face and contralateral body. Lower extremity weakness would be accompanied by hyperreflexia, not hyporeflexia, because of the involvement of the upper motoneurons. Thrombosis of the anterior spinal artery (Choice E) causes dysfunction of the anterior tracts within the spinal cord including the corticospinal tract (loss of motor function), spinothalamic tract (loss of pain and temperature sensation), and anterior horns. Thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus (Choice F) is rare because of the large size of this sinus. However, when it does occur, thrombosis in this area results in severe headaches followed by the potential for altered mental status, bilateral neurologic deficits, and seizures. This patient's findings are more consistent with cauda equina syndrome secondary to metastatic spread of cancer.

explanation.educational_objective: Cauda equina syndrome occurs as a result of compression of the spinal nerve roots comprising the cauda equina. It may occur secondary to metastatic spread of cancer through cerebrospinal fluid pathways. Symptoms include lower extremity numbness, weakness, paralysis, hyporeflexia, perinea! anesthesia, fecal incontinence with poor rectal tone, and overflow incontinence Clinical

vignette.presentation:
49. A 45-year-o ld woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a
generalized tonic-clonic seizure lasting 1 minute. She had a headache 6 hours ago
and nausea and vomiting 2 hours ago. She has no history of seizures and has had
no medical problems other than hypertension treated with enalapril and
hydrochlorothiazide. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 100/min and
regular, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 230/140 mm Hg. She
appears drowsy but is responsive to commands. Examination shows no
abnormalities other than the funduscopic findings shown. Which of the following is
the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's presenting signs and symptoms of hypertension, tachycardia, altered mental status, tonic-clonic seizures, and optic disc edema are consistent with a diagnosis of hypertensive encephalopathy. Hypertensive encephalopathy may result from acute and severe increases in blood pressure and may manifest with headache, vomiting, agitation, altered mental status, and seizures. It may progress to obtundation and coma. Visual symptoms may result from cortical hypertension or from hypertensive retinopathy. Retinal findings may include optic disc edema and nerve fiber layer infarction or hemorrhage. Treatment includes carefully lowering the blood pressure while avoiding excessive ly rapid drops in blood pressure, which can cause cerebral or cardiac ischemia. In general, a decrease in the mean arterial pressure of 25% within the first hour is appropriate, with gradual correction over the next day or more following. Sodium nitroprusside is a potent vasodilator and is a preferred agent because of its very short half-life, allowing it to be titrated via intravenous infusion Clinical include optic disc edema and nerve fiber layer infarction or hemorrhage. In general, a decrease in the mean arterial pressure of 25% within the first hour is appropriate, with gradual correction over the next day or more following. Sodium nitroprusside is a potent vasodilator and is a preferred agent because of its very short half-life, allowing it to be titrated via intravenous infusion.

distractor_explanations.A: Clonidine is an oral or intravenous antihypertensive agent that stimulates a -adrenergic receptors. It is commonly used as an 2 adjunct oral agent for the management of hypertensive emergency but is less appropriate as initial pharmacotherapy.
distractor_explanations.B: Furosemide is an oral or intravenous loop diuretic. Diuretics are not typically used in the treatment of hypertensive emergency because of their comparative ly long half-life and duration of action.
distractor_explanations.C: Lisinopril is an oral angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor. Oral agents are not preferred in the initial management of hypertensive emergency.
distractor_explanations.E: Propranolol is an oral or intravenous nonselective ~ adrenergic blocker. It is not typically used as a primary agent in the treatment of hypertensive emergency because of its comparatively long half-life and duration of action.

It may progress to obtundation and coma. Retinal findings may include optic disc edema and nerve fiber layer infarction or hemorrhage. Sodium nitroprusside is a potent vasodilator and is a preferred agent because of its very short half-life, allowing it to be titrated via intravenous infusion Clinical

choices.text: Aquaporin-4 autoantibodies in the cerebrospinal fluid
Aquaporin-4 autoantibodies in the cerebrospinal fluid

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Aquaporin-4 autoantibodies in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) are diagnostic of neuromyelitis optica (NMO), a disease characterized by intense inflammation and demyelination of both the optic nerves and various spinal cord segments, with involvement of both grey and white matter. Common manifestations include episodes of optic neuritis, which manifests as vision loss and pain, and transverse myelitis, which can affect any level of the spinal cord. Other unique findings include episodes of hiccups with associated nausea and vomiting. The disease course is often described as relapsing and remitting, with some patients experiencing few symptoms between episodes. Treatment is with high-dose intravenous steroids and, occasionally, plasma exchange for acute attacks. Prophylaxis with eculizumab or other biologic agents is warranted at the time of diagnosis.

distractor_explanations.A: Abnormal echocardiography is seen in patients with strokes secondary to septic emboli from endocarditis, but this patient ··- •• • - - - • - ••• - ••••• - • - •• • - • - -· ' •• - - - •••••• - •••• -· •• - - - •••••• Clinical A) Abnormal echocardiography B) Antinuclear antibodies in the serum C) Aquaporin-4 autoantibodies in the cerebrospinal fluid D) Decreased peripheral nerve conduction velocities E) Decreased serum copper concentration Correct Answer: C. Aquaporin-4 autoantibodies in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) are diagnostic of neuromyelitis optica (NMO), a disease characterized by intense inflammation and demyelination of both the optic nerves and various spinal cord segments, with involvement of both grey and white matter. Common manifestations include episodes of optic neuritis, which manifests as vision loss and pain, and transverse myelitis, which can affect any level of the spinal cord. Other unique findings include episodes of hiccups with associated nausea and vomiting. The disease course is often described as relapsing and remitting, with some patients experiencing few symptoms between episodes. Treatment is with high-dose intravenous steroids and, occasionally, plasma exchange for acute attacks. Prophylaxis with eculizumab or other biologic agents is warranted at the time of diagnosis. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E. Abnormal echocardiography (Choice A) is seen in patients with strokes secondary to septic emboli from endocarditis, but this patient does not have any evidence of endocarditis, and strokes typically present with unilateral symptoms as opposed to bilateral symptoms, which is more consistent with a spinal cord syndrome. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) in the serum (Choice B) are a feature of many rheumatologic diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus. There is also a portion of the population that has positive ANA titers and no identifiable disease; thus, this is a nonspecific finding. Decreased peripheral nerve conduction velocities (Choice D) are characteristic of peripheral neuropathy, which usually manifests with sensory changes or weakness of the extremities in a stocking-g love distribution. NMO is a disease of the central nervous system (CNS), and this patient's findings of positive Babinski tests and hyperreflexia are consistent with a central pathology. Decreased serum copper concentration (Choice E) is not a feature of NMO. Increased copper concentration is seen in Wilson disease, which can present with psychosis, Kayser-Fleischer rings, and cirrhosis.

explanation.educational_objective: NMO is a disease of the CNS with a characteristically relapsing and remitting course that presents with episodes of optic neuritis, transverse myelitis, and intractable hiccups. The presence of aquaporin-4 autoantibodies in the CSF is diagnostic of this disorder
